I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

After giving this game another shot I began to recognize the undertones and direct references from other fantasy based nostalgia. This game has a ton of elements and biomes to explore. You can literally customize and build to your hearts content while fighting off droves of the undying, unyielding and unwavering forces within the world of Terraria. If you want a side scroller, plat-former, that has dungeons and dragons based game play with a lighthearted twist then look no further. 5/5 for Creativity, 10/10 for Game play and design.

Terraria is unironically the best use of 10 dollars on steam, you will get thousands of hours of fun, just look at me! I've got almost 1700 hours as of now on this game, and that's just on PC, I probably rack up a good 3000 in total throughout all of my adventures in this game. 

I won't spoil much about the game, but if you like, exploring, fighting, building, and becoming stronger by the second, Terraria is the game for you. It comes with many difficulty options ranging from a casual and relaxing experience to a challenge that makes Elden Ring look like baby's first game.

Oh and also everything in this game is a pop culture reference, and that's cool as hell.

Buy this game.

This game is truly amazing. From the music, to the different biomes, to weapons and more. I cannot even put into words how happy I was when I played with my friends on Terraria for the first time. And even to this day, I still play Terraria often. If you have enough money, I seriously reccommend this game.

Was a bit sceptical about all the hype surrounding this game but I have to say that it is easily one of the best games I have played. The default experience has dozens of ways you can play through it and the modded experience adds a whole new level to the game. I had easily sunk 100 hours on this game without even noticing it due to all the fun I was having. The music is phenomenal, atmosphere is amazing and everything else is perfectly done. 100% recommend getting this game and I still cant believe that this game is this cheap for the level it. I would go as far to say that the level of enjoyment and fun you get from this game is on par, if not higher, than most triple A games that cost upwards of ¬£60. I've gotten this game over 2-3 years ago and I still have fun whenever I play with friends or by myself. The game is easily a 9.8/10 with updates coming that improve the game further.

This game has had me hooked for countless hours more than what's on my account. I've noticed that my offline time isn't reflected in my online profile here on Steam. Nor can it even know how many hours I've sank into the Switch and Mobile editions. Yes, I own them all!

I am having a particularly odd situation with Terraria on my Steam Deck however. I've been slowly adding various titles to my new favorite gaming computer as I have interest in picking them back up again. I am somebody who does not have home internet. And you'd think that a game as widely playable as Terraria is, wouldn't have problems launching on (yet another) computer that's frequently offline. I'm disappointed to say that, as of right now, no internet means no being able to play on my Steam Deck in Game Mode. This distinction is made for a reason. We Steam Deck owners are fond of our ability to directly access our games in a streamlined fashion right from the default loading screen. For Terraria, however, if I want to play offline, I can do so if I reboot into desktop mode, launch Steam (in offline mode, of course) and then launch Terraria. However, leaving the comfy confines of Game Mode removes much of the joy of Game Mode. The ability to adjust TDP and refresh rates, easily having access to keybinds and much more from the Steam and Elispsis buttons. I'm not sure if this is an easy fix or not, but I look forward to the day that Game Mode works well for this title, offline as well as online.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what¬†he¬†really¬†is.

My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

If you haven't yet do yourself a favour and play this. Terraria is easily one of the best games you can buy, it offers hundreds of hours of fun alone or with friends. The game has such huge variety in tools, weapons, and blocks that all aspects of the game from the building to the combat never get stale, at this point at least once a year one of the homies will suggest doing a playthrough and we'll all sink a hundred hours and a couple of weeks of our lives into a playthrough, this game is one of the few that I started playing as a kid and continued playing into adulthood, highly recommend! 9/10.

Terraria is an interesting game. It can be confusing for beginners just starting the game but an experienced player or someone who watches a few YT vids can have a great time. Terraria is similar to Minecraft in many ways yet wildly different. In minecraft, you have to search and explore to find the bosses but in Terraria you touch one funny looking butterfly and you get screwed. Terraria is much more difficult and offers much more base game content while Minecraft offers a much more dynamic and customized multiplayer experience. Terraria is an excellent game with near endless possibilities.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

Terraria is an exciting and engaging fishing game for all ages and demographics!

One might expect that the time spent on "boss fights" and "survival" mechanics might detract from the game's overall fishing experience, but, after completing the 200 fishing quests required for the "Supreme Helper Minion!" achievement, I can comfortably say the Terraria is a welcome staple to my collection of fishing games. The sheer variety of big catches and procedurally generated lakes and beaches makes each new world a unique fishing experience to enjoy for hours.

Terraria is a surprisingly fun game. There is a multitude of bosses and two large parts of the game in one world. in Pre - Hardmode you can find many awesome NPCs that you can build houses for, look at their shop, and see all of their different tips and tricks. If you ever need help or are stuck not knowing what to do, talk to the guide. The guide is your first NPC that spawns in right next to you when your world starts. He will try to help you with crafting recipies, tips, and more. Terraria also has a second stage called Hardmode which is basically a whole different stage compared to pre - hardmode. Overall, Terraria is a lot of fun and a very good game. Im saying this with 380 hours of experience in Terraria.
Get the game, its amazing and there are 0 downsides except maybe the time of your life you'll never get back

Ahh, Terraria, where do we begin? I guess the Npcs! They have deep lore, good cutscenes, and are just a huge game element in general. Next, making money and profesions. profesions allow extra abilities, which can help to make money. making money also isnt complicated at all, you can farm, fish, forage for items, go mining, etc. Honestly, Altho mining and upgrading tools, and watering can get tiresome, there are always scents of reward everywhere. The only things I think it needs is a built-in creative mode, and that kids can grow up bigger than a toddler. Apart from that, it is a wonderful game whit amazing music!

Edit: I just wanted to make sure people understand that there are a ton of mods on this game, including CBJ item menu (which is personally use)

Terraria is a top tier sandbox game. 
Every world is uniquely generated, with beauty and terrors across the land. There are countless resources and materials to be gathered and crafted into powerful weapons and armor. Fueled by an endless sense of progression, there are a variety of combat classes to enter, growing stronger to face the monsters and bosses of the world. Each defeated boss unlocks even more possibilities, filling the world with even more metals, creatures, and NPCs.  Then you can fill the world with your own structures, farms, and homes for the many NPCs to fill and offer you their wares.
Terraria is amazing because it is filled with possibilities and rewards at every corner.

This game has to be one of my favorite games, if not, my favorite. I've been playing since about 2014 and have put over 800 hours into it across all platforms. This game is easily the most repayable game I have ever set my hands on. If I had to choose between Minecraft and this, I would choose this every time. Once you play this game, you realize how many more things there is to do  rather than minecraft. There is so many more items, bosses, bricks, weapons, armor, pets, mobs biomes, etc... With Minecraft already being a super fun game to replay I'm sure you will find even more ways to replay this game.

It's wild to look back and see how far this game has come in the decade since its release. The devs have poured so much love into this experience. With how deep the base game's content is, along with how massive the modding community is, this for 10$ might be the best deal on Steam.

When I first saw this game, I didn't like it. There were to many things on screen that I wasn't used to. Then, my cousin convinced me to give it a try because he loved it and wanted to play with me. At first, didn't like the way it was set up. There were no crafting recipes, so I didn't know how to get any better items. The combat felt a little weird. The hardest part about it is that they don't tell you where to go at all. After defeating the wall of flesh, it does start to give you little hints for what you should do, but it doesn't tell you how to do any of it. In a way, that is also were it shines. In a way similar to how minecraft treats it, the game throws you into the world and say explore. The game doesn't have story, so there is no need to rush whatever your doing. While there are bosses & items locked behind progression, there is an infinite amount of things you can do. Getting bored of not having a challenge? Simply make a new world in expert mode, or find unique ways to kill the guide. Even if you have done all that, there are still mods. Tired of nothing being a challenge anymore? Simply download Calamity or other big mods and it will feel like Terraria's final boss in a baby for what those mods have in store for you. Terraria is definitely a confusing game at first glance, but if you pull through that and start to understand what your doing, endless fun can be had.

This is the same sandbox game where you can make all your dreams come true, in the sense of buildings, collecting things from bosses, and so on, in this game you can create your own world, make it how you want.

Plot: There is little plot here, or rather there is practically none, so I can‚Äôt say much about it.

GAMEPLAY: What about it, in terrarium 2D graphics, pixelated, but I don‚Äôt look at this game is worth the money, since it is a sandbox, here you can do everything from digging in a mine to eliminating bosses, in terrarium there are more than 600 types of swords alone! You can imagine it is 100 times more than in minecraft, the production of these swords is difficult, it is difficult to get them, there is an open world in the terraria, which is actually logical, the game is difficult, you can spend a lot of resources on one boss, a lot of time, and then screw it up , and then you again need to collect these resources, and spend a lot of time on this.

GRAPHICS: Any grandfather's computer from the times of the USSR will pull Terraria, so really, if in the world of games you are only interested in terraria, then you have a very large selection of laptop computers.

MINUSES: Updates stopped coming out in the game, the developers scored on the game, because they believe that they brought it to the end, and the maximum. There is no plot, only a small 3-5% of modern games with a plot

PROS: Open world, sandbox, catching fish, digging in a mine, jumping on clouds, building houses, bases, cities, exploring the world, this is one of the pluses of this game, I can also add that the game is optimized just for all PCs, and platforms, which is also a plus.

CONCLUSION: The game is beautiful, as well as the developers who have tried a lot on this project, terraria, which received steam awards in 2021, has proved that it is the best sandbox for the entire existence of mankind! I advise everyone to buy this wonderful game, thank you for your attention)

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

Upon creating a character (as long as it isn't a Journey Mode character, in which case you will receive the Iron Shortsword), you automatically receive the Copper Shortsword. Should you have tossed it out however, a new one can be made with 5 Copper Bars (15 Copper Ore). You should try to keep the old one however, as tin is not a replacement. Players with tin worlds will need to obtain copper from crates, the Extractinator, kill Slimes carrying copper ore, or go to another world that has copper.  The Starfury is a sword that creates falling star projectiles, similar to the Fallen Stars found at night. It can be found inside chests on Floating Islands. Keep in mind, though, that not all chests contain a Starfury, and not all islands have a chest. If no chests have a Starfury, it is necessary to fish for Sky Crates.  Terraria's Sword in the Stone, the Enchanted Sword is a sword that shoots sword beams and can be found in Enchanted Sword Shrines. You'll recognize one when you see a 1 block wide shaft leading to a rainbow shaped cave at the end with 2 pools of water on each side and a sword in the middle. Enchanted Sword Shrines are rare and are not guaranteed in a World. Furthermore, a lot of the time, the sword is fake. You can tell if it is fake if the sword look dull and bland. A real one has blue and yellow with a red jewel connecting the blade and the hilt. A real sword has 90% of dropping the Enchanted Sword (item), and a 10% chance dropping a Terragrim. If you were unable to find a Sword Shrine, you can also obtain it by opening Golden or Titanium Crates. Golden Crates can be fished in Pre-Hardmode, while Titanium Crates can be fished in Hardmode. Both crates contain roughly the same loot.  The Bee Keeper is a sword that inflicts the Confused debuff to enemies that it hits. When it hits an enemy, it also releases friendly bees that will damage nearby enemies. It has a 33% chance of dropping from the Queen Bee. Queen Bee can be summoned by breaking Larva inside Bee Hives, which are located in the Underground Jungle, or by using the Abeemination in the surface or underground Jungle biome. See Guide:Queen Bee strategies for more information on how to defeat the Queen Bee.  The Seedler is a Hardmode sword that you can obtain from defeating Plantera, with a 14.29% chance of dropping. When used, it fires out seed-like projectiles, which explode into tiny shards upon a period of time or when hitting an enemy.  Plantera can only be summoned by breaking Plantera's Bulbs, a naturally spawning object that can generate after all mechanical bosses are defeated. See Guide:Plantera strategies for more information on how to defeat Plantera.  The Horseman's Blade is a Hardmode post-Plantera sword that has a 12.5% chance of dropping from Pumpking, an event boss that spawns during a Pumpkin Moon. It spawns pumpkin heads that home in on enemies after hitting an enemy. The Pumpkin Moon can only be initiated by using a Pumpkin Moon Medallion. See Guide:Pumpkin Moon strategies for more information on how to survive a Pumpkin Moon and defeat Pumpking.  The Influx Waver is a Hardmode, post-Golem sword that has a  16.67% (1/6) chance (11.11% (1/9) chance in  Console and Mobile versions) of dropping from Martian Saucer, an event boss that spawns during Martian Madness. When used, it fires a sword beam projectile that after hitting an enemy, can return up to two times to attack the same enemy or other nearby enemies. The Martian Madness event is initiated when a Martian Probe detects a player and is let to escape. See Guide:Martian Madness strategies for more information on how to survive Martian Madness and defeat the Martian Saucer.  The Star Wrath is a Hardmode sword that has a 11.11% (1/9) chance of dropping from the Moon Lord. Whenever it's swung, three falling star projectiles shoot out from above towards the cursor's direction, dealing double the sword's base damage. The projectiles produce light and can pierce. The Moon Lord boss is summoned after defeating all four Celestial Pillars during the Lunar Events, or by using a Celestial Sigil. See Guide:Lunar Events strategies for more information on how to complete the Lunar Events and defeat the Moon Lord.  The Meowmere is a Hardmode sword that has a 11.11% (1/9) chance of dropping from the Moon Lord. It spawns a cat's head projectile with a rainbow trail when swung, which is affected by gravity, pierces multiple enemies, and ricochets four times, dissipating on the fifth hit. The Moon Lord boss is summoned after defeating all four Celestial Pillars during the Lunar Events, or by using a Celestial Sigil. See Guide:Lunar Events strategies for more information on how to complete the Lunar Events and defeat the Moon Lord. It should be noted that although the Meowmere has a higher listed base damage than the Zenith, the Zenith has a much higher DPS overall.  The Terra Blade is a Hardmode sword that is crafted from various different swords that you can obtain throughout the entire progression of the game. It is made by combining a True Excalibur and a True Night's Edge, which is crafted by combining the Excalibur and the Night's Edge each with a Broken Hero Sword, a material dropped from Mothron during the Solar Eclipse. The Excalibur is made using Hallowed Bars obtained from defeating Mechanical bosses, while the Night's Edge is made by combining the following swords at an Altar: Blade of Grass, Muramasa, Fiery Greatsword, and either the Light's Bane or the Blood Butcherer. See Guide:Crafting a Terra Blade for more info on how to craft a Terra Blade.  Once all the necessary swords are obtained, you can craft a Zenith at a Mythril or Orichalcum anvil.  The Zenith is a Hardmode, post-Moon Lord melee weapon crafted using a variety of swords obtained throughout the game's progression. When swung, the sword sprites of its component swords fly towards enemies within a 20-tile radius of the cursor (regardless of where the cursor is on the screen), and circle back in quick, frenzied arcs. They pass through solid blocks, and three swords will appear per use (at base melee speed). Each sword sprite deals the weapon's full damage. The Zenith is capable of autoswing. Its best modifier is Legendary.  The first sword generated on each swing will always be a Zenith projectile, which generates a mint green trail. Each sword generated will have a unique swing color, which generates a large amount of light. This can be used to reveal parts of the minimap. The Zenith ignores enemy invincibility frames. The Zenith can attack anywhere that the cursor can reach. Its range can be increased simply by using higher resolutions, larger monitors, or even multiple monitors. This is no longer true in 1.4.1, as Zenith can only go up to 600 pixels vertically and 960 pixels horizontally. Equipment and modifiers that increase melee speed change the number of swords that appear per use, but have no effect on the number of swords thrown per second, nor the swords' velocity. Each individual sword sprite may register multiple hits on an enemy, depending on size and positioning. Swords also deal damage behind the player on their return trip. Despite being nearly identical to its copper counterpart, the Tin Shortsword cannot be used to craft the Zenith. This is presumably due to the Copper Shortsword's role as the very first sword every player will encounter (with the exception of Journey Mode characters). The Zenith appears to have semi-homing capabilities. When the sword is dragged near an enemy, but not enough for the natural arch to reach it, one sword sprite will come out of the loop and hit the enemy.[1] This is especially useful in the Mobile version Mobile version, for players who are keen on using Aim and Use, as such toggle restricts the Zenith's range considerably. The Zenith is generally agreed to be the game's strongest weapon, making it ideal for any type of fight.

The memories I have from Terraria are all very close to my heart. Terraria was the first game my parents ever bought for me that I played on a crappy computer around when the game it was released. Even without the Wall of Flesh, Hardmode, Moon Lord, mods, or large crew of npcs this game held my attention for hours as a kid. I am writing this review out of nostalgia because due to some miracle, all of the worlds I committed to the cloud over the years magically uncorrupted themselves earlier today. That window into the past brought back so many hundreds of hours of fun, intrigue, anger, happiness, and so much more which brought a genuine smile to me. Terraria is a game that can be enjoyed by someone of any age, I would reccomend older people enjoy it with friends but that is not necessary. I will not say something as cheesy as, "the possibilities are limitless," because without mods Terraria is a very linear game progression wise. The part of this game that keeps on giving for me is how I can log on with friends and forget the world for a few hours as we explore a world and build within it. I have nothing negative to say. The developers care about the game and its players, which is evident in the content and extra releases still happening after the, "Journey's end," update. If anyone who has ever been on the developer team reads this review, I want to thank you for over a thousand hours of happiness both when I was a kid and now as an adult. If you have not bought Terraria yet, find a few friends and figure it out together, the wiki is a great tool. Thank you for reading, I know this is a long winded and messy review, I just cannot put my love for this game into words.

This game has a lot of potential for hundreds of hours of fun. It has literally hundreds of weapons, blocks, and enemies alongside multiple types of invasions and dozens of bosses for you to work towards beating. The staggering amount of variety found in this game works well with the different difficulty levels and almost completely unrestricted building to allow you to create anything your imagination desires as well as fostering an absolutely tremendous amount of re-play ability. If you somehow don't already own this game and are a fan of the genre, do yourself a favor and get yourself a copy because I promise you wont regret it.

Many people compare Terraria and Minecraft, and it's true; they are both voxel-based mining games. However, Terraria simmers a lot of what Minecraft is and then makes up for it in the exciting combat. Please don't get me perplexed, you can still create fantastic and exciting structures in Terraria, but the euphoria that some Minecraft creations can invoke is not found in Terraria. Suppose you prefer an emphasis on combat, boss battles, and equipment upgrades. But still want to be able to mine resources, create defenses, and terraform. In that case, Terraria is most certainly a great option. This review is why it's one of my favorite games on Steam.

I am a 48 year old mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my son, who is now 14. My son recently downloaded Terraria and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my husband had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

10/10

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Genuinely some of the most fun I've had in a game with my friends in a very long while. Nothing beats setting yourself up to beat up every single boss the world has to offer, creating artificial biomes to farm out new and exciting items, even building homes for NPC's so they can have a house even after you leave. 

A sentimental feeling comes over me as I finish another run, but it's worth smiling about, you know? The content people make, the community's ideas, even the developers, everyone makes this game worth playing. Genuinely, if you haven't before, it'll be some of the best ten dollars you'll ever spend. I know it was for me.

From fighting waves of bosses with my brother to trying to scrounge up the materials to make the Ankh Shield and Zenith... it's been an amazing journey.

I am a 64 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 16. My son recently started Terraria and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

Terraria is one of the few games I continue to play long after completing all achievements and many many play throughs. I cannot recommend it more to anyone who enjoys a thorough, well thought out adventure game. Including challenging boss battles, dynamic gameplay, creative building mechanics and the most enjoyable multiplayer aspect I have experienced in a game. 
Over 800 hours of gameplay later I use this game as a baseline for all other games. If another game gives me close to the same enjoyment as this game then it is worth my time. 
My only fault with the game is that there are no longer any updates coming, however, this seems reasonable considering the game is quite old at this stage.

I've played Terraria off and on across multiple platforms since it's initial release. It's ALWAYS been a game I've come back to. I have so many fond memories of this game, and with mods through tModLoader, I've gotten well over 2k hours out of this game. (Hours aren't properly tracked on Steam). Terraria is easily one of the best games I've ever played and any survival/builder game I play is compared directly to Terraria, even if it isn't 2D. I love this game and the developers Re-digit are so amazing, talented and friendly towards the community that it's one of those games you can support year after year without a doubt in your mind as to who or what you're supporting. Absolutely love this game, I can't say enough good things about it.

It's on almost every platform. If you haven't played Terraria, do yourself a favor and play this fantastic, amazing game!

You came here for a review, but you're leaving with a Pumpkin Pie Recipe that'll please all your Terrarians this spooky season!

Ingredients
Pat-in-the-Pan Pastry
- 1 1/3 cups all-purpose flour
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
- 1/3 cup vegetable oil
- 2 tablespoons cold water

Filling
- 2 eggs
- 1/2 cup sugar
- 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
- 1/2 teaspoon ground ginger
- 1/8 teaspoon ground cloves
- 1 can (15 oz) pumpkin (not pumpkin pie mix)
- 1 can (12 oz) evaporated milk

Sweetened Whipped Cream
- 3/4 cup whipping cream
- 2 tablespoons sugar

Steps

1. Heat oven to 425¬∞F. In medium bowl, mix flour, 1/2 teaspoon salt and the oil with fork until all flour is moistened. Sprinkle with cold water, 1 tablespoon at a time, tossing with fork until all water is absorbed. Shape pastry into a ball. Press in bottom and up side of 9-inch glass pie plate.

2. In large bowl, beat eggs slightly with wire whisk or hand beater. Beat in 1/2 cup sugar, the cinnamon, 1/2 teaspoon salt, ginger, cloves, pumpkin and milk.

3. To prevent spilling, place pastry-lined pie plate on oven rack before adding filling. Carefully pour pumpkin filling into pie plate. Bake 15 minutes.

4. Reduce oven temperature to 350¬∞F. Bake about 45 minutes longer or until knife inserted in center comes out clean. Place pie on cooling rack. Cool completely, about 2 hours.

5. In chilled medium bowl, beat whipping cream and 2 tablespoons sugar with electric mixer on high speed until stiff peaks form. Serve pie with whipped cream. Store in refrigerator.

I nominate Terraria for Steam's "Labor of Love" award every year. The devs have put so much work into this game, even when they've said they were all done, and it shows. Many people summarize Terraria as "2D Minecraft," which is true to an extent, but it's also so much more. I love the build variety, cute pets, exploration, and crazy boss battles Terraria has to offer. It's a game I'll always come back to eventually.

Game play for me felt better than single-player minecraft. All throughout felt better than minecraft but is definitely more grindy like certain armour or weapons requiring a lot of the specific ore to craft. This point is not that bad overall as if you are able to have a video in the background then it makes this whole process way easier. Pre-hardmode for me is boring and slow but not because of a lot of content that is too much to get through but more because mining and getting around takes ages as you do not have the gear. The game is very replayable with different classes comes different play styles. Melee which was my favourite as high damage and high armour, following the boss around. With melee you only really manage health but if you are playing terraria then everybody has to so I guess just not dying. When to ingage and disengage to heal; being melee you are the tank and the boss will follow you so knowing when to do these two things are kinda important. Early game melee for me (maybe different for others) kinda sucks as you actually have to melee lol. After hardmode, pretty much all melee weapons become ranged so there is no real melee weapons where you have to go close to the enemy to do damage (of course being within hitting range of an enemy with a hardmode melee weapon does more damage but why would you risk taking big damage against a boss). Mage and range are similar both having to manage something with mage being mana and ranged being ammo types like bullets or arrows. Both these classes are high DPS so if you are looking for a less tanky build but high dps, these two are good choices (I think that ranger is a slightly more tanky but less dps class, thought this point is kinda weird as armour sets in the game can allow for tanky builds of both of these classes but I meant in a more general way). I am glad for the kinda recent update for summoner, adding in whips was good as before, if you had summoned all your minions then you would just take a weapon from a different class and use it. These are my least played classes so I do not know much about them. I only really played with friends and then I only played melee because for me it was simple and boss followed you. Re-logic added NPCs needing appropriate housing was kinda annoying but oh well.

Early boss fights can be annoying but after the first couple times, they become very easy, the only real limitation could be the lack of armour or accessories. They can be seen as interesting fights but for me, I kinda just skipped king slime until I got the eye of Cthulhu shield (expert mode drop) then went back for him. Skeletron when you are prepared can still be a decently hard fight but after a couple defeats and getting down the moveset, can be easy. Queen bee can be skipped but I would say to always try fight because the game its in the game, the drops are also very useful for wall of flesh fight. WALL OF FLESH is one annoying piece of flesh. Whenever I play and it might be because I am just bad but I cannot defeat this dude first time on a playthrough. Very annoying but with my indomitable human spirit, I persevered and continued through. If you are new, this where the game puts on its big boy pants. Normal enemies before that would be one shot with your pre-hardmode gear will now hit you for half your health but with terraria, a bit of mining and breaking demon altars later, you will be able to take on the mech bosses. They are the next big hurdle. Skeletron prime, the twins and the destroyer. I feel like everyone has a problem with one of these mech bosses and finds the other ones easy. For me, the destroyer was always a walk in the park, the twins always kicked my ass and skeletron prime was kinda a challenge but with the second challenge I always won. The next hurdle is plantera; prepare carefully and this should be a walk in the park. Making a larger arena that what you think will be needed will always be helpful for all the bosses. The defeat of plantera unlocks the golem. For me golem was another walk in the park. Lunatic cultist and moon lord are next but you can defeat duke fishron for extra weapons for the upcoming fights. Lunatic cultist for me was not a memorable fight, it went by too quickly, maybe I was over prepared. Moon lord is next. Moon lord is difficult. I never can defeat it on my first try. But this is it. The last boss (not really as there is now the queen slime) before finishing endgame. All the building for NPCs, potion making, gear gathering, all the bosses, mining and farming mobs. It all leads to this. After the pillars are down, its time. The fight will be tough but the feeling you get when defeating it is worth it, and thats it. Game over. End game content is pretty much just destroying previous bosses you had trouble with with end game gear.

I have never wrote reviews before so there is probably a lot of errors but this took too long for me so ask any questions you have and I will try to answer them quickly. Overall, game is very good. Has a very active modding community which I have not touched on. If you enjoy Terraria then download tmodloader, calamity is very good and offers post end game content so even more stuff to do. 

TLDR -  GAME IS GOOD, PRICE IS AMAZING, GOOD MODDING COMMUNITY **BUY IF THIS IN ANY WAY FITS YOUR STYLE OF GAMES, EVEN IF IT DOES NOT THEN EVEN TRYING YOU MAY ENJOY IT**

Terraria - an addicting and amazing game

Back in February, my friends introduced me to this game, and it was the best thing I ever experienced. The progression system is super good, and each step you take feels so satisfying, especially when you get stuck at a certain part and finally overcome the challenge presented.

Terraria also contains plenty of weapons, items, class builds, and features. Whether you want to dish out tons of damage, be super fast, or tank anything and everything that could possibly hurt you, it's all possible in Terraria.

This game is also very grindy, so have fun spending lots of time to get one weapon or item you so desire, but the feeling of attaining it will be like no other. 

Overall, 10/10 game, would absolutely recommend.

I've played this game for around a hundred hours at the time of making this review, so I thought it was time to do a review.

Terraria is a great game. Often people call it "2d Minecaft" either ironically or otherwise, but it seriously isn't. This game may share similarities with minecraft in the way that you can build pretty much whatever you want and you begin the game by harvesting a tree however that's about as far as it gets. Terraria includes boss fights, a variety of npcs and enemies, as well as a replay-able class system. There are 5 damage types in Terraria, which includes the four "classes" (With a classless class), these are: Ranged, Melee, Magic and Summon. There is also just "damage" damage, which is the classless class I mentioned prior. 

I wont go into modding for it is an entirely different thing, but it is much like the base game but even better. If you are to mod the game I recommend the calamity mod, it's difficult but insanely fun.

[h1] Personal Description [/h1]
I was originally going to write this review saying how this is not 2D Minecraft but as I was thinking about the differences, yeah, this is 2D Minecraft. You start with practically nothing, gather wood, go mining for resources to craft new things, fight bosses, get super op, beat the final boss. Yes, I'm well aware of the differences between the games like items, and game mechanics but honestly, mods can change all of that for both games. So if you're looking for 2D Minecraft with more of a focus on mystical stuff, here you go.

[h1] Ratings [/h1]
Here is where I rate each aspect of Terraria based on my player experience. 0 = Low | 10 = high

[b] Graphics [/b]
7/10 - Good for a pixel game. Not like ray-tracing is gonna do much here lol

[b] Price [/b]
0/10 - Honestly, I think $10 USD is too cheap for a game like this.

[b] Grinding [/b]
5/10 - Game progression is slow and fast at different points of the game so grinding is pretty necessary.

[b] Combat [/b]
8/10 - For me, being a mage is the most fun so I really enjoyed the combat. 

[b] Exploration [/b]
3/10 - It's like playing Minecraft. A world is a world and sometimes you'll find some cool random generation.

[b] Audio/Soundtrack [/b]
6/10 - No complaints. Nothing epic but the mood fits.

[b] Story [/b]
0/10 - Does Terraria have a story? I'm not Mattpat so I'm not gonna go searching for a story that isn't right in front of me.

[b] Bugs) [/b]
0/10 - Pretty damn polished. 

[b] Multiplayer [/b]
Exactly as you'd expect. Works very well and players can do just about anything in eachother's worlds.

[b] Overall Gameplay [/b]
9/10 - I may have scored low on a bunch of the categories but I still rate this game high. You'll have a blast if this is your type of game.

HOW IS TERRARIA ONLY 10 DOLLARS???????????????????

(if you don't want to read my rant, skip to the bottom for a summary, I won't blame you if you skip, it's pretty boring.)

Terraria is an amazing game that is worth well over 10 dollars, at least 25 in my opinion. There is so many things to do, explore, fight bosses, build, craft, and mine. You can also download mods, which make the game even better somehow. 
There is a variety of styles to play, for example, you can play on the challenging Expert or Master difficulties, with A.I changes and enemies being much stronger. Or you can play on the relaxing, (Or living hell) Journey difficulty, which starts you out with better gear and being able to research items to duplicate them as much as you want, as well as godlike powers, including changing the weather, time, difficulty, monster spawns, etc.
There is also 4 main 'classes', each one has it's own unique traits and gameplay, every class is described here in no particular order: 
Melee, the most standard class, uses close range weapons, like swords and maces, due to this, melee has higher defense than all other classes, although when you reach a certain progress point, the melee class becomes mostly based off of swords shooting projectiles, but the defense remains, therefore melee is objectively the easiest class.
The second class is the Mage class, a mage uses magic weapons, like staffs and spells, that excel in almost every way, they are very good at controlling crowds of enemies and have high damage. The drawback to this is, using magic weapons costs Mana, which can be replenished by potions and regenerating it naturally, the Mage class is mostly about conserving and regenerating Mana, causing it to be on the more complex side.
The most simple class in my opinion is the ranger class, a ranger uses weapons such as bows and guns, they can also use throwing weapons such as grenades and knives, the ranger class requires farming for ammo to shoot your weapons, the ammo types are diverse, some home, some pierce, some give enemies debuffs, some bounce, and some are just normal straight shots. The gun types also differ, some being fully auto, and others being semi auto, some shoot differently than others, like shooting multiple bullets at once, or shooting other projectiles, that after a delay, shoot bullets toward the cursor. All in all, the ranger class is a fun one.
And finally the last class, Summoner, Summoners summon creatures such as imps and spiders, even other things like dragons or magic swords, as well as using summons, they use whips which enhance your ability to deal damage, such as increasing whip speed or summoning an extra projectile on hit with enemies, or just directly increasing how much damage your summons do, Summoner is the most complex class in my opinion, but also very fun.


SUMMARY HERE:
Terraria is a very very fun game that highly focuses on combat and exploration, it has lots of customization options, leading it to be a very fun game in general.

I played other games of this genre, and I have to admit... the start is way too boring and way too hard. The usual cycle of 'go find better gear, to delve deeper, to get even better gear' is marred by the first tiers of weapons feeling like wet paper under the barrage of monsters that can jump over you and kill you in just some hits.

Plus, crafting materials cost way too much, three to five ores to make a bar, sure. but to make a full set, you need something akin to fifty bars and more, while most veins will give you... one bar if you're lucky. Plus, some bosses require you to sacrifice materials that, by then, still insanely rare to get, and you won't progress until you kill them. Having to go to an npc for them to explain to you what you can do with x materials is cute on paper, but in reality everyone will just go to the wiki... which shouldn't happen.

A well-rounded experience with near limitless replayability and high modding potential. From the first to the last boss, it's a wild ride, and it only gets better with friends. Even if there's something you don't like about the game, there's a mod for that. Don't like a recipe? There's a mod for that. Want more content? There's a mod for that. Want to endlessly grind, or minimize the grind as much as possible? There's mods for that, too. This game is a top-tier 10/10 in my books, with 1,000 hours in Terraria and 300 in Tmodloader, I can say with 100% certainty that this game is a great way to burn many, many hours of your time when you're bored, especially for its price. Go crazy, Terrarians.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

I'd be hard pressed to believe you haven't heard of this game. Question is, should you play it in its current state? Well, yes and no...

The game is fun, there is a LOT you can do in this game. If you like Minecraft, I highly recommend this game to you. You will enjoy it just as much as Minecraft, maybe even more. It's just different... There's a reason Terraria recommends Minecraft and vice versa.

The only thing about this game that might not be enjoyable to some is its difficulty and how "lost" you can feel. There's only so much you can do pre-hard mode... What is hard mode? Well, you beat this boss in literal hell and then the game "advances" too hard mode where enemies are harder, new things spawn and whole sections of your world change. It can be pretty overwhelming and takes a lot of time to get used to, but if you feel like dumping a lot of hours into this game so you can feel like an overpowered god this is right for you.

I highly suggest at least giving the game a try. The developers really care about this game and continue to update it with new and fun things to do. The games price is also a lot better than games you'll see these days. And I even got the game on sale and let me tell you I'd pay full price for it. In fact, I have on Xbox One. The game is cheap, fun and has so much you can do in it I highly doubt you'll do everything there is to do in the game.

I love this game SO much. The game progression is very smooth. You make one weapon and set of armor, immediately you can see the next goal and know what to do. Which, there is ALWAYS something to do. The building allows for creative builds. The grind for drops and such can be irritating (*cough cough* fishing), but is SO rewarding when you get what you are looking for. Combat and classes are perfect, with balanced bosses and weapons. Multiplayer is very fun, with little lag at all and allowing for great co-op play.

I would be fine with the game just getting harder, like just higher health/damage bosses. But in the game's Hardmode (which is inevitable, regardless of difficulty), there's a thing called The Hallow. And The Hallow is very very annoying in my opinion. It slowly corrupts everything, turning it into a mess (and making you miss out on some content), unless you do a very long and boring process.

Terraria is a open world 2D game with a fun and unique twist. You can play the game and mine and mine to your hearts content but you will never have better armor then the armor and weapons you can get from bosses. Their are many different play styles, if you like being close up to your enemies their are a wide array of options to pick from. Their is also different armor sets that can complement your play style. Over all it is a great game that I would definitely recommend to all types of Gamers.
Fun Indie game to play if you're looking for an intricate 2D MineCraft.

Massively open world and there are a lot to explore. Terraria has cool Easter eggs, interesting artwork and a general feeling of either calm or when you pick master mode a feeling of wanting to rip your soul out.

After about 30 hours the gameplay loop, grind and RNG become boring, which is a shame because the end game content is cool, there's just too much filler to get to it. I'd like a condensed version of this game with less grinding and repetative tasks. Inventory management is a total headache, mods can help though.
Game is extremely fun, and in a way competitive if you want it to be. All around great.

I've played this game for awhile. Loved Vanilla, tried modded and enjoyed some well renowned mods through multiple playthroughs, and even enjoyed quite a few challenge runs including each class/limited weapons, Upside down, builder only etc. I enjoy other games, but i still find myself coming back to it all the time, be it with friends or by myself, sometimes for new personal challenges, but mainly to just relax. 

The only problem I have is that with the update 1.4, I don't know what changed, but I just don't enjoy it as much. There's plenty of new content that changes the game, mostly for the better, and I still enjoy it and come back from time to time, but its just not the same.

Sticky Toffee Pudding 

Ingredients
For the pudding
225g whole medjool dates
175ml boiling water
1 tsp vanilla extract
175g self-raising flour, plus extra for greasing
1 tsp bicarbonate of soda
2 eggs
85g butter, softened, plus extra for greasing
140g demerara sugar
2 tbsp black treacle
100ml milk
cream or custard to serve (optional)
For the toffee sauce
175g light muscovado sugar
50g butter, cut into pieces
225ml double cream
1 tbsp black treacle
Method
STEP 1
Stone and chop 225g medjool dates quite small, put them in a bowl, then pour over 175ml boiling water.

STEP 2
Leave for about 30 mins until cool and well-soaked, then mash a bit with a fork. Stir in 1 tsp vanilla extract.

STEP 3
Butter and flour seven mini pudding tins (each about 200ml/7fl oz) and sit them on a baking sheet. Heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4.

STEP 4
While the dates are soaking, make the puddings. Mix 175g self-raising flour and 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda together and beat the 2 eggs in a separate bowl.

STEP 5
Beat 85g softened butter and 140g demerara sugar together in a large bowl for a few mins until slightly creamy (the mixture will be grainy from the sugar). Add the eggs a little at a time, beating well between additions.

STEP 6
Beat in 2 tbsp black treacle then, using a large metal spoon, gently fold in one-third of the flour and bicarbonate of soda mix, then half of the 100ml milk, being careful not to overbeat. Repeat until all the flour mix and all the milk is used.

STEP 7
Stir the soaked dates into the pudding batter. The mix may look a little curdled at this point and will be like a soft, thick batter.

STEP 8
Spoon it evenly between the tins and bake for 20-25 mins, until risen and firm.

STEP 9
Meanwhile, put the 175g light muscovado sugar and 50g butter pieces for the sauce in a medium saucepan with half the 225ml double cream.

STEP 10
Bring to the boil over a medium heat, stirring all the time, until the sugar has completely dissolved.

STEP 11
Stir in 1 tbsp black treacle, turn up the heat slightly and let the mixture bubble away for 2-3 mins until it is a rich toffee colour, stirring occasionally to make sure it doesn‚Äôt burn. Take the pan off the heat and beat in the rest of the double cream.

STEP 12
Remove the puddings from the oven. Leave in the tins for a few mins, then loosen them well from the sides of the tins with a small palette knife before turning them out.

STEP 13
You can serve them now with the sauce drizzled over, but they‚Äôll be even stickier if left for a day or two coated in the sauce. To do this, pour about half the sauce into one or two ovenproof serving dishes.

STEP 14
Sit the upturned puddings on the sauce, then pour the rest of the sauce over them. Cover with a loose tent of foil so that the sauce doesn‚Äôt smudge (no need to chill).

STEP 15
When ready to serve, heat oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4. Warm the puddings through, still covered, for 15-20 mins or until the sauce is bubbling. Serve them on their own, or with cream or custard.

As you can tell I have put a good number of hours into Terraria, probably more will be poured into it as I am typing. I am hooked on this game and learned so much that it has enhanced every single play-through I have had and the number of guides and the wiki makes it even easier to find what you need help with. I can whole-heartedly say that Terraria is much easier to get into than Minecraft another game I poured a good amount of hours into and simply removing the Z-axis has made this game less intimidating in MC am always getting lost because the world is just too huge and you'll be wandering aimlessly. In Terraria the game starts you off with a copper sword, ax, and pick-ax with you wanting to upgrade your tools really making this game feel like a Metroidvania. The accessories really are a plus with equipment that can make you run faster and negate fall damage outright you can really make the world into your play-thing. But with a world what are the dangers within, that's where the bosses come in monsters that will kill an unsuspecting player the first time around which will drive you even more into getting more powerful so you can obliterate your enemies and with the healthy amount of events sprinkled about this game will keep you on your toes with blood-moons that causes the undead the be relentless and goblins trying the raid your village there is so much I can talk about but I have to end this somewhere. So I highly recommend you purchase this game for yourself and give it a shot because this review has bearly scratched the surface of this gem of a game, thanks for reading.

This is one of the "classics" for me. Terraria is a sandbox, 2D open world survival craft game, where you progress by defeating enemies, making bases and building houses, and defeating bosses. The progression works within the enemies, and the world by itself. Not only this being extremely and highly moddable, but enjoyable on its own.

You should definitely try Terraria, If you're into:
-RPG-like hack n' slash combat and action
-freedom of what you can do in a randomly-generated world, like terraforming and architechury
-Difficult, yet possible and good challenges within the events that the bosses and enemies provide
-Modding and and extended progression and features within the skilled community
-Good games to grab alone, OR with your friends!

Terraria is without a doubt one of the best adventure games out there, mainly because it has a lot of content to give, such as bosses to defeat, items to obtain, and abilities to unlock; something that stands out from other games is that it allows you to completely modify the environment to your liking; the gameplay is good although it is not that advanced, the soundtrack surprises with extraordinary songs in each part of the game, and finally, the story is not continuous, so in an open world like this it is exciting to discover everything that one can because there are many things to do, in short, an excellent game and I recommend it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

My cousin introduced this game to me way back in 2013 (ish) and I've been playing ever since. I've put more time into this game than any other in my library and I can say it really does have something for everyone; boss fights, exploration, building, complimented by plenty of extremely rewarding progression and beautiful art style, all of which can be experienced with friends. It can run on really any computer and still look and runs fantastic, and along with massive community support and constant updates from the developers (even if their not updating it anymore they still update it.) The only thing I can even really say this game lacks is story (largely because it leans heavily on the fact that it's primarily a sandbox game, so I can't really knock it). But hey, their coming out with a comic book soon, so maybe this game really does have something for everyone.

[h1] Me and Terraria [/h1]
Although it doesn't show on my Steam Account, I've previously played over 2000 hours on the GoG version of Terraria, and have no regrets. Personally, it's my favourite game ever, and is one of the few games I return to play, several years after I first started playing it. I first booted up the game after downloading it on a sketchy illegal website back in 2013 (probably with more than a few viruses as well), and waiting hours for it to download. Upon first opening it, I had no idea how much I was going to fall in love with the game.

[h1] What is Terraria [/h1]
At it's core Terraria is a 2D open-world sandbox game, which spawns you in a randomly generated world with nothing more than a Copper Shortsword, Pickaxe and Axe, and an NPC called the Guide. On your journey to survive in this world, you'll dig, fight, explore and build, amassing an armada of loot and finding your own way to progress from battling Slimes to beating the Moon Lord.


Terraria itself contains an unbelievable amount of depth and replay value. Even playing the game in the most linear way possible (obtaining better gear and fighting increasingly difficult bosses) there's almost limitless ways to approach every portion of the game, which is in large part due to the sheer range of weapons, tactics and equipment/armour that's available, but is also aided by the randomly generated maps, and the sandbox nature of the game where any and all blocks can be mined or placed.

There's four difficulty modes (as of v1.4.3.6) Journey, Classic, Expert and Master. Each one ramps up the difficulty steeply, but the harder difficulties, Expert and Master make the game more engaging for experienced players, requiring more precise play and more nuanced tactics to complete the game.

In standard Terraria, there are four playable classes of weapons/armour (although there's no restrictions on what you can use), Melee, Ranged, Magic and Summoner, where each one rewards different playstyles, and makes specific points in the game easier or harder.

Did I mention that the game has fully functioning multiplayer as well? You can play with as many or as few players as you want in a world, which creates lasting memories between you and your companions.

[h1] tModLoader [/h1]
However, if you're not convinced, and are worried that you'll ever begin feeling bored of the main game (which I can assure you, will NOT happen quickly), there's a highly active and polished mod-client, tModLoader, with mods ranging from huge content mods which completely remake and extend the game (e.g. Calamity, Thorium) to Quality of Life mods that improve certain features in the game (e.g. Magic Storage, Terraria Overhaul, Improved Multiplayer) to cheat mods which can just completely break the game (Item Randomiser, Hero's Mod, Cheat Sheet). The sheer quality (ignoring Item Randomiser lol) and variety of mods can leave you browsing the tModLoader Workshop for hours on end.

[h1] Summary [/h1]
Personally Terraria is the most engaging game I've ever played, and I've lived through almost half of my life playing it, from Terraria 1.2 in 2013 to Journey's End in 2022, and I'm sure I'll still be playing it for many years to come. An originally great game loving supported and updated by the incredibly dedicated developers at ReLogic for over 12 years now, has made Terraria into a truly one of a kind game, making memories I'll cherish for the rest of my life. I hope in this review (I kept it brief) that I was able to convey my love for the game, and how much of an impact Terraria has played in my life.

Many people try to compare the game with minecraft, i`m not going to argue if its similar or not but I want to mention that the style and progression of the game is a lot more complex than minecraft.  with hundreds of more weapons, blocks, and mechanics this game is more like the roguelite cousin of the game,  you are constantly finding upgrades and replacing your tools rather than fixing the same tools durability.

Alot of people try to say the game is too grindy and if you are going for harder difficulties or 100%ing the game then yes it will be extremely grindy, but I think the game is constructed to split up the time you take exploring, mining for loot, building and upgrading houses, and then killing bosses usually in that order, thjis mixed with the hundreds of items in my opinion keeps the game fresh even after serveral runs, and there are different class specific armours and weapons to keep runs different from eachother if thats what you want.
The game also has an extensive community on wikis and steam workshop.

It's odd to say a pixelated game has managed to become one of, if not the best, video game of all time. Here we are nonetheless. To preface this, my steam game time is not reflective of my total game time, total it would be around 1900-2000 hours.

Now what makes Terraria so good? Well...many things.

Music. There is a serious argument to be made that Terraria has one of the best music selection in all of gaming. The songs don't adhere to a specific genre, however the best way to describe them as a whole would be electronic orchestral. The primary uses of Music in Terraria are between its biomes, bosses and events. The game has four volumes of music now which have been released through every major update (1.0-1.4). Leaving plenty of music to the point where you're bound to enjoy at least one tune. I seriously believe that without the amazing use of music, Terraria would of never reached the point it is at today.

Artstyle. Terraria's art direction is great, even if limited by the inherent pixelated nature of the game. The developers do a great job making the game look good despite this limitation. I can't act as if pixelation is what makes Terraria game changing however. Pixels are pixels so, visually, they'll always be limitations and many a game look better than Terraria. However, I'm sure the more simple process of game development this way has aided it in pumping out more content so that's a plus. 

Gameplay. THIS is what makes Terraria different. The different playstyles and builds makes interacting with Terraria's abundant worlds so fun, and most importantly replayable. For one, the boss fights in this game are fantastic and challenging as a newbie with many levels of difficulty scaling if you find yourself too beastly for normal mode now. Progression is very rewarding and until the defeat of moonlord, there is ALWAYS something to do. The weapons are interesting and the distinct classes give many ways to go through the game. Overall, there's so many items to chase and ways to play differently that people like myself rack up so much play time.

Perfection? No. Close? Yes. Terraria isn't a perfect game due to its reliance on the wiki. Nothing is fully explained to the player and I believe that has scared many away from the game. This can be as simple as adding a longer tutorial, a more fleshed out guide etc. All is to be said is that you should not miss out on this game.

2D minecraft but in the most positive way possible. In contrast to procedural generated, building sandbox survival Minecraft; Terraria is 2D sandbox RPG game. Terraria allows the player to choose their playstyle via weapons of varying usage, accessories that change up utility, and armor that can be used as full-sets or combinations for specific results.
Melee: Highest Defense class, items related broadly do strong damage and excel up close.
Range(r): Damage enemies from a distance, utilizing weapons such as guns and bows, which require ammunition. The choice of ammunition can greatly effect results.
Magic: Less defense, using weapons that can home on enemies, regular or controllable projectiles, AOE attacks, etc. The catch is they require mana to use their weapons.
Summoner: Weakest class in the game, but they utilize staffs that summon minions that auto-target enemies or manually target and damage enemies with whips. Many times a person will utilize a non-Summoner weapon when not using a whip to balance out combat while minions assist.

I've been playing Minecraft since July 2010, so I've seen most major updates for game. The game offers "Infinite wonders and endless possibilities" Minecraft isn't actually infinite or endless, but it might as well be due to the large amount of things you can do with the game. My favorite parts of the game are survival and hardcore singleplayer, and survival multiplayer. Minecraft may seem simple at first, but there are a lot of mechanics under the hood and there are ways to manipulate the game in unintended ways. Multiplayer is another big part of Minecraft, where I play on my private servers with friends and family. There are a lot Multiplayer servers, although most are private. My favorite is my private server and 2b2t, the oldest anarchy server in Minecraft is another experience altogether. In summary, Minecraft is a game that is definitely worth a try, and is more than a simple little block game.
Its just a fantastic game, I have loved it since I started playing it. Just one quick tip: if you keep dying and yo want to give up, DONT GIVE UP! If you keep on going you will achieve greatness.

Terraria is incredible, i just got a PC and this is one of the first games I'm playing. I've bought this game 4 times on an ipad when I was 7, my phone and my play station. In total i would easily 1000s of hours in this game because that's what you can do. You beat the game? try it on one of the 3 other classes. you beat it on all the classes? Try a more difficult gamemode. The game boasts hundreds if not THOUSANDS of different items weapons and blocks. Every single part of the world is unique with different biomes horizontally and vertically across the vast 2D world. And every biome contains tons of horrible monsters ores and chests containing loot to progress you further. Another incredible thing is the community countless youtubers creating guides, people writing useful tips and the wiki. One thing you will need is a wiki. i couldn't reccomend this game more for all ages, skill levels and people without as much time grind. PLAY THIS GAME
10/10 game. If you haven't played, your life is meaningless.

So I've played the game for 745 hours now and I still can't find the words to describe how fun and fantastic it is. After all these years it's simply still worth it to get the game and explore it to the fullest! The higher difficulties bring some new items and challenges which freshen up the experience once you've been through the classic difficulty.

Ofcourse there's also a great community adding to the game with mods, though I haven't really delved into those much myself, but I probably will soon!

Basically, all in all, amazing game, fantastic OST, great creative freedom, adventurous and challenging if you like it to be, 10/10, would (and probably will) spend another 745 hours playing it.
I still haven't even left spawn area and I love this game. Highly recommended.

Terraria is one of those games where to start off just barely better than naked and become someone who slays gods for fun at the end. When you finally defeat the final boss, you will remember how you spent your first night scared in a wooden box, how afraid you were when you fell into an area where you couldn't places torches on walls, how it took you hours upon hours to mine just a small section of the map and then you will reflect on how far you have come, now that you can make entire biomes disappear in minutes, can fly infinitely and even more incredible feats. Truly, one of the best games I have ever played.

often compared to Minecraft due to the blocky aesthetic, but packs tons more features. There's always something to do and the progression between a character and world feels well balanced, so there's never really a time when it seems impossible to survive against the new common monsters and it also doesn't take long to advance onto the next part of the game so it stays interesting. You get hints on where to explore next to lead you to the next boss battles while gaining new, cooler, more powerful equipment along the way. It's the type of game that can be played for hours without becoming dull.
