Terraria has taken 377 hours of my life. And I'm told that's rookie numbers. I've played many different games throughout my years, but I haven't come close to this many hours in any other game. 

I don't know what it is about this game that has caused me to spend so much time on it. It could be the burning desire to upgrade my gear, the many different play styles to choose from, the unique and challenging bosses, the incredibly detailed biomes, or maybe the fact that, as much as they want to, the developers can't seem to stop adding final updates. 

A game so loved by the developers that they are still developing it more than 10 years later is a great sign that it's a game worth playing. Especially for the price of a meal from Wendy's. I actually did the math...this game has cost me just less than 4 cents an hour to play.

The ONLY problem I have is that it requires a little tech knowledge to set up a 24hr server to play with friends on, but it's not too bad. If you are cool with the server running only when the host is on, that is built into the game.

TL:DR - Just buy it. You WILL get your moneys worth. This is probably one of the best and most well-known games for PC in existence, and there are plenty of reasons why.

Developers, a sincere thank you for developing and continuing to support such an amazing game.

When you think about this game it is impossible not to think about a 2D Minecraft, when you first step into the world you see a friendly environment and the first night and steps are played out in a similar way. However, when you keep exploring and discovering, the different biomes, enemies, weapons, accesories, bosses and structures just give out this endless feeling of adventure and uncertainty.

You have to put a lot of hours to fully discover this game. It makes you feel fear when facing the unknown and great accomplishment when you advance through a tough obstacle. These feelings can last for hundreds of hours of gameplay, just for this it deserves a spot in anyone's library, but the actual way to play this game varies so much from person to person AND you can play it with multiple friends too!

Could very well just be a skill issue on my part, but most of the bosses in this game are made with such horribly bad design that it could almost be considered hostile to the new/unprepared. Eater of Worlds is a tunneling boss that makes you summon it from underground leading to you getting stunlocked, Brain of Cthulu teleports INSIDE of you making magic and ranger builds have a needlessly difficult time with them, Wall of Flesh requires that you make a giant pathway across the entirety of Hell that you basically never use again, some gear pieces are impossible to obtain depending on your world seed, and RNG forces you to grind and grind and grind for the random obscure item you need for your build, which is almost always the Emblems. The game gets a lot better and fun with mods or if you fully learn the game, but god, I just can't handle a game being so unbelievably hostile to new players that it genuinely drives both me and my friends away. That said, I will definitely still be playing this game with my buddies that already know the game.

A very interestingly developed game that offers a lot of gameplay options and gives you the best gaming experience, mostly with its impeccable graphic design and a variety of in-game items, being suitable for both new, more experienced, and even seasoned veteran-type players. I would like to mention that there is currently an unfixed glitch in the game that allows players to see freely through the near landscape below them for a short period and is accessed by going to the video settings and changing your lighting from white to retro. Overall, however, this iconic game is 100% worth your money, time, and even trouble, sorrow, and travail fighting your way through expert and master mode.

A classic. Truly a masterpiece.
Don't even hesitate to get this game, especially now that the official mod launcher '[b]tModLoader[/b]' is on Steam.

What I really liked about Terraria was mainly the progression, you start out honestly weaker than an infant, but as you progress, kill bosses, find new ores and go into hardmode, you really do begin to not only get a feel for the combat, which is a bit more complex than you might think at first glance, but the later gear you can get is insane, and you really do feel like a powerhouse, and what's best is that the endgame bosses still pose somewhat of a challenge, even when you're all powered up, it never gets too stale. The music and pixel art is all very nice as well, and really do adds to the experience, in my opinion. All this, coupled with the amazing support Terraria has gotten from it's developers throughout the years honestly make this a very fun time to play and one of my personal favorite gaming experiences in recent years. There are flaws as well, of course, but these are minor compared to everything great the game has to offer, and honestly did not tarnish my experience with it. All in all, great game, I'd give it an 8 or even a 9 out of 10.

A sandbox with more of a combat focus, with a nice selection of weapons to suit many different playstyles. With tons of bosses, enemies, and events, This game rarely gets too boring. The free Tmodloader DLC even means you can add even more content in case you've exhausted all that Terraria has to offer.

There is just something about Terraria that always brings you back. The progression is steady and never too fast or too slow, the building is satisfying, the decoration extensive, and the combat challenging and exciting. Beyond that, everything about the game is just so well done and imbues such a sense of nostalgia for me, just as Minecraft might, though with more concrete goals, like bosses and such.

A game that is different with its 2D pixelated gameplay when comparing it to Minecraft. The boss battles are challenging, when setting it on Expert or Master difficulty, but rewarding after slaying them with the right weapons. The gameplay itself, is so far good when you start from scratch and evolve over the course of your journey. The accessory slots is an fantastic feature of applying awesome equipment to dodge, gain short invincibility, speed, health regeneration, flying and having info displayed to you. The four weapon classes are especially cool depending on how you like to play: warrior, ranger, summoner or sorcerer. The music of the game is entertaining and soothing when walking in certain biomes. The Npcs are a nice addition to the game as well along with creating buildings with a certain purpose.

Would recommend playing this game and it is best and fun playing it with friends.
Great fun with friends, a lot of stuff to do.

Terraria is a great game overall. It has loads of bosses, loads of potential projects, loads of unique weapons so you can find your own play style and it has 4 classes and 3 difficulties so you can replay it multiple times. Not to mention challenges that you see youtubers all the time, and if you enjoy suffering you can try for the worthy master mode. I've beaten the game once on PS4 in 1.3, and am yet to complete it in 1.4, which i have decided to do with my friend who gifted me the game as soon as i built my new pc. And for the last time, it is NOT 2d Minecraft. If i hear another person say this i'm going to remove their kneecaps. There are far too many differences for this to be a mere clone.
I enjoyed it, I love the graphics, the gameplay. really good game.

So I've started playing this game years ago, and even till now it's one of my favourite games. In this game you can have many many hours of fun. It impressed me so much that I even bought it on multiple consoles like the WiiU or the PS4. I recommend this game to everybody that likes Open-World-Sandbox games with a nice progression feeling that you get stronger the more you play and obtain. Its A LOT of fun with friends too.  The Vanilla Game approximately takes 80-100 hours to complete the Game and most of its contents (my experience). But with mods like for example "Calamity"  you can even increase the playtime.

This is one of THE BEST multiplayer games out there. You can spend hours and hours in this game. The bosses are cool and unique, the weapon and equipment loadouts are basically infinite, and there's some great building aspects, too. The soundtrack is top tier and really adds a lot to the game. Even after beating the game a few times like I have, you can check out the million community mods to make the game a whole new experience. I'll always love the time I've spent on Terraria with friends. This game really is one of the greatest games of all time.

I used to be one of those who didn't really know Terraria back then, I mislead Terraria since it reminded me of Minecraft in some aspects but how wrong I was... Terraria has his own personality far from other games and in any case is a simple copy of what was popular back then. Basically you've a game with different world-phases with  different bosses (up to 17), a vast world with biomes, lots of options to take and to be specialised combat-wise (such as ranged or summoner).  Different difficulties and new ones with the new update, alchemy, special waves of enemies (goblins in pre-hardmode) and much more just for you to discover. Don't be fooled of his apparently simple 2D because it is really hard and even more if you play mastermode + medium-core (which I do), try it and then judge for yourself.  (sorry for typos)

All Dogs Go to Heaven 2 is a 1996 American animated musical fantasy adventure film, and a sequel to Goldcrest Films' animated film All Dogs Go to Heaven (1989).[2] Produced by MGM/UA Family Entertainment and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Animation, it was co-directed by Paul Sabella and Larry Leker. Dom DeLuise reprises his role from the first film, alongside new cast members Charlie Sheen, Ernest Borgnine and Bebe Neuwirth, respectively. New characters are voiced by Sheena Easton, Adam Wylie and George Hearn.

Don Bluth, the director of the original film, had no involvement with it. It was the second of only two theatrical sequels to a film directed by Don Bluth to not involve Bluth himself, the first being An American Tail: Fievel Goes West, as 13 sequels to The Land Before Time and a single sequel to The Secret of NIMH were direct-to-video releases along with two sequels of An American Tail in 1998‚Äì2000, as well as An All Dogs Christmas Carol. This was MGM's last theatrically released animated film until Igor (2008). It had a DVD double feature release with the first one on March 14, 2006 and January 18, 2011. It was also released on Blu-ray on March 29, 2011. The film also served as the series premiere for the All Dogs Go to Heaven: The Series.

Got this game via the Humble Bundle (back when they had really good stuff), as a 4-pack (though none of the people I gave the extra copies plays it). I must say that the learning curve was a little steep for me at the beginning, especially figuring out how to navigate vertically (use platforms and ropes until you get or make the "proper" equipment; i.e. grappling hooks and jumping/flying accessories). If you don't mind the spoilers, visit the Official Terraria Wiki. You should at least learn about the different game phases so that you can be better prepared for the transition to "hardmode" (the gameplay changes dramatically after you defeat a certain boss).

I've now completed 800 hours playing the game on-and-off since I got it some years ago. I only now feel confident to attempt getting to hardmode.

I was going to compare Terraria to Minecraft (I had made a list of Minecraft cons, compared to Terraria), but I think [url=https://www.gamedeveloper.com/design/minecraft-vs-terraria]this[/url] article will explain enough for you to see if Terraria is a good fit for you.

I hope you have a great time with Terraria like I had (without being so afraid to advance to hardmode)

i've done 3 full playthroughs of terraria and while i absolutely do recommend the game to most people i thought i'd point out some of the less good things with the game that might be a dealbreaker for some:

- the grind absolutely sucks. if you want to get a specific item you will likely have to farm it for ~30m-2h 
- this includes fishing quests. you need 6 different items at a 2.5% drop rate, and you can only do one quest every real life 20 minutes 
- the game is extremely overwhelming. at the time of writing this, there are 565 unique weapons in the game, and you WILL need to have a wiki page open while playing
- there's no crossplay between PC & mobile
- the steam workshop sucks. to find 1 good mod you will have to dig through 99 lazily made ones that either changes one sound in the game or gives a character big tits

the game is however amazing and i do recommend it to most people

At 78 hours (at the time of this review) spent on Terraria, I should not have to convince you that it is a personal favorite of mine, and that's just considering the time spent on the PC version, whereas the Xbox 360, PS4, 3DS, and Switch version all carry close to the same amount of playtime, if not even more.

The graphics quality is smooth on the eyes, the caves well designed. The bosses bring quite a challenge and stopping point to an otherwise free-spirited adventure. The weapons are most intriguing. The overall crafting is easy to grasp. The NPCs feel interactive and less like plain AIs. The building is so in-depth that there is almost nothing you cannot do. There's so much to do in this game that it's hard to describe every single thing. The most important thing is that this game brings with it the best experience to be had in any Sandbox game to date.

Terraria is an amazing city builder, after travelling to an unexplored land, one or more travelers quickly establish low income housing and begin tackling real urban problems like rampaging undead and demonic eyeballs the size of a small house. Terraria is an amazing RPG where adventurers adorn themselves with the spoils of war and gear themselves in preparation for their next showdown, knowing whatever awaits them next will have them fighting for their lives. Terraria is a wonderful survival game, where the lush plains of yesterday are to be the dank and terrifying hellscape of tomorrow.

For how much money this game costs, there is so much content to be found. A golden rule I've always followed since I have gotten money to spend on video games, is that for every dollar spent on a game, you should get at least one hour of content, and Terraria has ABSOLUTELY delivered on that end. I can't imagine how my life would be different if I never got Terraria. This game is incredible on your own, but absolutely perfect, with friends, either mutilating bosses, building mega-bases, farming for very low drop chance items, massacring wave events, or even just exploring the map, this game has so much stuff to do and so many ways to do it. 10/10 would play 642.8 hours again.

insanely fun game. four different classes with four different gameplay elements of each, not only that, four different modes
Journey - a sort of creative like gamemode 
Normal - Regular gameplay
Expert - New boss ai's, enemies do more damage and have more health, higher drop chances, and exclusive accessories dropped by each boss.
Master - the same as expert but with even more scaled difficulity in health and damage and bosses have exclusive mounts and pets.
this is already a LOT of content for a cheap game like this, but remember this has full mod compatability, workshop compatability, multiplayer, servers, and much much more.
definetly worth buying even at full price

This is easily my favorite game of all time. All the systems work so wonderfully. The mining, crafting, combat, and overall progression system is just superb. And the community that supports it is one of the best I've seen in a good while, with all the content they make off of the game and the mods, resource packs, and maps. The dev team is also one of, if not, the best I've ever seen. The upcoming labor of love update should be proof of that. Overall Terraria is a really fun game and it's not really surprising why it's the 9th best selling video game worldwide.

I am a 52 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my son for help, and together we spent hours playing . I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Steam has ever since brought me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories..

The Hog Rider is a fast ground troop with medium hitpoints, low damage, and the ability to jump over enemy Walls. He is unlocked at level 2 Dark Barracks. The Hog Rider (person) is a bare-chested dark-skinned man holding a hammer. He has a mohawk, wears a brown leather loincloth, a red belt, and a pair of leather sandals, as well as two large golden wristbands and a gold earring. His ride is a large hog, about half his height. It has a brown leather bridle looped around its tusks, which in turn is held by the Hog Rider. Hog Riders prioritize defensive structures above all other targets, and will bypass all other types of enemy buildings and troops while any defenses remain on the battlefield. This is true even if they are under attack by enemy Clan Castle troops, heroes or Skeleton Trap skeletons. Note that like all troops that prioritize defenses, Hog Riders do not consider the Clan Castle to be a defense regardless of whether or not it contains enemy troops, but do consider the defending Grand Warden and the activated Town Hall weapon (if any) to be defensive buildings. Once all defenses are destroyed, Hog Riders become like any other troop with no preferred target; they will attack the nearest building to them regardless of type, and will turn and attack enemy units if they become aware of any nearby.He can be used to jump over any level Walls, rendering them ineffective against Hog Riders. Note that while this allows Hog Riders free access to what lies behind the Walls, it does not open up gaps for other troops to move through. If the Hog Riders need the support of other ground troops, you will still need to deploy Wall Breakers, a Jump Spell, or Earthquake Spells in order to assist them. Hog Riders can be used en masse, i.e. a "Hog Rider Rush", without requiring any Wall Breakers to break Walls. However, such a strategy can be costly in terms of Dark Elixir, and sports weaknesses against defending Clan Castle troops, Heroes, and Skeleton Traps, a problem which only becomes more prominent at higher levels. At Town Hall 10 and above, Hog Riders can be combined with Miners in a strategy known as Miner Hog Hybrid. Both troops are able to bypass Walls innately, but Miners do not have a preferential target, allowing them to cover for Hog Riders by dealing with defending Heroes and Skeleton Traps. The combination also has weaknesses against flying Clan Castle troops, as neither are able to target air. At lower levels, Hog Riders are quite capable of acting as distracting troops like Giants; they have nearly as much health as a similar-level Giant, move twice as fast, and do considerably more damage. They work well with the Healing Spell when you group several of them together. A good tactic for using Healing Spells is to place them strategically on a cluster of defenses (at least about 3 or more) and also deploy them shortly before the Hog Riders arrive in the area, i.e. deploy them ahead of the Hog Riders. This is so that the Hog Riders get the most out of the Healing Spell, and destroy the defenses without losing too much HP. Spots where Giant Bombs or Bomb Towers are/may be should be given special attention when deploying Healing Spells. Hogs of the same level as the Giant Bomb will survive a single Giant Bomb, but they're helpless against a pair of Giant Bombs even with a Healing Spell. Heal them after they've gone through a Giant Bomb blast. The Hog Rider is one of the best troop types for drawing out Clan Castle troops, as it can avoid Walls to penetrate deep enough to reach centrally-placed Clan Castles (and enough health to not die before it gets there). Deploy one or a few to trigger the Clan Castle troops, then lure the reinforcement troops to the corner side, and deploy multiple Archers or Wizards to slaughter them, and then deploy the remainder of your Hog Riders. This strategy is especially effective during Clan War raids. However, Skeletons from the Skeleton Trap and Heroes can also easily kill the Hog Riders, as they can only target defenses, so make sure to have some troops that target anything, such as Wizards, which can swipe out the Skeletons. Hog Riders don't target air so flying Clan Castle troops, especially Dragons, can be a big threat. Most mass Hog Rider strategies in Clan Wars require that the Clan Castle troops be killed first by luring. Bring other troops in addition to Hog Riders, such as Wizards, to deal with enemy Clan Castle troops and clean up the base. Poison Spells can be used to kill almost any enemy Clan Castle troop, but beware as the troops will attempt to flee the poison. If the Poison Spells are decently leveled, and you effectively keep the Clan Castle troops from escaping the Poison Spell with distracting troops, they can eliminate almost any troop. They can also be used to dispense of those pesky Skeletons risen from the Skeleton Traps. Time is also a factor to consider. With only 3 minutes in an attack, it is essential to make sure that this whole process and the remainder of the attack is done as quickly as possible to avoid running out of time.Defending against Hog Riders is tricky, as their ability to bypass Walls renders them irrelevant. However, the fact that they can jump over Walls and attack defenses means that they may leave behind their ground support (such as Barbarians, etc.), as they will not be able to follow. This will allow your interior defenses to concentrate on the Hog Riders. Another way to defend against Hog Riders is to exploit the fact that they will attack the closest defensive building. You can arrange your base in such a way so that you have high-powered defenses on the inside and lower-powered defense on the outside, with a layer of resources in between. That way, the Hogs will (in theory) complete a loop around your base before being able to attack your interior defenses (Inferno Towers, X-Bows, etc.), by which time they should have all been killed by the interior defenses. You can place Spring Traps in between defensive buildings to take out a few Hog Riders at a time; good usage of multiple Spring Traps can severely hinder a Hog Rider rush. Hog Riders can be easily killed using "forced pathing". Forced pathing is a strategy that manipulates the Hog Rider AI and makes them go to at least 2 defenses that cannot be prevented by surgical dropping or side clearing. Placing a set of Giant Bombs in between the two can most certainly hinder the attacker progress. They would not be able to heal the Hog Riders in time. Clan Castle troops, Heroes, and Skeleton Traps set to Ground Mode can be an annoyance to mass Hog Rider raids, as Hog Riders will not attack them unless all defenses have been destroyed. Make sure to centralize them if you want to beat Hog Riders. In Clan Wars, Dragons are excellent troops to place in Clan Castles against Hog Riders, especially for Town Halls 8 and 9. They have high HP, meaning they won't die easily and can kill mass quantities of Hog Riders swiftly if not properly lured. Most mass Hog Rider strategies require that the enemy Clan Castle troops be killed first, so if the attacker lures out a Dragon, but fails to kill it, then a 3-star win is next to impossible, much less a 1-star win via destroying 50% of the buildings. Multi-target Inferno Towers can be a severe hindrance to Hog Riders, having high HP to take several hits from Hog Riders, while hitting large groups of them. Although the Hog Rider is certainly not a liability on defense, the fact that all defensive troops are unimpeded by Walls negates the primary advantage of the Hog Rider. Still, for the space they take they are faster and more damaging compared to Giants.The Hog Rider undergoes significant visual changes at levels 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Initially, the Hog Rider is a dark-skinned man with a black mohawk and beard. He also has a gold earring in his right ear and sports two heavy golden wristbands, a red belt, and a brown loincloth. The Hog Rider's hammer has two brass bands.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

[h1] OPENING THOUGHTS [/h1]
Sensational game defining a generation, approaching 400 hours on steam however if you include old Xbox 360 and Xbox one hours its definitely reaching the 1.5 to 2 thousand hours scale. One of the few games that showed up and stuck around with no main-stream re-releases or sequels to "keep the hype", no pay to win, micro-transactions, loot boxes or additional payment of any kind after initial purchase. Just a one time payment of half your average triple A title and nothing else for the next 10 years. Incredible.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
A simple yet compelling gameplay loop to keep you engaged; cycling through its three main aspects: Building, Exploring, and Combat, each evolving and adding new elements each time you revisit them. While the gameplay looks simple of the surface it houses a large variety of different pathways and challenges allowing you to focus into combat classes and damaged types, combating bosses at a chosen time and coming back to others later, optional events and bosses not key or in anyway required for progression in the game while giving the player an edge in the future if they choose to.

[h1]COMMUNITY/DEVELOPERS[/h1]
With a game that's been around as long as Terraria it builds a large dedicated community around it and the developers do a great job with keeping in touch with said community even to this day still providing us with teasers and answering questions about upcoming updates. The game also has a large and still thriving youtube and reddit community providing fans with endless streams of content as well as tips and trick with new ideas for their own games. I've listed a few of my favourites below.

[url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCdImtrRS4UewEbPdnF8R4qw] ChippyGaming [/url]
[url=https://www.youtube.com/c/Yrimir] Yrimir [/url]
[url=https://www.youtube.com/c/Pedguin] Pedguin [/url]
[url=https://twitter.com/Demilogic] Red (Dev) [/url]

[h1]MY EXPERIENCE[/h1]
I probably started playing on xbox 360 for the first time around late 2013/2014. I was around 9 years old and one of my friends showed it to me, i remember instantly falling in love with it, running home from school everyday to squeeze in as much time as i could in every waking moment. Spanning what is probably about 100 worlds and characters with my and my mates most recent being played around the beginning of this year. I remember he so scared of my first time conquering the dungeon or entering hell and finally reaching hard mode for the first time; discovering and entirely different game with new monsters, biomes, bosses, weapons and what not was incredible. 

I've been alive longer knowing and playing this game than I not and I still play to this day on and off - If that isn't a positive review then I don't know what is.

Dear god where do i even start with this game.

Terraria is a coalition of what every game wishes to acquire. This game includes a nearly infinite character creator, casual and energetic game play, music beyond the stars, a huge fan base, boss fights, and a history of evolution. All of these great artifacts are very difficult to get right, but Terraria did it right. This game even incorporated all those details, into just a 2D side-scroller.

Lets start with the character creator. there isn't much to say about this one, you start off with the default character. You are given 4 choices of clothing for both sexes. (If i say gender, someone might get mad.) There is a catalog of hair to choose from, there are short hairs and medium hairs. The greatest point of this creator is the fact that each and every part can be colored to your desire. You can change the color of all the following: Hair, Eyes, Skin, Shoes, Shirts, and Pants. Despite such the limited choices, later on you will unlock accessories to make your experience better.

Next up, the game play. There is so much game play. it all ranges from building a house to fighting a literal moon "lord". At the start of your world, you spawn in with a guide who is more helpful than you think. Just like every other survival game, you start off by cutting trees and making a starter base. Once you all safe and sound, you can go out and explore, finding many creatures and ores along the way. After reaping the rewards of hard work, progress does it all by itself at that point. After some time you fight your first boss, then you build more houses. Now some NPCs can move in and give you more items. Now you face hell. Shortly after entering, you murder a wall of actual flesh (and your guide). Come out of hell to see magical ponies. Don't acknowledge the ponies and run to the Jungle and kill a statue. Once all is done, run over to the local dungeon and murder cultists. Without realizing it, you just summoned eldritch horrors into your world and you need to destroy 4 pillars to return back to normal. Once you think you've done everything, in comes the Moon Lord to kill you. After failing, he turns into bone and you get 1 of the items withing his loot pool. Hopefully if you paid attention, you can create the crucib- I mean the "Zenith". You did all of that? Well all that's left for you is to build to the limits of imagination. The true endgame of Terraria is to advance your skills in building.

The music of Terraria is on a completely separate level from anything else in this game. To me personally, the music is terrifying. But not in the sense you think. The music and it's 8-bit sounds put chills in my spine, why? In my mind, I can feel the boundless potential pouring from the song. Listening to the songs in this game makes me actually feel imagination itself. From space to hell, each score of music has its own story behind it, whether it be outside the game or lore-wise. Terraria music is something to be truly held out with pride.

I, myself, am not as deep in the fan base of Terraria as many others. Trust me I do enjoy this game, it's just not one i'm willing to do big things for. This isn't about me, it's about others. These fans exist on separate plains of existence. The artwork done for this game is on par with biblical paintings. The fan animations inspire others to create something. Overall, these people who love Terraria enjoy placing dedication into the things they make.

From start to finish, these boss fights give me a sense of actual stress. Some of that may be from not playing dark souls or just the music being intense. Each and every boss fight was handled with care and acted like children to the developers. Slime King is simple yet confusing, the Eye of Cthulhu is easily the most iconic, the Wall of Flesh is well-known for being unavoidable (and "boss music 2"), Plantera is probably the first plant based boss, and the Empress of Light is a female. Finally, the final boss Moon Lord, being the long lost brother of Cthulhu.

Terraria has it's own fair share of history. There are some dedicated players who have charted all the steps taken by the developers and have put it out for the world to see. most well known person like that is "ChippyGaming". Unfortunately, i'm not well versed in the bible of Terraria so I don't have much to add to this part.

Terraria is a fairly simple concept mixed with alot of branches and customizations for gear and equipment. The game starts off with you in a forest, aided by the Guide, someone who will remain useful for the majority of the game whenever you get new ores or materials and want to know what to do with them. The best thing I can recommend is to hack down a few trees to make houses for future NPCs and to mine some ore in the Forest biome (where you start), in hopes of getting equipment for other biomes. In a sense, it has similarities to Minecraft in the early moments, but it quickly spirals into its own thing. Usually, people are meant to focus on a single "class" with their equipment, but I like to go hybrid and equip whatever I have that I like and take on bosses that way. Really fun with friends.

Oh, and pro-tip: if you see someone you can talk to, talk to them instead of just ignoring them, as they may either warn you not to enter the Dungeon or may be someone in need of your help to join your other allied NPCs in your village. There's virtually no reason to ignore them, unless you want to die from an obvious trap and complain online after.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is

Have done many playthroughs before and after 1 hour, I lose the urge to conitnue. The game lacks immersion because its 2d and third person. You don't feel like your in the game, you feel like your controlling somebody thats in the game instead of actually being there. Literally 99% of the items in this game are useless, and the power creep is insane. Stats and gear scale exponentially with each boss making it quite unbalanced. Graphics are MS paint level. Lots of duplication bugs and the music sounds like arcade music that has been flushed down the toilet. The game is stupidly dark and you legit can't see anything no matter how many torches you put, it becomes an inconvenience rather than a good feature at that point. Progressing in this game has more rng than the lottery as you need the right stuff from chests which is a extremely annoying. TLDR, game is overrated.

I'd be hard pressed to believe you haven't heard of this game. Question is, should you play it in its current state? Well, yes and no... 

The game is fun, there is a LOT you can do in this game. If you like Minecraft, I highly recommend this game to you. You will enjoy it just as much as Minecraft, maybe even more. It's just different... There's a reason Terraria recommends Minecraft and vice versa.

The only thing about this game that might not be enjoyable to some is its difficulty and how "lost" you can feel. There's only so much you can do pre-hard mode... What is hard mode? Well, you beat this boss in literal hell and then the game "advances" too hard mode where enemies are harder, new things spawn and whole sections of your world change. It can be pretty overwhelming and takes a lot of time to get used to, but if you feel like dumping a lot of hours into this game so you can feel like an overpowered god this is right for you. 

I highly suggest at least giving the game a try. The developers really care about this game and continue to update it with new and fun things to do. The games price is also a lot better than games you'll see these days. And I even got the game on sale and let me tell you I'd pay full price for it. In fact, I have on Xbox One. The game is cheap, fun and has so much you can do in it I highly doubt you'll do everything there is to do in the game.

Very good game over all, however if you want to get all achievements it STINKS. One achievement, ONE ACHIEVEMENT, makes all achievements a nightmare.
  You see, there is an achievement where you have to get 200 fishing quest for this idiot child. Lets say that you start doing this in hardmode: the day night cycle will be 24 minutes. In this time, you can fish and get only  1 fish to turn in. Now, you take 24 times 200 and get 4800 minutes: 80 hours. 80 HOURS of real life time.
  That's how long it would take without using bed to speed time up inbetween or figuring out how to mess with it and turn multiple in. 
  Using the bed, it would speed time up by 5 times. Now you devide 80 by 5 and get 16. 16 HOURS STILL. Mind you, that would be getting the fish and turning it in in less than a second - not possible.
  This is by far the worse decision anyone could do with achievements. Make an rng, heavily time based achievement. 1, 10, 25, 50, 200 : the fishing numbers required per achievement.
  To fix this, simpily reduce the time required to get it by half (make it require 100 instead of 200.)
  This is why it has a 2.5 % completeion rate.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Let my hours in game let you know that this game is fun.

First off, for anyone who is unaware of this game, it is a more combat based 2D minecraft. I'll go into detail on what I mean below.

Second, great features include characters and world being saved separate and are freely interchangeable, drop in-drop out multiplayer through steam, mod-ability, and adjustable difficulty levels for those who love a challenge. 

Third, what I said before, lots of people either love or hate comparison to minecraft, know this, there are boss monsters, equipment with set bonuses, rare equipment drops, special monster events, and multiple ways to build or equip yourself for victory, there is even a guide npc right with you at the start to help you get through it all. But what I love is how easy it is to build cool houses and arenas. 

Fourth, there is a deep amount of fishing.

Fifth, cons: no game is perfect for everyone. 
The game is designed more around fighting than infinite creativity, so if you aren't the type who enjoys beating up monsters, it may not be perfect, but there is a creative mode too. 
The map is limited, you can make it pretty big, but once you get advanced items it is easy to travel it all, but some people prefer that. 
The last thing I'll consider a con is the replay-ability, there are two types of worlds, tons of variety in map randomization and even secrets to discover, but ultimately the game will follow the same overall structure each time, I think there is more than enough content to enjoy multiple times through, but the only way to get a truly different experience is to turn up the difficulty for the new enemies and items that become available. 

All that being said, I truly believe no adventurer or fighter's library would be complete without this game. I easily drop 100-200 hours per world, and love the customization of building in 2D. Seriously, any questions, comment here.

It's Terraria, how could you hate it?

Jokes aside, the game is good for those who enjoy a quest to explore worlds, build structures across their worlds for new and (sometimes) helpful residents to live in or combating certain creatures that may attempt to invade your world! If you enjoy Minecraft regardless of what platform it is, you'll probably enjoy this especially since the two compliment and call each other out in a friendly way!

Pros:
+ Travel the world, find loot and improve your character, whether it's by finding a new material to make new tools and armor or by finding a accessory that improves your mobility such as a Grappling hook!

+ Make settlements and find people to move them in while also figuring out where they like and who they enjoy being around, netting you improvements like selling more stuff or even selling stuff at a cheaper price!

+ Enjoy the music the game has to offer! Especially since its great music and informs you of what area / biome you are in when you can't rely on visuals.

+ It's easy to host a Multiplayer game! just go to to the "Multiplayer" section and
 set up small settings, and boom, people can join through steam easily or you can set a password and invite them! Sidenote, you probably want a Large world for it, certainly not small.

+ In 1.4 you now have the option between the original character difficulties and then Journey difficulty which allows you to play the game at your own pace and way, controlling the weather, time of day, world difficulty and more! Of course this Journey difficulty is limited to Journey worlds so classic difficulties and Journey will remain separate.

+ Loading mods is easier than ever, going to Tmodloader on the store and using the "Workshop" section you can check out mods and download them from there, and don't sweat sharing a list if you want to play together, unless the mod isn't from the built in mod browser (haven't tested this so I wouldn't know.) 

Cons:
- Can be difficult, even on Classic world difficulty, unless you are experienced be prepared to die a lot.

- Game doesn't tell you a whole lot about where to go expect via what may be cryptic chat messages to some people and a NPC, The Guide who spawns with you in any world (expect certain special seeds)

- Remember the part where I mentioned dying? Unless you like looking at the spot you died in for 10 seconds, don't die if you can help it! (Not that anyone finds that advice helpful in video games.)

- Once you beat the final boss (ooo spooky and mysterious.) What you do from there is upto you, and depending on who you are may just cease playing, I guess if anything, that con is if anything is your fault.

My final score? 
I give it a 8.7 out of 10.
My experience comes from Console which I have 100% achievements / trophies for (atleast pre 1.3), maybe one day It'll be the same here, that's all for now, feel free to state opinions whether positive or negative.

I am a 44 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started Terraria and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Tiktok. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

After only a couple hours of playing, i say its alright. One thing i have to say is good is that i can fight intergalactic gods, go to hell and back killing a wall made out of flesh, and kill walking goldfish.

The game is a versatile open world adventure which allows you to be the destroyer and creator of your own world. Customization is decent and building asthetics are quite well established. There is a great aspect which allows you to rescue other civilians and use them as your workstation so they can provide you with goods but with a cost of course. There are boss fights which bring excitement and challenge to the players adventure which is carried out with a wide variety of weapons never seen before in any other games. 
Although, I advise being careful with the Wall of Flesh boss. First make a VERY long platform in hell before spawning and go to the corner of the platform to spawn and use it to keep a distance from the wall and use bows to heavily damage it without having consequences. After finishing this boss you will enter a new, harder, more challenging world of more fun and so this game awaits your call.

If you found this helpful please rate and share and if you can please donate thanks for your help!

Imagine what Minecraft might be like if it had been made with pixel art sprites and released in the SNES era. That sums up the overall vibe of Terraria pretty well. It also explains why I just can't seem to tear myself away from the darned thing. This devious little indie sandbox title borrows so many ideas from Notch's game that it essentially is Minecraft in 2D, but it also beefs up the familiar gameplay in exciting ways. There's a lot more creepy crawly stuff to kill, and the staggering number of doodads you can MacGyver together into deadly weapons to slay them with is mouth-watering. Say what you will; there's some gnarly fun to be had in these uncharted depths.

After you're done customizing your sprite character, Terraria dumps you on the colorful surface of a randomly generated pixel world with nothing more than a handful of tools and the vague sense that you're meant to build stuff, explore the terrain, and battle monsters. Figuring out exactly how that's done is a little puzzling at first. There's a lone guide wandering around the surface, though his advice is random. The lack of a tutorial meant I had to consult the game's Wiki page to get a better sense of how things work and what can be built. Even so, it didn't take long to get the gist. Though there aren't any real story elements or epic quests to conquer, the strong fantasy trappings instill a desire to adventure nonetheless. There's magic, monsters, and mayhem waiting both on the surface and in the dark caverns below. Uncovering unexpected new prizes and perils is a big part of the game's charm.

The entire game world is destructible, and breaking block lets you collect core resources like stone, wood, and iron that can be used to make cool gear or build structures. Rarer resources are dropped when you slay skeletons, floating fanged critters, and other monsters or when you dig deeper into the subterranean underworld. Since such a large portion of Terraria's gameplay revolves around foraging for different components and seeing what you can build with them, the drive to explore every nook and cranny of the landscape kicks in right away. But it's important to temper your desire to set out exploring in hopes of amassing huge quantities of loot with the pressing need to build shelter and expand your spawn point's home base.

Life on the surface follows a day/night cycle. Exploring topside during the daytime is safer ‚Äì you can pick flowers, roam around, chop trees, and kill weak slimes that roam too close. It's also a perfect time to build houses that serve as shelter and attract helpful NPC characters to your settlement. Things get dicey when night falls; zombie hordes and floating eyeball beasts come out in droves, forcing you to fight or flee. That's less of an issue once you get a sturdy settlement started.

The village development aspect of the game is a clever addition ‚Äì once you discover it exists. You can throw together bare-bones shacks or craft elaborate fortresses that tower upward into the heavens. Either way, you want to deck them out with enough accoutrements to lure NPCs to your village. These support characters can heal you, sell you items, and offer other helpful services. You have to complete a specific task to attract them, and even then they only appear if you've created a room (complete with walls, furniture, lighting, etc.) for them to stay. This offers some tangible incentives to spend time building, beyond the desire to lord over a large stronghold.


Having an elaborate and ever-expanding home base to return to on the surface is satisfying. However, the dark, foreboding underworld is where the real action is. Everything you need to make the most basic items like torches, furniture, and healing potions can be found near the surface, but you have to adventure deep below to uncover the rarest materials. This is where Terraria's gameplay feels more like an old-school action platformer and where it really sunk its hooks into me. Digging for ore eventually uncovers sprawling caverns that are home to many varieties of creepy creatures. Giant slimes, skeletons, burrowing worms, and tougher beasties roam the dark, and they often come charging at you while you're excavating. Exploring is a lot fun on its own, yet it's the strong emphasis on combat that's really appealing. For one thing, stopping to battle monsters breaks up the monotony of digging. Creatures also drop coins that can be used to buy shop items. There's an added risk versus reward element to combat too. Getting killed causes you to re-spawn on the surface with your gear intact, but you'll leave a chunk of your precious coin stash behind.

The real impetus behind adventuring is driven by the insanely deep gear crafting system. Almost everything you pick up in the game is a component used in forging some crucial piece of kit. There are well over a hundred different weapons and items to build. Though some equipment is more functional ‚Äì like protective armor, grappling hooks that lets you navigate with greater ease, and treasure chests for storing loot ‚Äì most of the stuff designed for cleaving monsters into itty bits is just sheer badass. Magical boomerangs, laser pistols, spell books that shoot fireballs, light sabers, and ninja stars are just a handful of the crazier weapons you can build. Hunting down the rare items you need to build the best weapons is obsession forming.

A few other cool nuances enhance the absorbing tasks of exploring, building, and battling away. Journey to the farther reaches of the surface world, and you'll inevitably run into The Corruption ‚Äì a teeming mass of demonic turf filled with extra danger and extra rewards. You'll also uncover demonic altars for forging special items that can be used to summon one of the game's three spectacular bosses to fight (sporting awesome names like "Skeletron" and "Eater of Worlds"). Terraria's multiplayer mode is a blast too. Co-operatively exploring and building with friends or strangers is even more enjoyable than going solo, depending on the folks you play with. Finding an open public server to play on is a real drag, since most fill up within minutes of being posted on the game's forum. The good news is you can create your own server and share it with your pals (or post it online for others to join).
Verdict
Though on the surface it looks like just another "me too" indie game seeking to ride the coattails of Minecraft's success, Terraria expands on the familiar sandbox gameplay with a greater emphasis on combat and adventure that proves very satisfying. Fresh elements ‚Äì like an absurdly expansive weapon crafting system, a broader scope of monsters to battle, and a slick retro 2D presentation ‚Äì make it a stand out among the pack. Hell, it took all the resolve I could muster just to shut the game down long enough to write this review. That's rare indeed.

And yeah sure you can just go on tmod but I feel that original terraria  is just better even though mods add heaps, 

I feel like the simplicity of terraria is just perfect 

First you start building a wooden box with a workbench and chair, the guide opens the door during night time and gets your innards get turned into outtards you expand make armour,and better weapons 

And then you get the infamous
"You Feel An Evil Presence Watching You"

You kill a blue slime who has obviously taken slot of supplements

You explore your world seeking loot, you find a dungeon.
Of course you jump headfirst into the dungeon and the dungeon guardian massacres you

You fight either a brain that summons illusions that a bloody 4 year old could see through, or a long ass worm

Then you fight an oversized bee

Then a lanky skeleton

You build a hell bridge and fight a literal wall of flesh

Your world enters hard mode, you destroy the evil altars around your world,granting you powerful ores.

You fight huge mechanical worm that massacres all your npcs, a pair of eyeballs and a four armed metal skeleton.

You explore the jungle and find a funny plant and try pick it up...

You kill the oversized plant

And open the door to a trap filled temple you narrowly navigate through till you accidentally summon a literal golem that will punch the shit out of you,

You kill some cultists and fight a dragon summoning one

Then celestial creatures invade you kill them and...

Impending Doom Approaches...

You kill low budget cythulu and congrats, you won the game.

PS thanks for reading all of this sorry I made it so long.

This is honestly one of the greatest games I have played. I hate it when people say this is a minecraft copy because they clearly have not played it. Terraria has so much you can do but not only that it has so much you NEED to do to be able to progress. Yes in games like minecraft there is a lot to do but there is not a lot do which you actually NEED to. This is my favourite thing about terraria; It took my a full 2 weeks on grinding it for about 8 hours a day with my friend to actually complete it. Terraria is also one of those games is that playing through the first time is something specail, having to learn everything. I could not progress without having to use the wiki half the time. Also is that once you complete it the first time, the differnt difficultys are so much different. Classic and expert Terraria are two different experiences. Even after deafting the moon lord, there is still so much to do which is still engaging for example getting the zenith (where i belief the game ends). In conculsion, terraria for me, will go down as one of the greatest games of all time because of how well its made, its not like call of duty where having 2000 hours means you have been doing the same thing, Terraria 2000 hours always has you doing something different which actually means something.

The reason I'm making this review is because I believe that the unmodded version of Terraria is an absolute pain in terms of grinding. The issue isn't necessarily the drop chances or spawn chances, but how frequent they appear throughout a playthrough, and how they feel almost required when playing master mode. The reason I say unmodded is because I think that tmodloader fixes every single issue that the vanilla game has. Many items and recipes that improve QOL are added with mods like Calamity or Luiafk. Instead of grinding for an ankh charm, a lot of it can be crafted. Infinite potions, torches, instant hellevator, etc. take away (IMO) the least fun part of the game. Not to mention that mods are encouraged, supported, and tmodloader, from my experience, improves optimization. I lag quite a bit with certain programs open in the background while I play the base game, but I have NEVER had that issue with tmodloader.

If you buy Terraria, you shouldn't restrict yourself to just the core game, IMO mods are what really do make this game perfect.

I personally love Terraria. Though, I only recently started playing it, (as in I've literally just started playing as of a couple months ago) and I do have to say one important factor of Terraria; it is not very new player accessible. Now what do I mean by that? I mean that it is a very big and complex game and doesn't give a whole lot of explanation as to what to do. Now, this isn't a huge point against the game, it just means that players that are new will have a lot of trouble trying to figure things out and get their bearings. Though, that isn't too bad. It is just a frustrating experience to figure out the game but ultimately, once you have gotten things figured out, it is a great game for casual play and focused gameplay!

The amount of content that developers make is insane, I like how they even made a crossover with Dungeon Defenders 2 and Don't Starve Together (even though I never played them). It might be confusing if it's your first time playing this game (now that I think about it, I think it would have been nice if they made an in-game tutorial instead of constantly looking at the wiki) but if you really get in to it, trust me you'll love this game as much as I do. Highly recommend it, it's cheap, better if you play with friends, and It will forever be my favorite Steam game.

This is a fanastic game, especially  if you are looking for something to play with your SO. The monsters are still difficult and interesting and varied, but the 2d combat is very nice for newbs such as myself, who can barely play Mariokart decently.  Farming, fishing, Destroying evil monsters, getting the ham salad smacked out of you by bats -- Terraria has it all, and manages to make a game that is perfect for seasoned gamers as well as those who have no skill. Not to mention that the NPC's are fantastically varied, the biomes are gorgeous,  building materials are varied and cool. I am hooked!

Terraria is an awesome sandbox builder fighting survival PvE game that I definitely recommend. The game has 97% positive reviews, so you don't have to think twice to buy it if you are into such a genre. My personal favourite side of the game is that you can play it as an idle game, where you just go into caves, and dig endlessly, go back to the base and give the loot to your friend to make you stuff. The game can be played on long sessions but it may become boring after a certain amount of time. 8/10.

I just had a very negative play experience, not that it detracts from the game, because I have already played it all before, And will say it is very good.

Why negative? First night is crucial, get a house around you ASAP.. there will be too many zombies and eyes to deal with, plus the slimes are still spawning. But you do 2 damage to the zombies.. And their HP bar is over 88 or something strong. What am I supposed to do, I wonder, Is it like beating the bottom boss, where the overworld is more dangerous than the underworld?

It surely feels like I should be propelled to go lower to escape these hard fought foes of the surface to get down under as far as i can go. Constantly propelled towards progress.

But there is no breathing room anymore....

This is one of my favorite games, I have a ton of hours on console, and own it on PC as well. Try it out, it is a little difficult at first, but try out journey mode and toggle it to classic mode. Play it for a bit and try to beat the game with god mode off. Its a fun game filled with lots of stuff. I would say an average run probably takes me about 20 hours while I'm taking a bit of time but I am a bit experienced. It will probably take you about 30-40 hours to beat the final boss. Dont be afraid of looking things up on the wiki. The game is huge and has tons of items, bosses, events and armors. The game has around 16 bosses I think, 8 of which are required, but really 9 to be able to get good loot to kill the other bosses.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Terraria may look like Minecraft but it's way more than that.

before we start, on the main menu there are single-player and multiplayer there the main modes. You can change your in-game character to make it look as you like it. When making a world you can choose two world types corruption and crimson both have many enemies and one unique boss for each. There 4 difficulties, journey, classic, expert and master. The journey is for people who want an easy experience playing Terraria. Classic is Classic. Expert is for people wanting a harder experience playing Terraria. (not made for new players) Master is for the best of the best, the hardest difficulty in the game bosses have more health, new attacks and new tricks.

you can make your world small, medium and large. Now you are ready to start playing, there 3 parts of the game non-hardcore, hardcore and endgame. Non-hardcore is the start of the game, the beginning. There are a few bosses lots of armour, weapons and enemies. Then it's a hardcore must of the game. Tons of new bosses, weapons, armour, ores and the final boss after that it's the endgame where you can do whatever you want, what you like to create in OUR world lots of stuff to do even when you finish the game.

There are lots of fish quests and multiple classes to play as. lots of events like a blood moon or a winter event. The pixel art is so beautiful, that anyone could like it. the work they put into just the art is amazing and the music is even better. You can listen to it for hours.

Now multiplayer, there are some servers you can play for PVP or to play with your friends.

There are also mods in the mod loader to easily get mods if you get bored of the main game with huge mods or quality of life mods or just simple mods. 

The game is very cheap and goes on sale a lot of times, For me, it's 10.99$CAD for the game in Canada, 9.99$US and 6.99$pounds. If I would make a rating of this game I would give it a

9.4/10 and a Canadian maple leaf :)
Really fun game with a lot of content like weapons, armor, enemies, intense bosses, and even decorative things

Amazing Job.

If you are OK with very simple graphics, the game has a lot to offer in terms of content. This can be a pro, since it runs in many notebooks and not so powerful machines.

It is not easy to find out how to build stuff, and you will likely need to do your homework on specialized websites and wikis. You will probably need help to find out how to summon bosses.

The good and fun parts are the exploration and the option to play multiplayer. This is what makes the game shine.

I am a 55 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 12 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Ive played more hours outside of steam and it's an experience to play and do with the right people!

Had to cheese final boss. I didn't like that. It got genuinely frustrating and annoying to play the game. I had to build a money farm and a box to put NPCs in, and hit the boss through walls, just to win. I admit I'm not the best gamer in the world. But I feel like, if I beat every single boss in a game through hard work and perseverance and dying many many MANY times, only to come up against a nigh-unkillable wall, where even after grinding for hundreds of hours and getting the best level (until that point) gear, I couldn't come close to defeating... That's not really a balanced boss. The game went from Zelda to Dark Souls REAL quick. That massively brought down my level of enjoyment. So even though I finally beat it, and I also plan on a modded playthrough now, I still can't in good conscience recommend it to other people.  Unless ridiculously massive difficulty spikes are your thing, I guess.

Terraria is a beautiful game yet it has such a simple style. There are endless things to do in your time playing this game by collecting cool items, weapons, armor and more. There are countless boss fights to test your skill and even holiday events to add something different around those times of year. Overall, the time and effort pays off and allows for countless hours to try new strategies, character builds, and much more. This game is amazing and I recommend it to anyone willing to give up some time to get into the game.

I've heard about this game on and off over the years, and I've always been curious to try it and I finally bought it this month. I would like to say it was DEFINITELY worth the price! I did buy it on sale, but if I ever had to buy it again I wouldn't mind paying full price now that I've experienced it.

In the beginning I had a lot of WTF moments because of all the enemies and the things I discover in this game, but that's something that makes it fun. It has a large assortment of items and biomes, as well as enemies and friendly critters, and the designs and ideas don't feel old! They're pretty creative. It didn't take too long for me to figure out the basics, the guide being there is also a huge help for figuring out what to do. It was overwhelming at first because there was A Lot of new stuff to me and so much to do, but as I played more it felt more manageable but still a good level of challenging!

Pros
-music
-art style
-beginning is pretty fun

cons
-the transition in difficulty after wall of flesh is not smooth at all. The next set of bosses are extremely tough and spawn very quick afterwards.
-it's taking me tons of hours to make minimal progress
-looking anything up because of how obscure it is or the lack of direction it gives you is bad game design

EDIT: Normal does not scale regardless if it's one player or 2+ people. This game is definitely fun with friends because there is no scaling so everything is a ton easier but playing alone and for the first time it's garbage.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game goes out of its way to punish players using 21:9 aspect monitors.

I recently changed to a 21:9 when my old 16:9 broke. Little did I know that the developers of Terraria were so colossally petty as to deliberately make their game de facto incompatible with 21:9 monitors. They could have just added black bars to the sides of the game screen like any game that was developed before 21:9s, but instead they created a forced zoom that shrinks the entire field of vision to far less than what you would get on a 16:9, thus making the game nearly unplayable, and certainly not enjoyable. Their flawed logic: 21:9 monitors give an unfair advantage in multiplayer. Except I don't play multiplayer. And more importantly, by shrinking the field of view in 21:9 to less than what players on 16:9 get, they are giving an unfair advantage to 16:9 players.

It's 2022 people. There are no "wide" monitors. There are no "ultra-wide" monitors. There are just monitors, and they come in all shapes and sizes.

Yes, I know that there's a mod to fix this. I don't care. The devs can take their deliberately broken game and shove it where the sun don't shine.

It's not Minecraft so don't expect that it plays much differently and is much more fleshed out and thorough in many more aspects of the game. The trade off being that the world is not infinite, but, you can create infinite worlds still, and take characters from one world to another, which allows you to gather materials outside of a main world to make it look beautiful, and keep it natural looking, or it allows you create separate worlds for separate purposes, transferring items between them. I think the two dimensional playstyle is a lot more fun and allows the developers to expand on many other aspects of the game not to mention it consistently runs well on all devices, even older ones that aren't really good for gaming. Plus it is easier to download worlds and mods for than anything else I've played with just a simple YouTube tutorial it took me about 5 minutes.  Phenomenal game with many great attributes about it, and plays smoothly on all devices. Would recommend to anyone with a lot of time on their hands who is open to playing a game with "retro graphics".

Put 5,000+ hours into this game, only for it to give me a horrendous game-breaking glitch. For some reason, whenever I left-click to use items to mine or to use my sword, in Journey Mode, it just opens up an array of menus in vertical order that have the symbols of a yellow,red,blue box, a gear wheel, a clock, a fist, a painting, and a skull. I can't back out of this for some reason, even when I open up Settings to Exit the game. I tried reinstalling, and even Alt+Clicking some items to favorite them ('cuz other than opening up uncloseable menus, the game also thinks I'm trying to throw stuff). Nothing has changed this. 
Hope the game gets a good fixing, 'cuz I'm tapping out.

Character created and world generated in 2015. Finally beat the Moon Lord today. The fact that I was able to come back to a 7+ year old save and progress it incrementally over the years without any save breaks, character stat or inventory loss, or world state loss while they were doing major version upgrades is definitely a sign that Re-Logic was worthy getting the Labor of Love award. Terraria is one of the few games I would love to forget and fall in love playing again, so that I could relive the joys of discovering new biomes, new gear, new bosses and that feeling of finally defeating a boss and getting access to all the new goodies. Can't wait to see what 1.4.4 has for us! I might play through it again once that update drops and finally get some better inventory management (if you know, you know :P).

requirements vital to nations and not consider them untouchable for eternity.
