accepted them. It would have sufficed not to reject the proposal of the Fuehrer [Hitler] made last October 6 after the
campaign in Poland ended.
Now all that belongs to the past.
If today we have decided to take the risks and sacrifices of war, it is because the honor, interests, and future firmly
impose it since a great people is truly such if it considers its obligations sacred and does not avoid the supreme trails
that determine the course of history.
We are taking up arms, after having solved the problem of our continental frontiers. We want to break the territorial
and military chains that confine us in our sea because a country of 45,000,000 souls is not truly free if it has not free
access to the ocean.
This gigantic conflict is only a phase of the logical development of our revolution. It is the conflict of poor,
numerous peoples who labor against starvers who ferociously cling to a monopoly of all riches and all gold on earth.
It is a conflict of fruitful, useful peoples against peoples who are in a decline. It is a conflict between two ages, two
ideas.
Now the die is cast and our will has burned our ships behind us.
I solemnly declare that Italy does not intend to drag other peoples bordering on her by sea or land into the conflict.
Switzerland, Yugoslavia, Greece, Turkey, and Egypt, take note of these words of mine. It depends on them and only
on them if these words are rigorously confirmed or not.
Italians, in a memorable mass meeting in Berlin, I said that according to the rules of Fascist morals when one has a
friend one marches with him to the end. This we have done and will continue to do with Germany, her people and
her victorious armed forces.
On this eve of an event of import for centuries, we turn our thoughts to His Majesty, the King and Emperor, who
always has understood the thought of the country.
Lastly, we salute the new Fuehrer, the chief of great allied Germany.
Proletariat, Fascist Italy has arisen for the third time, strong, proud, compact as never before.
There is only one order. It is categorical and obligatory for every one. It already wings over and enflames hearts
from the Alps to the Indian Ocean: Conquer!
And we will conquer in order, finally, to give a new world of peace with justice to Italy, to Europe and to the
universe.
Italian people, rush to arms and show your tenacity, your courage, your valor.

This is a great game with a lot of content that you won't see in a single run.  It's a lot of fun and gives you a lot of options for how you want to play. I've played this game for years and can say no two runs will be the same. Expert mode is a great option for when you want a bit more of a challenge and has great new rewards for doing so. 
The only criticism I have for this game is pillar event/moon lord.  The pillars are tedious and boring, the enemies are annoying, with one enemy for each pillar being a major problem while the rest are just fodder. And then, after all that( and waiting for an eternity) the moon lord appears. I love his design, and the fight is reasonable on normal and expert, but the high health and defense on master mode makes the fight take and obnoxiously long time. And if you win' your prize is a one in nine chance to get the item you actually want.

I don't think this game needs a review, it's just so beloved already, but as with many people, I absolutely adore many aspects of Terraria. 

The gameplay seems deceptively simple at the start, but as you go, it opens up and before you know it you're fighting eldritch monsters in epic battles at that shape the world itself. The game's creativity seems so limitless that when compared with games of a similar ilk, they can hardly compare. I've put lots of hours into those adjacent to Terraria; Minecraft, Starbound, but there's just a boundless charm to every ounce of Terraria. The exploration is so beautiful and meaningful. Every direction you go there's something new and interesting to find. New items to craft, new bosses to fight. It really is a game that keeps on giving. 

Also if you haven't done it yet, get TModLoader and play the Calamity mod. It's amazing. It feels like a very natural extension of the already beautiful base game, but only if you've completed the base game prior.

If you ever keep scrolling, looking for games, I'm sure this one will catch your attention. Terraria is a world-wide known game, in which you can either play in "creative mode" (Journey) or try your skills in survival mode. You can select between Classic, Expert and Mastermode difficulty, based on the player's comforts. It's a great change of pace, because you need to constantly upgrade your gear and weapons. This may sound a bit boring, but I can assure you, it's really entertaining. I would recommend that game to every player.

I am a person who thought that I would never play this game. To be honest, I was fairly adamant at one point in my life about not wanting to try it out. One night, however, I got drunk with a buddy over voice chat and he convinced me to buy what I thought at the time was a cheapie 2D Minecraft clone. Boy, was I wrong. This game is a million times better than Minecraft. In fact, I do not know why i had even compared the two. What started as a little wood chopping and house building adventure eventually turned into a one hundred hour long duo playthrough with my buddy. I think this game actually improved our friendship. I still can't wrap my head around all of the stuff you can do in this game. In Minecraft you fight a dragon. In Terraria you fight fucking Cthulu. Must I say more?

Just writing this cause I noticed I never wrote a review for this even though a lot of people have probably already played this game and know how great it is. If you have not yet played Terraria you 100% should, just to try it out at least. One of the greatest games ever made with so many possibilities on what to do and an insanely amazing amount of replay value, not to mention the almost insurmountable amount of items that this game throws at you is great. BUY THIS! 
This is better than almost any other game ive ever played. and ive put more hours into it than any other game i have on my account (as of 7/21/2022) its not just minecraft but 2D, its so much bigger. there's so much to do, so many boss fights to win, so much items to make, so many places to find (and raid) you can make items, make houses for NPCs, fight monsters, try out mods (SO MANY MODS) play around with items, make minigames, and put those minigames out on the workshop. you can make golf maps, you can make PVP maps, parkour maps, adventure maps, using wires and a bunch of creativity, you can make entire games and stories in here. and the amount of mods this game has is just comical. you just never run out of fun things to do. and it runs well on low end hardware, so long as you mess with graphics settings a little bit.
and theres multiplayer. and it makes the game even more enjoyable. but im not gonna get into that, because i havent played it. 

10/10 game. while minecraft is making updates designed to ruin the playerbase, re-logic is making updates to keep the community hyped up, and happy. and they do it perfectly. 
oh yeah, and one more thing, the soundtrack is really good. and its worth buying it for 5 bucks just to support whoever made it.

Terraria is hard if you're new, but it's a good adventure to have. Figuring out how to beat bosses and get better gear (with slight bit of help from the wiki) and talking to the guide is pretty much all you need to progress. It gets rough though when you enter hard mode as enemies began to shred through you and began to pose a challenge once again. The game's progression scales in difficulty is alright - not the best as from pre-hardmode to hardmode enemies just seem to do x5 damage, but that's what Terraria is about. Very good game and has replayability as you can get additional gear from the alternate crimson/corruption biomes in different worlds as well as difficulty (normal, expert and master).

More than anything, I feel like Terraria is a game crafted with love. The more you play it, the more you can feel the love the creators have put into every little facet of the game. What else can be said about this wonderful game that hasn't already been said? The gameplay is exquisite, the soundtrack is one banger after another, and the progression is so juicy that after you take one bite, you can't stop yourself. If you consider yourself a person who enjoys video games, you are doing yourself a disservice if you don't try Terraria. And at the price it's selling for, it's a damn steal.
This game is very fun although people may think it's bad because its 2d it being 2d is one of the best parts about the game.

I am a 4,500 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Of All of the games I have played, This one is my favorite. For only ten dollars I have spent 603 Hours (at the time of writing (Not including Tmod)) playing, building, and exploring the Worlds of Terraria.
If you want something that has the most bang for your Buck, Terraria is it.
If you want a way to build in cool and unique ways, Terraria is it.
If you want Combat that is Loose, yet still somehow rigid, Terraria is it.
If you want to play one of the best games Ever made, Terraria is it.
$10 may be a bit much, but I promise that this is worth more than the most recent TrippleA game produced by Company:tm: 
If you want a good time, Terraria is it.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you‚Äôre watching this tape, I‚Äôm probably dead‚Äì murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my fiftieth birthday, Hank came to me with a rather shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was astounded. I‚ÄìI always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time‚Äìsomething he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn‚Äôt want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head and, Hank had a partner named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn‚Äôt know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, of which Fring flatly refused to give it, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh, I guess‚Ä¶ I guess you call it a hit on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me. And he gave me no option in that. I have often contemplated suicide, but I‚Äôm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the reigns to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time to keep me in line, he took my children from me, for three months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done. Why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. And I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me. Or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

So basically, me, my friend, and his dad were chilling on the beaches in Los Angeles when his dad told us that he had bought a new speedboat. So we went down to the marina and saw this long, red, slick looking speedboat. I then looked over to see his dad twirling the keys in his finger and then he stepped into the boat. Me and my friend both hopped into the boat and we all left the marina. His dad then told us both, "Picked 'er up for about $65 000, and she can go REAL fast." We both put a large grin on our faces along with a pair of life jackets. My friends dad then sat us down and then cranked the throttle all the way, making the boat almost fly across the water. We were going around 150 km/h at max. While me and my friend were enjoying the crystal beaches of LA, his dad reached for his sunglasses, and while he was digging around for his glasses he didn't notice a large boulder in front of the boat that we were speeding right towards. Luckily, me and my friend reacted quickly, we grabbed each other and then jumped off of the boat. We then watched in horror as my friends dad violently combusted along with his boat when he flew into the rock. I swam away unscathed but my friend had minor injuries around his foot and leg. We swam to shore where a local LA rat called emergency services, and we were taken home. That is the story of how my friends dad died in a high speed boating accident.

Starting with nothing but a pickaxe, axe, small sword and no armour, you have to survive the first night (zombie attack), gather ores and other materials to craft better armour (after building your workstations so you can craft), better weapons, better tools, and even potions and food using alchemy and cooking, so that you can go to more dangerous places to gather better ores and better materials to craft better armour, weapons and tools, to repeat the cycle until you're able to defeat the early game bosses (fairly non-linear, although there is a door boss gating you from the other 70% of the game).

These bosses will drop loot and materials that will help you upgrade everything to the next level, so you're able to go to more difficult areas to get better... you get the idea.

While the bosses are a nice challenge, there are also armies that will come to invade. They'll attack your village from the east or west and it's down to you to single handedly massacre them all for daring to attack, earning some coin and drops in the process.

Early on you can decide on your playstyle/class, in the way that you can use the standard sword and play as a melee character, or if you'd prefer, opt for bows and arrows, guns, flails, spells, summons, turrets, yoyos (surprisingly good considering they're yoyos), or all the weapons at once and switch it up mid combat. The armour you aim to craft and equip will be effected by the way you want to play. Later armours have more stats than just defence, so you won't want to be aiming for that +20% melee damage armour if you're set on being a gunner.

But the grind isn't the goal of the game. Doing whatever you want is. After the initial gearing up session so the average overworld slime isn't a challenge to you, you're fairly free to build your dream castle/haunted mansion/undersea base/bat cave or play around making pixel art (check the internet for the incredible things people have built).

You can build a nice village for your NPCs (they'll come move in once you've met certain criteria) or trap them inside square rooms with no way out, or just straight up murder them in a lava pit if you feel like it. Some of them even drop vanity items.

Work on getting your wings so you can fly, or a flying mount to zip around even easier. Get the cutest minion to follow you around and customise your mine cart so you zoom through the underground on a fish-mobile. Explore the various underground biomes, as well as the equally dangerous overground ones. Rescue the mechanic so you can add wiring to your village, or the goblin tinkerer so you can upgrade your accessories.

Finally, the entire game is multiplayer, so kill those bosses, dig up those ores, build those fancy houses and jam to the addictive soundtrack with your friends (or kill them, there's also a PvP mode).

The list of what you can do in this game is fairly endless, but if it's any example, I didn't play for over 1,200 hours just to kill the same bosses again and again.

If you're still unconvinced, check out a few Let's Plays on YouTube. That usually helps me make the decision about whether or not to buy a game.

I have spent more time than I'd like to admit playing Terraria, I originally played it on my 3DS years ago and poured hours into it nonstop. Unfortunately due to the buggy nature of the 3DS my original save file got corrupted but that didn't stop me from loving this game.

Content: The game has thousands of items to collect and over a dozen bosses to fight. On your first play through you'll most definitely need to check the wiki just due to the sheer amount of content in this game. It's honestly mind blowing and can seem overwhelming, but that only makes it more fulfilling when you start to understand the mechanics of the and get better at them. 9/10

Progression: I can't think of any other game that makes you feel this badass, you go from a sad scrawny boy to a UFO-riding, zenith-wielding, dolphin-shooting Chad. There is nothing more rewarding than killing the boss you've been stuck on for hours and reaping the rewards of its demise. 10/10

Visuals: The visuals are nothing groundbreaking in the world of gaming but goddamn this game looks nice. The sprites and animations of enemies are consistently good. The backgrounds look fantastic. I have seen some crazy cool shit that people have made in this game, despite the game being 2-D it never seems confined by this and instead thrives on it. 9/10

Soundtrack: Genuinely my favourite OST in a video game ever. Maybe it's nostalgia but this shit goes hard. The only thing holding me back from smashing my monitor after dying to a giant wasp for the tenth time is the funky beats playing in the underground jungle. The boss fight music is just fantastic and gets me in the mood to go sicko mode on those fuckers every time. Its just all around iconic and has very few weak points. 10/10

Gameplay: The overall Terraria experience is great but isn't super friendly to new players. But fear not, there are many guides to follow for the early game and the Terraria Wiki will have all the answers you need. A lot of elements of the game can be tailored to your personal preferences. For example, grinding, you can go into the game completely blind and use whatever items the game throws at you, or you can spend hours grinding to get rare items like the Rod of Discord. You can also go for a completionist run and get every achievement in the game, fair warning the fishing quests are hell. But in general the gameplay is rewarding, fun and keeps me coming back time and time again. 10/10

Replayability: Terraria is one of the most replayable games I have ever played. This is due to a number of factors. The amount of content in the game ensures that two of your playthroughs will never be the exact same, you're always going to acquire different gear to progress the game and it's always fun to experiment with different combinations. On that topic there are different dedicated classes you can play as in Terraria, such as melee, ranged, magic and summoning. All of them are unique and challenging in their own right and are all worth checking out at least once. You can also just say fuck it and mash all the classes into an OP abomination and it will still be fun. There are also a few different difficulties to play in, classic, expert, master and journey. From classic through master the difficulty expectantly gets harder, but there are also unique items that are only obtainable in their respective difficulties. Journey mode is the most interesting because it gives more freedom and turns the game into more of a sandbox, the best parallel I could give is Minecraft's creative mode. But its mostly the satisfying gameplay that always makes me excited to start up a new playthrough. 11/10

Community: In my experience the Terraria community is mostly filled with creative nice people. And the modding community for this game is also thriving and the mods can add a lot to your experience with Terraria. 9/10

To conclude this review, I can't express to you how outstanding this game is and the impact its had on my life.
If your on the fence about buying this game, just go for it, for the $11 that you spend on it, it is so unbelievably worth it

Almost as if Minecraft became a 2D 16-bit pixil game with chock full of references to other popular video games and homages to pop culture. The crafting is extensive and is far from logical when crafting items, as is the item names and the descriptions for items. This game is obvious that it doesn't take itself too seriously and is surprisingly very addictive. You can wear costumes, equip funky gear to do awesome and at time odd maneuvers and skills, fight slimes, mimics, and lovecraftian monsters. Do some fishing in-between and hopefully not get caught during a Blood Moon, or make it back in time to fight off the Goblin Army or an Airship pirate invasion. With luck, maybe a lovely patch of land will land will converted into Terraria's version of Whimseyshire from Diablo III and you'll get to play with pink unicorns who'd love to trample your corpse.

The benefits of this game - unlike most others if not all others games - is that when you do exhaust all you can do on your map, you can pack your bags and hop onto a new map for a new adventure with all your loot you've earned. The developers made sure that they kept the "fun" aspect of this game and it can be as hard or as easy as you make it, you don't have to loose anything if you want to. 







NOTE: This is my opinion and thoughts of the game and not an overall view of the game for general audiences. As with many reviews and opinions, take this with a grain of salt and do your own research. This notice should not be necessary, but is included due to previous inflammatory commentary on reviews from previous games due to people being "butt-hurt" that I said either something bad about the game, disagreed with it being good, disagreed with it being bad, or using "wording or descriptions" one doesn't agree with.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Rookie hours as of creating this review, most of my hours for Terraria have been sunk in using the mobile version. That being said, the PC version is the definitive way to enjoy the full experience. The game only gets boring if you allow it to, as there's multiple different classes, paths for progression and thousands of options for building as well to accommodate for the person who just prefers to build pretty buildings. If you like survival, platforming adventure whilst also enjoying the metroidvania-esk progression ladder, you'll absolutely love Terraria

I've played almost a hundred hours and have yet to defeat the empress of light. 

Terraria is a massive game that's relaxing yet chaotic, easy to have fun, but hard not to lose mental. There's building, fishing, fighting, making a town, fighting the world from killing itself, a million items, and most of all, developers that keep on updating.

When I first picked up this game, I really thought it was a nice pixel building simulator and boy was I wrong. I spent more time preparing for the moon lord than I spent prepping for my ACT tests, I've spent more hours waiting for one gosh damn truffle worm than I've spent studying in my entire life (I've got more hours on TModLoader), and I've died to the eye of cthulu more times that I'll admit to anyone.

Alongside building your township and mining for shiny ore, you've got a nice little boss progression that pushes you through the game only at a pace you're comfortable with. There's a million different weapons so you can shoot, slash, cast, and yo-yo whatever fierce thing rolls up to your doorstep. There's more biomes in Terraria than I have black shirts in my wardrobe (I've got a lot, black's my color man.) 

This open world adventure game is the gift that keeps on giving and there's another update coming out soon as well. Thanks for 10 years of fun Re-Logic, and I hope we get another 10 more.

Awesome game! Definitely worth the money. Really, really, really hard though. I'm not a great gamer, but this is one of the harder games i have played, especially after entering hard-mode. It's a sandbox game, simple at its core. What results attractive to this game is the "do whatever that you want" thing.
You'll have to survive and all that, defeating some bosses to progress and all that stuff in a survival rpg style. tho if you aren't into that and want to make some cool looking structures. the game offers some easy ways to make your 2dimensional house more pretty, literally, creative mode (kinda), easy mode, and more... but, if you don't want to make a happily ever after house, you can fight to death this badass bosses, find a pyramid, take adventure on some lovecraft's creations (or at least a part of them).
In conclusion:
it's a sandbox game. You can do whatever you like and if you get used to it, you'll find it kinda chill.
100% recommendable + if you have friends.

One of the best games out there, hands down. 
Playing alone? The perfect mix of length, things to do, and pacing.
With friends? it can be a clusterfuck of enjoyment, with what can feel like even more of a challenge than single player.
The game is one that by itself is fan-fucking-tastic, but with mods? it only gets better.
For 10 bucks, this is easily one of the best "bang for your buck" games.

I feel like writing a review for Terraria is now pointless. It seems like everyone who ever would play it already has/does. But, if by some chance, you have never played it, and you're reading this, do yourself a favor. Go play Terraria.

This game has been out since 2011, and it still holds up, and will do so for years and years to come. I go through periods of time where I don't play, but I ALWAYS come back to it and never get sick of it. It's like literally discovering a new world with every new game. I learn new things about it even now, over a decade later. AND if you don't delete your characters and worlds, you can always pick up right where you left off or start a new world as the same character.

The graphics are so pleasing to the eye, the music is awesome, and while the game overall can feel rather difficult at times, learning HOW to play is actually quite simple. A lot of people call Terraria "2D Minecraft" because you can... mine. And of course, craft. But they are 2 separate games with their own pros and cons and everyone is going to have a preference. Mine is, and always will be, Terraria. It is more complex, and while you can argue that it's not necessarily a "story" you definitely progress in a way that you do not in Minecraft. Collecting all the NPCs to move into your town is a great example of this, as well as the many boss fights and goblin invasions that mostly occur randomly. I also really love all the little Easter eggs and references.

Seriously, if you haven't played it yet, go play it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Terraria is one of those games that some people just can't seem to let go of, and for good reason. I never really liked Minecraft, so when I was handed an Xbox360 version of this game, I was skeptic.  After putting many hours into the game, I realized that it was very outdated and didn't have a lot of the items that I was looking for to craft better gear.  So I decided to buy the PC version for myself.  I really wish that I could transfer a bunch of my stuff from the Xbox because starting over from scratch sucks.  I'm getting killed by mobs that I was killing with ease before, but oh well.  Though I love finding all new things on here that my other game didn't have.  In my opinion, this game is 1000 times better than Minecraft!!

Terraria's easily on the Mount Rushmore of early-2010's-indie-games. The elephant in the room is that, yes, in fact, this game IS quite a bit like Minecraft! You build up a house and survive the night whilst zombies attack you, and you mine into the ground to get progressively better materials(at first, anyways). 

However, Terraria has a bit more to it than just that. Terraria has a greater focus on both boss fights and weaponry. The bosses are actual bosses, not just sword/bow sponges with 2 or 3 attacks, and the weaponry is very diverse, with 4 classes that you'll be able to choose from in the base game, all of which are pretty different from one another.

I'd say in terms of content, Minecraft is wider, but Terraria is deeper. Terraria doesn't have 20+ stupid meaningless features, it only has about 5, tops. Playing the game straight-up is highly fun, either with friends or by yourself. I'd say to 'beat the game' and kill the final boss would take you about 30 to 50 hours, if you weren't using a guide. With a guide(and not the NPC!), it would definitely take less time. 

I will mention that the endgame of Terraria is much weaker than Minecraft's. In Terraria, after you beat the final boss, there's not a lot for you to do. You get plenty of nice weapons, certainly, but what could you use them on?

Aside from the weak endgame, I'd say that Terraria is a superb game with a lot to do in it. If you decide to get into modding, it can get even better.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is such a good game, with so much time and attention put into it. My biggest thing for open-ended games is that the world feels alive, which Terraria certainly is. From the start, you are put into a random world that will evolve in difficulty as you progress. Scattered throughout at little details that make things feel more immersive, such as growing environments. In Minecraft, for instance, you have biomes, but these biomes are location specific and do not grow themselves... This is a small example of nice details the developers have put into their game. Detail. The world feels alive. If you give space for it, other biomes will grow themselves and change the entire feel of the map. I love these little details!

But other than that? Terraria is great game for those who want an experience that slowly makes you feel like a powerful god, has clear, deep progression, and gives reason to strategize your progress to the next level.

This game is so chock-full of content (almost to a fault) that you'll be able to sink hours into this game and almost NEVER get bored. There is so much to do, so much you can CHOOSE to do, that every playthrough is different. The bosses are fun to fight, building is fun (if you want it to be, nothing's stopping you from making a small, dirt box and calling it a day, which is equally as valid), and there are so many options for gear, furniture, pets, mounts, vanity, accessories, EVERYTHING. Don't be intimidated if you're not sure how to play at first. You'll learn over time and have the time of your life!
It does bring a bit of a challenge but I like a good challenge. Overall, this game is quite fun to play and is great quality even being a 2-D type game.

This is one of the most fun and addicting games I have ever played. The amount of content is staggering. The progression system is fun and interesting. You can choose practically any play style you could possibly imagine. I tend to get lost in the world, in the possibilities, in the  game as a whole.

One of my favorite parts of this game are the bossfights. There are 17 bossfights in all, and all of them are unique and engaging. (Except Golem. That guy's a joke as far as difficulty goes, but he's still fun. We've memed him into oblivion.)

One of the best parts of this game is the community. Veterans are kind and helpful to new players, and the Workshop, (when it's not taken over by horny programmers drawing huge tits on everything in the game) is full of impassioned and talented people who genuinely love the game, and want to add to the experience.

It's one of the few games where the devs seem to be a part of the community. Relogic is made up of wizards, and they love the game and community. I've seen people ask for something in the game on Reddit, and the team at Relogic just up and adds it without question. If you look into this game, you'll undoubtedly be bombarded by the FiNaL uPdAtE meme, but it really is true. The devs really seem as though they can't help but work on this game. I admire that kind of passion and pride in their work.

All in all, this is an amazing game in every way, shape, and form. It should be on every gamers list, whether they be casual, competitive, or simply creative. You won't regret it for a second.
Fun fact: If you beat the game 5 times without dying once, Moon Lord actually becomes a naked zoologist, how crazy is that!

After playing this game for a couple of years now, and after recently getting all in-game achievements I can say with confidence that this is one of those games I've come to love over the years, with the updates and new content being added by the "Final update(s)" of the game. The game is HIGHLY repayable and when you bring in friends for some added extra fun it becomes a whole new experience that helps the game keep fresh after countless worlds and characters are created. If you haven't experienced it I recommend you give it a try and determine if this is the kind of game that works for you, I know I adored every single hour of gameplay. If you like open-world games where you can play at your own pace, by building incredible structures or grinding for that one item you so hardly desired. Terraria has something for you to enjoy

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, created my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Terraria is a Minecraft that traded its 3D world for litterally everything else. One of my friends gifted it to me on my birthday, and I can't thank him enough!
Now lets talk about the game: It has a huge variety of mobs, ores, bosses and so many different weapons that i can't even remember half of them! And there are many different biomes too. My personal favourite are the sky islands. The only thing i dislike in this game is the fact that the map isn't infinite. And there is so much to do, that you basically can't get bored! 
I consider this game being a 10/10!

Quick note: THIS IS AN ACTUAL REVIEW FOR PEOPLE LOOKING TO BUY THIS!

To be perfectly honest, I think Terraria is amazing, a great game with difficult bosses. But after the first, maybe second time you beat it, it just stops being too fun. That's why tModLoader exists, to keep the fun going! So if you want a game that will keep you playing forever and ever that's actually entertaining and isn't a clickergame/tycoon this is the game. 10/10 game. Only issue is the fact that Re-Logic scrapped some cool bosses and now they're only exclusive to certain platforms ( like Ocram who is only on Old-Console versions of the game, like the XBOX360 version. Or Lepus on the 3DS. ) Luckily, I did buy these versions so I can experience the bosses but still, keyboard and mouse are way easier to me.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

HOOOOO boy, this right here is by far my favorite game on steam. The progression is immaculate, the bosses are amazing, the exploration is satisfying... just, WOW. The music is outstanding, and the graphics(while pixelated) really match the sense of adventure and discovery. The bosses are absolutely amazing and test your skills extraordinarily well, with each boss kill giving an unreal sense of progression and satisfaction. Exploring the underground biomes and buildings never gets old, and just reeks of adventure. The second-half of the game(deemed "hardmode") is really when the game opens up, however you won't be getting any spoilers from me about it 'cause it's just that good. And don't get me started on the mods! Overall, just an absolutely outstanding game that reeks of passion both from the developers and the community. Although, do be prepared to grind some items for long periods of time.

i have played this game (if you add up the hours i have on mobile and on console) for ~1200 hours and it is my favourite game.
the amount of content in this 10‚Ç¨ game is incredible and the replay value is huge. there are 4 modes journey (not very fun) normal (good for first time players) expert (the best mode in my opinion) and master (which starts to be harder more than fun)  of course you can play using master mode which tests your skill at the game.
there are 4 classes in the game summoner melee ranger and magic and all of them have unique gameplay
when you buy the game you can use tMod Loader (terraria mod loader) and the ammount of mods that expand the game is uncountable (good examples: calamity, thorium).
the best part of the game has to be exploring (especially the caves) all of the biomes have unique mobs, accesories, weapons and more.
the game runs on virtually any computer (even on my toaster) so you ll be guaranteed to have decent fps while playing it.
this is and will be the best game i have ever played and i don t regret spending as much time as i have spent on Terraria.
my adivce to you is to convince your friends to play it with as it makes the game exponentally better and (if you cant spend the 10‚Ç¨) to wait untill it goes on sale or (if you want to play alone) pirate it and then decide if you want to buy the game when you ve made an informed decision.

This was my grandmother's apple pie recipe. I have never seen another one quite like it. It will always be my favorite and has won me several first place prizes in local competitions. I hope it becomes one of your favorites as well!

1 recipe pastry for a 9 inch double crust pie
¬Ω cup unsalted butter
3 tablespoons all-purpose flour 
¬º cup water
¬Ω cup white sugar
¬Ω cup packed brown sugar
8 Granny Smith apples - peeled, cored and sliced

Directions Below -

Step 1
Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Melt the butter in a saucepan. Stir in flour to form a paste. Add water, white sugar and brown sugar, and bring to a boil. Reduce temperature and let simmer.

Step 2
Place the bottom crust in your pan. Fill with apples, mounded slightly. Cover with a lattice work crust. Gently pour the sugar and butter liquid over the crust. Pour slowly so that it does not run off.

Step 3
Bake 15 minutes in the preheated oven. Reduce the temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Continue baking for 35 to 45 minutes, until apples are soft.

If you're ever sick of the repetition of Minecraft, then this is the place to go. There is just so much to this game and stuff I'm willing to bet I still don't know exists in it. Usually if I'm playing a creative or survival game I will have music going on in the back round, but not for this one since every song is an absolute banger and puts you into the setting. It is by far probably one of my favorite games to play with friends. I plan on playing calamity for the first time very soon as well. Overall this game definitely is something I will continue to play whether it updates more or not.

A Very Entertaining Game
The game may not have the best graphics when compared to other games, but, it more than makes up for it in terms of gameplay. Due to the multitude of weapons and tools in the game itself, you can spec out into a few different classes which gives you a lot to mess around with. 
In terms of difficulty, when you first start playing the game, you may find it a bit difficult as you may not know what to do. But, after talking to the first NPC you encounter and doing some exploring,  you'll get the hang of it in no time. Once you've finished the game on normal difficulty, you can go on to play on higher difficulties. Higher difficulties will give you more loot from bosses which will give you a slightly different experience than when you played the game on normal. 
You can mod the game too.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Lore text
Welcome to the World of Terraria. A land full of mystery and wonder, with much of its destiny left up to the wildest imaginations... however, a few legends of old have made their way to our present time. Passed down by countless generations of the Order of the Guide, these few scraps of information will serve to help you navigate your journey and overcome threats lurking in the shadows. This knowledge is now passed on to you, the brave adventurer, with the hope that it will aid you in your quest to save our world...

In the beginning, the Gods established a balance to guarantee fairness for all living creatures. This balance was to be of paramount importance, with no cost too great in seeking its fulfillment. Eons have passed since the Gods first began testing the complexities of life in their fairness experiment. In this process, countless living worlds were created and now exist within the Terraria universe. Each world of Terraria is a sentient being that knows all that goes on and can feel the thoughts of all living creatures: with their sole purpose being to ensure that the desired balance is maintained ‚Äì often violently so. The worlds utilize many defense mechanisms to ensure the balance is upheld at all costs ‚Äì some of them are known as the Hallow, Corruption, and Crimson.

The Crimson
The Crimson is a single emergent living being connected directly to each world, sharing a hive mind, and solely focused on restoring balance at all costs. Thousands of worlds before the one on which you stand now have been absorbed by this being. Many misguided people have made the horrific mistake of raising the Crimson to the level of a deity ‚Äì conducting human sacrifices to it to placate the monstrosity or seek its favor. The Crimson gladly consumes these bodies, becoming one with them and producing terrifying beings, who lose the ability to feel and blindly follow the hive mind.

The Corruption
The Corruption is a cancer caused by the sins of those living in the worlds of Terraria. The vile actions and thoughts present in all beings feed the growth of the Corruption as it spreads relentlessly across each world. The Corruption knows nothing else but to consume everything it touches, leaving behind terrible creatures of hate that exist for the sole reason to cause pain in punishment for the unearned pleasure experienced by living things. After the Corruption restores balance to life, it destroys it with the goal of turning the world into a desolate abyss void of life.

The Hallow
The Hallow, on the other hand, is of an entirely different nature. Within each world is a Guardian who serves as the worlds[sic] master and core. Once this creature is destroyed the world will release the Ancient Spirits of Light and Dark to expedite the process of finding a new Guardian. It is here when the Hallow is created and functions as an overcompensation of purity, taken to the absolute extreme. The Hallow cures threats that would attempt to violate the critical balance of life, killing anything in its path as though it were treating an infection ‚Äì whether friend, foe, or neutral party. Ultimately, the Hallow serves to push back against the never-ceasing encroachment of control.

Your World
It is against the backdrop of this precious balance of life, desolation and pain that the great battles of legend and the adventures of our time take place. In the blind spot of the universe, there exists a planet of unprecedented potential: your world!

Your story begins with Cthulhu ‚Äì a creature of immeasurable power and unknown origin ‚Äì who arrived long ago with its seemingly sole purpose being to rain destruction on and to have dominion over all the sentient life that flourishes on your world.

None could stand against the advances of Cthulhu. The very fabric of Terraria itself seemed on the precipice of doom. At last, when all hope seemed lost, the ancient race of Dryads arose to wage battle against Cthulhu. The Dryads, with their unparalleled connection to the planet, were Terraria's truly last hope as they joined together to save all life from annihilation.

The Dryads were alas unable to kill Cthulhu. However, with the Dryads [sic] combined power they were able to cripple Cthulhu's ability to wreak further damage on Terraria by ripping out Cthulhu's eyes, part of its skeleton, and chunks of its brain. Ultimately this substantial damage forced Cthulhu to retreat to the dark side of the moon, where it dwells to this day, gathering strength for another attempt at total conquest. As for the Dryads, sadly, all but a single member perished... and the sole survivor has not been seen for many, many years.

Lunatic Cult
Much time has passed since the Great War of Cthulhu. However, rumors tell of a Lunatic Cult led by a fanatical zealot that is methodically seeking to revive Cthulhu to its former power and bring about the end of the world. As a part of these efforts, a renowned genius ‚Äì known simply as the Mechanic ‚Äì has been kidnapped and forced to rebuild the parts needed to make Cthulhu whole once again. Hushed whispers tell of the results of these experiments: horrible mechanical simulacrums of Cthulhu's organs. The Mechanic has nearly completed her work, only needing to finish the Mechanical brain to restore Cthulhu to its full destructive power.

Passing travelers hear construction and screams emanating from the Dungeon ‚Äì an evil, demonic fortress of the dead in which the Mechanic is supposedly held prisoner as she conducts her work.

Many across Terraria have fallen under the possession of the cult, including the benevolent Old Man who oversees the Dungeon, a once thriving city full of life until a curse forced all its inhabitants to go mad ‚Äì living beyond the point where their bodies rotted away and they became mindless undead servants of evil. Without some intervention, some force to stem this tide, some hero to save the day, Terraria's doom is nigh at hand!

This brings us to our adventure. It begins with you ‚Äì in humble beginnings and shown your path by the faithful and mysterious Guide. As this world's champion, you will experience communications from the world to help protect your mission. The world has brought you to this specific location at this specific time ‚Äì will you stand up and fight for Terraria against the growing shadows of impending doom?

Warning: Very Addictive Game

I've had this game for about 6 days and 12 hours and I managed to put in 47 hours and beat Moonlord.

[u] [b] WARNING: OFTEN AN ANNOYING RNG GRINDING SIMULATOR [/b] [/u]

In my 47 hours of gameplay I've probably spent 20 hours or more grinding enemies and bosses for RNGesus to bless me. Sadly he never came. You have no idea how much pain I was in while grinding Rusty Armored Bones (one of the dungeon's most common post-Plantera enemies) just trying to get the goddamn Adhesive Bandage (his most common drop) to slap it on a shield. And by pain I mean KILLING ALMOST 400 OF THEM JUST TO GET MANY DUPLICATES OF HIS RAREST ITEMS AND ONE BANDAGE LIKE WTOJFHUAEWBNJVGIHNJKONRAEGFGNHOIRGBOK. During this painful escapade, I was also grinding Bone Lees in order to get the Black Belt and Tabi to become the master of [strike] puppe [/strike]ninjas. It felt like I was the unluckiest man alive and was wasting my time as I was killing Mr. Lee for probably half an hour as he dropped only coffee. However, after those 30 minutes, the tables were turned approximately 85 degrees as I got my first Black Belt. Then, not long later I would find myself obtaining my first Tabi. Did you notice how I said 'first' and not 'a'? Well that's because WHILE GRINDING FOR MY SPONGEBOB PATTERNED BAND-AID I GOT 2 MORE BLACK BELTS AND 5 MORE TABIS IN A SHORT AMOUNT OF TIME. WHERE IS THIS LUCK WHEN I DON'T HAVE THE ITEM? Aside from the mental agony; this grind did get me a lot of money. Luckily, I only had to kill 2 Corruptors to get my Flinstone Vitamin Gummies. Finally, I had the ingredients to make a special piece of paper of which I taped to my skull-engraved shield.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Lore text
Welcome to the World of Terraria. A land full of mystery and wonder, with much of its destiny left up to the wildest imaginations... however, a few legends of old have made their way to our present time. Passed down by countless generations of the Order of the Guide, these few scraps of information will serve to help you navigate your journey and overcome threats lurking in the shadows. This knowledge is now passed on to you, the brave adventurer, with the hope that it will aid you in your quest to save our world...

In the beginning, the Gods established a balance to guarantee fairness for all living creatures. This balance was to be of paramount importance, with no cost too great in seeking its fulfillment. Eons have passed since the Gods first began testing the complexities of life in their fairness experiment. In this process, countless living worlds were created and now exist within the Terraria universe. Each world of Terraria is a sentient being that knows all that goes on and can feel the thoughts of all living creatures: with their sole purpose being to ensure that the desired balance is maintained ‚Äì often violently so. The worlds utilize many defense mechanisms to ensure the balance is upheld at all costs ‚Äì some of them are known as the Hallow, Corruption, and Crimson.

The Crimson
The Crimson is a single emergent living being connected directly to each world, sharing a hive mind, and solely focused on restoring balance at all costs. Thousands of worlds before the one on which you stand now have been absorbed by this being. Many misguided people have made the horrific mistake of raising the Crimson to the level of a deity ‚Äì conducting human sacrifices to it to placate the monstrosity or seek its favor. The Crimson gladly consumes these bodies, becoming one with them and producing terrifying beings, who lose the ability to feel and blindly follow the hive mind.

The Corruption
The Corruption is a cancer caused by the sins of those living in the worlds of Terraria. The vile actions and thoughts present in all beings feed the growth of the Corruption as it spreads relentlessly across each world. The Corruption knows nothing else but to consume everything it touches, leaving behind terrible creatures of hate that exist for the sole reason to cause pain in punishment for the unearned pleasure experienced by living things. After the Corruption restores balance to life, it destroys it with the goal of turning the world into a desolate abyss void of life.

The Hallow
The Hallow, on the other hand, is of an entirely different nature. Within each world is a Guardian who serves as the worlds[sic] master and core. Once this creature is destroyed the world will release the Ancient Spirits of Light and Dark to expedite the process of finding a new Guardian. It is here when the Hallow is created and functions as an overcompensation of purity, taken to the absolute extreme. The Hallow cures threats that would attempt to violate the critical balance of life, killing anything in its path as though it were treating an infection ‚Äì whether friend, foe, or neutral party. Ultimately, the Hallow serves to push back against the never-ceasing encroachment of control.

Your World
It is against the backdrop of this precious balance of life, desolation and pain that the great battles of legend and the adventures of our time take place. In the blind spot of the universe, there exists a planet of unprecedented potential: your world!

Your story begins with Cthulhu ‚Äì a creature of immeasurable power and unknown origin ‚Äì who arrived long ago with its seemingly sole purpose being to rain destruction on and to have dominion over all the sentient life that flourishes on your world.

None could stand against the advances of Cthulhu. The very fabric of Terraria itself seemed on the precipice of doom. At last, when all hope seemed lost, the ancient race of Dryads arose to wage battle against Cthulhu. The Dryads, with their unparalleled connection to the planet, were Terraria's truly last hope as they joined together to save all life from annihilation.

The Dryads were alas unable to kill Cthulhu. However, with the Dryads [sic] combined power they were able to cripple Cthulhu's ability to wreak further damage on Terraria by ripping out Cthulhu's eyes, part of its skeleton, and chunks of its brain. Ultimately this substantial damage forced Cthulhu to retreat to the dark side of the moon, where it dwells to this day, gathering strength for another attempt at total conquest. As for the Dryads, sadly, all but a single member perished... and the sole survivor has not been seen for many, many years.

Lunatic Cult
Much time has passed since the Great War of Cthulhu. However, rumors tell of a Lunatic Cult led by a fanatical zealot that is methodically seeking to revive Cthulhu to its former power and bring about the end of the world. As a part of these efforts, a renowned genius ‚Äì known simply as the Mechanic ‚Äì has been kidnapped and forced to rebuild the parts needed to make Cthulhu whole once again. Hushed whispers tell of the results of these experiments: horrible mechanical simulacrums of Cthulhu's organs. The Mechanic has nearly completed her work, only needing to finish the Mechanical brain to restore Cthulhu to its full destructive power.

Passing travelers hear construction and screams emanating from the Dungeon ‚Äì an evil, demonic fortress of the dead in which the Mechanic is supposedly held prisoner as she conducts her work.

Many across Terraria have fallen under the possession of the cult, including the benevolent Old Man who oversees the Dungeon, a once thriving city full of life until a curse forced all its inhabitants to go mad ‚Äì living beyond the point where their bodies rotted away and they became mindless undead servants of evil. Without some intervention, some force to stem this tide, some hero to save the day, Terraria's doom is nigh at hand!

This brings us to our adventure. It begins with you ‚Äì in humble beginnings and shown your path by the faithful and mysterious Guide. As this world's champion, you will experience communications from the world to help protect your mission. The world has brought you to this specific location at this specific time ‚Äì will you stand up and fight for Terraria against the growing shadows of impending doom?

Great sandbox-survival game! Can be a little daunting, but the customisability of your worlds - from the difficulty to the seed itself - helps keep the game in [i]your[/i] ballpark.

The only real downside is the grinding involved to get some of the items; however, you do have help in the form of battle potions and blue candles to increase the spawn rates of enemies, thus reducing the time spent grinding/farming significantly.

Don't like fighting? Don't worry! You can reduce the spawn rates of enemies via sunflowers, peace candles, and potions! Alongside that are various activities you can do to relieve stress, such as fishing, which includes various quests, or golfing, which can be done pretty much anywhere!

Excellent pick for people who love spelunking, combat, fishing, golfing, or [i]literal[/i] worldbuilding!

[h1] Terraria is a great game. [/h1]

I've followed it from the very beginnings. Its one I played for years on four different accounts with every possible build option. I've built many great looking houses and defeated many enemies hundred of times. I am trying to better myself with master difficulity but it is tough as nails. It is fun to play alone and its great with friends. Time just vanishes as you play because the world and what to do's just sucks you in. But here are some pro's and con's with the base game.

Pro's:
- When you fight a boss you feel awesome and it feels great to defeat them.
- There are many funny deaths and its easy to just laugh at your failure.
- The progression is very good, its balanced enough that you really can measure how much a suit of armor helps or a better sword does.
- You can customize yourself in many ways and can do head canon stories for your character.
- Playing with friends makes the game more difficult but also fun.
- The music is great.
- Easy to learn hard to master type of game, when you try the higher difficulities you really need all you can get. Buffs, potions, accessories, reforges, and the nurse becomes so much more handy.

Con's:
- Fishing and other randomly decided things can get annoying to do. When you need just that one special thing and it has a 1% drop chance you really need to grind and in the end it leaves you with a bit bitter taste at the end.
- Sometimes you just get upset when you die and it can be difficult in single player to respawn the bosses and waves every time because when you die they go away (except if there are other players alive). 
- There are sort of classes in the game, but it changes as you progress. It would be really nice if all class options would be avaiable trough out the whole game and even it would be better if there would be more classes.
- The game doesn't hold your hand. It doesn't tell you if you need to build a structure to fight a boss or a wave. It would be nice if it would tell you to build an arena to have a better chance againts some.
- It gets tedious to manage the chests as you progress with lot of loot and you need crafting stations close to each other to see recipes.

But overall it is a great game to purchase and play. It is worth the full price but there are many times when it goes on sale. 

Also there is the tModLoader you can get for it to download mods to make the game even more refined and great. There are a couple of fantastic mods to try too.

I hope I helped a little.

This masterpiece of a game takes you through a journey, not only going to hell and back, but so much more beyond! It is a wonder on how you can get carried away playing the same game from so long ago, but I keep finding myself going back into this game time and time again, reliving the journey I fell in love with as a kid. As for difficulty scaling, it can go anywhere from a peaceful building game where you can express yourself, or recreate whatever you may want, to a game where any wrong step could mean instant death. I think the four choices of difficulty truly serve as a good outline for so many people's style of playing! I love this game, and it will always be one of my favorites!

Herman Melville‚Äôs iconic 1851 video game Terraria is an undisputed American classic. Since it was first published, it‚Äôs been translated into 22 languages and received international acclaim, with more than 50 million copies sold worldwide.

For those who don‚Äôt know, this epic maritime tale follows Captain YOURPLAYERNAMEHERE on an obsessive mission for revenge. His target is a giant MOON LORD who bit off his leg on a previous voyage. The story is told from the perspective of a sailor named YOURCHARACTERNAMEHERE, who watches on in awe at the captain‚Äôs erratic quest to dominate nature.

If you‚Äôve not played terraria, don‚Äôt worry, I won‚Äôt spoil it for you. In this article, I‚Äôll just give you a little teaser in the form of the opening and closing lines of the video game. I‚Äôll also throw in some fun facts about this classic tale that even fans of the video game might not know about.

‚ÄúCall me Ishmael‚Äù‚Ä¶

There are some lines from literature that have entered the public "zeitgeist" and become icons in their own right, and this famous opening line of terraria is certainly one of them.

This instantly recognizable quote is short and simple, but these three little words do a great job of setting the tone for the rest of the story. This attention-grabbing line creates an air of intimacy, as well as gentle authority, as we‚Äôre immediately acquainted with our narrator. We‚Äôre left wanting to know more about this mysterious YOURCHARACTERNAMEHERE character and the tales he has to tell us.

The placement of this short sentence also adds to its power, so to give you a little context, here is the full opening paragraph of the first chapter of Terraria; Loomings.

‚ÄúCall me YOURCHARACTERNAMEHERE Some years ago‚Äînever mind how long precisely‚Äîhaving little or no money in my purse, and nothing particular to interest me on shore, I thought I would sail about a little and see the watery part of the world. It is a way I have of driving off the spleen and regulating circulation. Whenever I find myself growing grim about the mouth; whenever it is a damp, drizzly November in my soul; whenever I find myself involuntarily pausing before coffin warehouses, and bringing up the rear of every funeral I meet; and especially whenever my hypos get such an upper hand of me, that it requires a strong moral principle to prevent me from deliberately stepping into the street, and methodically knocking people‚Äôs hats off‚Äîthen, I account it high time to get to sea as soon as I can. There is nothing surprising in this. If they but knew it, almost all men in their degree, some time or other, cherish very nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me.‚Äù

This first paragraph reveals an awful lot about YOURCHARACTERNAMEHERE. Immediately he implies that he‚Äôs not from wealth or aristocracy, ‚Äúhaving little or no money in my purse.‚Äù He also peppers in a little dry humor, with lines like ‚ÄúI thought I would sail about a little and see the watery part of the world.‚Äù That humor takes on a darker theme when he talks of ‚Äúinvoluntarily pausing before coffin warehouses, and bringing up the rear of every funeral I meet.‚Äú

Within just a few sentences, it‚Äôs clear that our narrator is prone to bouts of the blues and that his way of combating them is to set out on an adventure at sea.

The lines ‚ÄúThis is my substitute for pistol and ball. With a philosophical flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I quietly take to the ship‚Äù are his tongue in cheek way of sharing his tendency to suicidal thoughts that can only be alleviated by escaping his life on land and heading out onto the open terraria video game.

By introducing this morbid theme so early on, Melville sets the scene for the rest of the story. As anyone who has played Terraria can attest, the video game is filled with dark, melancholy descriptions and metaphors about the grim reality of madness and obsession.

[h1] Terraria (2011), 99/100 [/h1]

[i] - A declaration of love to videogames players. Essential. [/i]


[b] PLUS [/b]

- 11 years after launch and a free (as is all Terraria content to date) update is coming. If that's not dedication to the players, I don't know what is.
- Dig, build, fight, collect, create, decorate, fish, eat... endless things to do with multitude of tools at your disposal. Imagination is your limit.
- Charming soundtrack.
- Mods support and a fantastic long lasting community.
- No missable content, play at your own pace.
- Even better playing with friends.
- Incredible price, hard to find more for less, anywhere.


[b] MINUS [/b]

- The Angler's quest daily (in game) limit, makes the 200 quests achievement a bit tedius. But there are workarounds, nothing serious.
- The interface could get some quality of life improvements, like saved presets of weapons+armors+accesories, or consumables+potions. Bigger stacks, storage and interaction range for packmules and compulsive collectors like me.


[b] RECOMMENDATIONS [/b]

- Take your time and enjoy the journey.
- All combat styles are viable, check out the wiki for lots of info and strategies if you're having a hard time with a boss.
- A character can visit different worlds, you can carry items with you from one to another.
- Zenith (obviously and absolutely).


[i] Played Build ID 8369983, June 2022, Windows 10, Lenovo Legion. [/i]
[i] - Stable: not a single problem. [/i]

Terraria is a fantastic game that rewards the player for exploration, curiosity, and creativity. It has a wonderful curve of progression and difficulty and I would highly recommend the game.

The statement of Terraria being "2D Minecraft" is entirely false. 
While they share some minor similarities, Terraria is of course an entirely separate experience from Minecraft. While Minecraft has only a few bosses, with only one of which being necessary to kill in order to beat the game, Terraria has over 15 bosses, and a number of minibosses. Almost all of which are necessary to beat in order to progress. Terraria is far more oriented on progression, advancement, and combat than minecraft is, and should attract players who are ready for and want that. I would recommend, for your first few playthroughs of the game, to play with the wiki constantly at your side, as well as preferably a more seasoned friend who knows the game. If you want to expand the experience, or simply avoid some of the grinding necessary in Terraria, tModLoader is there to help (free once you purchase Terraria). Terraria features 4 unique classes with their own weapons, armor, and accessories to suit a high range of playstyles, and of course mods only add more to this. There is a lot more to say about this game, but I think this is enough to at least get you interested, and maybe give it a try. Once you begin playing it, the game speaks for itself. Between vanilla, tModLoader, and the time I spent on Playstation, I have over 250 hours on this game, and it keeps increasing. Terraria has high replayability, engaging game play, and it's overall a blast.

Best ten bucks of my life

The best $10 I've spent in my life. I don't know how I lived without this game before I had it to be honest. It has more content than it ever needed and even after 1,000 hours I haven't gotten every achievement, which is a good thing. The re-playability is great, and you can get mods extremely easily, without even getting out of the game, in fact. The game features four difficulties, each with varying loot and small changes, namely Journey Mode, Classic Mode (which is basically just an easy mode), Expert Mode, and Master Mode. As a beginner, I'd recommend Classic mode at first, then once you have a grip on the game and how it works, move on to Expert mode. Expert mode provides plenty of extra loot, and once you have defeated a boss in Expert mode, you just can't go back because there are loot bags that give you excellent loot almost vital to move on in my opinion. Finally, once you have a solid grip on the game and feel like you need more of a challenge, move on to Master mode. If that isn't enough challenge for you somehow, try some popular mods. Anyway, this game has been my favorite for years and probably will never stop being my favorite game, ever.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This is game . It is called Terraria - the game is actually pretty n0ice ,except one thing that not everyone gonna like . Unlike such games as minecraft or another sandboxes in this game you waste lots of time on learning mechanics of the game. For excample the game is based on 2nd demention . So you will move towards left right up and down like in oldschool games (sonic/ mario/ etc.). Also there are many types of armor and tools; and you will never choose what type of armor you should wear , because you will ocasionaly or naturally, walking through the game, find another , better armor . Then , very soon you will have to choose one of four classes : mage, melee, shooter, summoner. In the begining you dont have to worry about it . You can be whatever you like , But sooner , after killing one of important bosses , you will need a guide to play for the class you chose .
Many bosses,many mobs, large amount of: fishes, biomes, NPCs, where each sells different items and lives in pleasant biome , two stages of the game: pre-hardmode and hardmode itself.
If you like building, exploring, learning - then "Terraria needs you" (dryad)

I fucking hate this game.
I hate loot-heavy games where you grind the same enemy over and over again until you get the rare drop you want, only to defeat a boss that trivializes all your hard work by unlocking stronger gear.
I hate games where your class is entirely dependent on what gear you're wearing, crushing any semblance of roleplay as a specialized character who is more than the blade they wield.
I hate games with disjointed mechanic bloat, where it seems that ideas are tossed in sukiyaki-style for the sake of being cool.
I hate games that start off begrudgingly slow, unless they have some sort of engaging exposition that makes the grind more bearable (Terraria does not).
I hate games that insist on having mesmerizing crafting trees that no newbie could ever hope to decipher without keeping a wiki tab open.
But somehow, I love this game and am incredibly addicted to it (I have severe Stockholm syndrome).
I wanna rip my hair out, overall very cool
