I started Terraria back before freshman year of 2016. I've had multiple great memories of this game with my brother. From defeating Plantera, the Wall of Flesh, and to our very first boos of the Eye of Cthulu; these are memories that I wouldn't trade for the world. "ThiS gAme iS JUsT 2d MINecrAfT"
No it is very much not my friends. This game is arguably better than Minecraft in every way. And this is coming from someone who owns both games. 
Terraria is a very fun experience that rewards good strategy (or just good enough luck) with awesome and zany weapons and accessories. The game has over 15 bosses so you'll always be looking forward to something. Also, with over 4000 items to collect and experiment with, you are basically playing the ultimate sandbox game. The game progression is nice and really kicks up in hardmode. You think Skeletron is hard? How bout fighting Skeletron PRIME. Hardmode is the second half of your adventure and the difficulty ramps up signifigantly. The final boss is also a nice way to end your adventure after many trial and errors later. 
Also, Re-Logic just keeps adding new stuff, despite saying many times they are done adding stuff to the game. So this game has longevity.

There is so much to do in Terraria! You can grind for achievements, race for a speed-run, build massive creations, and so much more. I fully recommend this game to anybody who likes a challenge and a good adventure.

Terraria is a two dimensional (2D) sandbox platform with lots of weapons, items, people, non-playable characters (NPC's).  There is a variety of thing to do in the game like fishing, building, Player Vs. Player (PVP), fishing and more. The graphics are excellent for a two dimensional (2D) game and easy on the eyes. The System Requirements very low as well so you can play the game smoothly on almost every system. The game also gets tons of updates at a great pace. There is no story to the game sadly but great lore to read that makes up for the story if you are interested in that kind of thing. There are also a variety of mods made by the Terraria community to play on the Tmodloader. Even I am still playing Terraria to this day even after completing the entire game like lots of people. Mods such at Calamity, Overhaul, Thorium, and every mod brings lost of thing to the party. I would also recommend looking at the Terraria community section for more stuff to see such as builds, videos, Guides and such. Speaking of the Terraria community, is still very much active ever since 2011 when the game came out.

Me and my friends didn't play terraria in a very very long time and we decided to come back to see a lot of new things. my friends was like "Damn, it's been years since we played terraria. Let's play on the hardest difficulty." I was like "What?! Why?!". And he just goes "Why not?." And it's changing the whole entire game when you played on the hardest difficulty. It was a lot more fun, more stress, more funnier. You'll find a lot of ridiculous things. Like what happened to me, i was on full health and almost die because of ONE FREAKING SLIME, A FREAKING SLIME. How ridiculous is that. Or when i was mining, and i found a chest. and when i open the chest, BOOM. EXPLOSION. And since you're playing with your friends, it just become something funny, something to laugh it off.

If you go to the jungle and encounter a Derpling or Giant Flying Fox, there is a 2.5% chance (across all difficulties) that the mobs drop some GRAPES........

The use time is 17 (Very Fast), it gives a medium improvement to all stats and increased life regeneration for 16 minutes. The GRAPES can also be sold for 40 silver coins........

2 GRAPES, a bottle and a cooking pot can create one GRAPE Juice. The GRAPE Juice use time is 17 (Very Fast), it gives a major improvement to all stats and increased life regeneration for 16 minutes. The GRAPE Juice can also be sold for 80 silver coins........

Fun Fact:
Despite real-world grapes being clearly a fruit, Grapes in Terraria do not fit into the Fruits category. They cannot be used to craft Fruit Juice or Fruit Salad, are not dropped from Trees, and both they and their juice give far better buffs than the members of that category. Also, researching Grapes requires 10 of them, unlike all the other fruits that require only 5........

Imagine what Minecraft might be like if it had been made with pixel art sprites and released in the SNES era. That sums up the overall vibe of Terraria pretty well. It also explains why I just can't seem to tear myself away from the darned thing. This devious little indie sandbox title borrows so many ideas from Notch's game that it essentially is Minecraft in 2D, but it also beefs up the familiar gameplay in exciting ways. There's a lot more creepy crawly stuff to kill, and the staggering number of doodads you can MacGyver together into deadly weapons to slay them with is mouth-watering. Say what you will; there's some gnarly fun to be had in these uncharted depths.

After you're done customizing your sprite character, Terraria dumps you on the colorful surface of a randomly generated pixel world with nothing more than a handful of tools and the vague sense that you're meant to build stuff, explore the terrain, and battle monsters. Figuring out exactly how that's done is a little puzzling at first. There's a lone guide wandering around the surface, though his advice is random. The lack of a tutorial meant I had to consult the game's Wiki page to get a better sense of how things work and what can be built. Even so, it didn't take long to get the gist. Though there aren't any real story elements or epic quests to conquer, the strong fantasy trappings instill a desire to adventure nonetheless. There's magic, monsters, and mayhem waiting both on the surface and in the dark caverns below. Uncovering unexpected new prizes and perils is a big part of the game's charm.

The entire game world is destructible, and breaking block lets you collect core resources like stone, wood, and iron that can be used to make cool gear or build structures. Rarer resources are dropped when you slay skeletons, floating fanged critters, and other monsters or when you dig deeper into the subterranean underworld. Since such a large portion of Terraria's gameplay revolves around foraging for different components and seeing what you can build with them, the drive to explore every nook and cranny of the landscape kicks in right away. But it's important to temper your desire to set out exploring in hopes of amassing huge quantities of loot with the pressing need to build shelter and expand your spawn point's home base.

Life on the surface follows a day/night cycle. Exploring topside during the daytime is safer ‚Äì you can pick flowers, roam around, chop trees, and kill weak slimes that roam too close. It's also a perfect time to build houses that serve as shelter and attract helpful NPC characters to your settlement. Things get dicey when night falls; zombie hordes and floating eyeball beasts come out in droves, forcing you to fight or flee. That's less of an issue once you get a sturdy settlement started.

The village development aspect of the game is a clever addition ‚Äì once you discover it exists. You can throw together bare-bones shacks or craft elaborate fortresses that tower upward into the heavens. Either way, you want to deck them out with enough accoutrements to lure NPCs to your village. These support characters can heal you, sell you items, and offer other helpful services. You have to complete a specific task to attract them, and even then they only appear if you've created a room (complete with walls, furniture, lighting, etc.) for them to stay. This offers some tangible incentives to spend time building, beyond the desire to lord over a large stronghold.

Having an elaborate and ever-expanding home base to return to on the surface is satisfying. However, the dark, foreboding underworld is where the real action is. Everything you need to make the most basic items like torches, furniture, and healing potions can be found near the surface, but you have to adventure deep below to uncover the rarest materials. This is where Terraria's gameplay feels more like an old-school action platformer and where it really sunk its hooks into me. Digging for ore eventually uncovers sprawling caverns that are home to many varieties of creepy creatures. Giant slimes, skeletons, burrowing worms, and tougher beasties roam the dark, and they often come charging at you while you're excavating. Exploring is a lot fun on its own, yet it's the strong emphasis on combat that's really appealing. For one thing, stopping to battle monsters breaks up the monotony of digging. Creatures also drop coins that can be used to buy shop items. There's an added risk versus reward element to combat too. Getting killed causes you to re-spawn on the surface with your gear intact, but you'll leave a chunk of your precious coin stash behind.

The real impetus behind adventuring is driven by the insanely deep gear crafting system. Almost everything you pick up in the game is a component used in forging some crucial piece of kit. There are well over a hundred different weapons and items to build. Though some equipment is more functional ‚Äì like protective armor, grappling hooks that lets you navigate with greater ease, and treasure chests for storing loot ‚Äì most of the stuff designed for cleaving monsters into itty bits is just sheer badass. Magical boomerangs, laser pistols, spell books that shoot fireballs, light sabers, and ninja stars are just a handful of the crazier weapons you can build. Hunting down the rare items you need to build the best weapons is obsession forming.

A few other cool nuances enhance the absorbing tasks of exploring, building, and battling away. Journey to the farther reaches of the surface world, and you'll inevitably run into The Corruption ‚Äì a teeming mass of demonic turf filled with extra danger and extra rewards. You'll also uncover demonic altars for forging special items that can be used to summon one of the game's three spectacular bosses to fight (sporting awesome names like "Skeletron" and "Eater of Worlds"). Terraria's multiplayer mode is a blast too. Co-operatively exploring and building with friends or strangers is even more enjoyable than going solo, depending on the folks you play with. Finding an open public server to play on is a real drag, since most fill up within minutes of being posted on the game's forum. The good news is you can create your own server and share it with your pals (or post it online for others to join).

Then guide walked on over next to me, he reached out and grabbed my balls, my slime balls, asking if he could eat my balls, my slime balls he wanted to feast. I tell him no, but he forced himself onto me trying to steal my balls, I tried to push him away, I pushed, I pushed but he was not letting go of my balls, my slime balls.
I gave up and let go of my balls, my slime balls. Seeing my beautiful blue balls in another man's hands brought a tear to my eye. But that tear was not a sad tear, it was a god damn vengeance tear!
Because the guide tripped over the crafting table while eating and started to chock on my balls, my slime balls, I got up and pulled out my wood and jammed it down his throat! Forcing my wood deeper into his filthy hole!
Watching the life fade from his eyes as my ball juices leaked from his mouth, trying desperately to get me off but to no avail. He died chocking on my balls with my wood deep in his throat. 
As I lay there in my ball juices next to a dead body to keep me company, I see a light shining through the cracks of the door, I get up and braced my self for the worse, I open the door with my eyes shut scared to see what was on the other side.
But nothing happened, I slowly opened my eyes to see why death has not come sooner, to be blinded by the sun and all of its beauty, "By god, I made it through the night" I said quietly.

I made a severe and continuous lapse in my judgement, and I don‚Äôt expect to be forgiven. I‚Äôm simply here to apologize.

What we came across in the woods that day was obviously unplanned. The reactions you saw on tape were raw; they were unfiltered. None of us knew how to react or how to feel. I should have never posted the video. I should have put the cameras down and stopped recording what we were going through.

There's a lot of things I should have done differently but I didn't. And for that, from the bottom of my heart, I am sorry.

I want to apologize to the internet. I want to apologize to anyone who has seen the video. I want to apologize to anyone who has been affected or touched by mental illness, or depression, or suicide. But most importantly I want to apologize to the victim and his family.

For my fans who are defending my actions, please don't. I don‚Äôt deserve to be defended. My goal with my content is always to entertain; to push the boundaries, to be all-inclusive. In the world I live in, I share almost everything I do. The intent is never to be heartless, cruel, or malicious.

Like I said I made a huge mistake. I don‚Äôt expect to be forgiven, I‚Äôm just here to apologize.

I'm ashamed of myself. I‚Äôm disappointed in myself. And I promise to be better. I will be better. Thank you.

This is probably one of the most fun games I ever played. The amount of content this game is still getting even after over a decade after its release is incredible, this game deserved the Labor of Love award, more than any other game. 

Content: 9/10 There is so much content in this game. You'd probably need a guide to figure out what to do. Even if you did run out of content, you can get T-mod loader on Steam for free and get popular Terraria mods like Calamity and Thorium or make your own. You can also download maps and resource packs from the Steam Workshop. 

Soundtrack: 9/10 has probably one of the best OSTs ever. Heck even the tutorial theme is good. I won't say more about the soundtrack because I think you should see it for yourself. 

Gameplay: 8.5/10. Gameplay is very enjoyable overall. However, be aware that the game is very hard at the beginning. Your character will probably die... a lot! The game eventually gets easier, until you reach Hardmode. Although, just like the beginning it will get easier, as you get stronger gear and weapons. The game is also very grindy which some people may like and others may not. It's entirely up to personal preference. For example, some weapons like the Rod of Discord have incredibly low drop rates. 

Controls: 8/10 The controls are very good and if you do not like them you can navigate to the settings menu and change them yourself. 

Story: The game doesn't really tell you the story. If you want some story, you will probably need to look up the official Terraria lore online. I haven't really read the lore though, so you should probably check it out yourself.

Length: You could play this game for ages, thanks to the amount of content, the community, and the ability to build whatever you want. Length 10/10

Bugs and glitches: This game has quite a few bugs and glitches from when I played. For example, You can cheese some bosses such as the Dungeon Guardian and the Moon Lord. You can also duplicate items too. 

Best of all, the system requirements are so low that you could run this on a dirt cheap laptop.

Overall, an incredible game that everyone should play at least once. Hopefully Terraria will get content for years and years to come.

I know you've probably heard this a million times, but it really is like Minecraft but 2D. It's still got the same sense of exploration, although there's a little bit more world building involved - not in the sense of actually building things, but with different NPCs and multiple bosses and the such. I've been having tons of fun with it ever since I've started playing it. If you like Minecraft for its exploration, then I 100% recommend you try out Terraria as well.
It's an amazing game. The general gameplay is awesome and well balanced, as well as the fact that instead of having individual worlds, you can have huge campaigns that span across many worlds.

I would say that this would have to be one of my favorite games on steam, I've been playing Terraria in a whole since about 2014 when my brother and I got it for mobile. Then we switched to Xbox 360 edition, and a few years later I picked it up once again with some pals. This game never gets old with other people, especially if you all choose different classes.

The developers are humble as well as work hard; There isn't an major update to date that doesn't have something new to shake up playstyles. Props to Redigit and the rest of the mod team for creating and maintaining this masterpiece for so long, and going out of your way to make the game as polished and beautiful as possible. Not only that, opening the workshop and having your own modloader published, free with a copy of Terraria.

Unfortunately the game isn't perfect, it has a slow start to play in-game and can be a little laggy and resource intensive out-game. Though they have gotten better about optimization, that might just be my computer being a potato.

All-in-All, a good 10/10 for a nice adventure with friends.

I had a lot of fun playing this game on my first play through, in 16 hours I still haven't even managed to start the second part of the main game (hard mode), and I've constantly been finding new things to do, new enemies to spawn, new places to explore, and more challenges to overcome, I highly recommend this game for both casual and veteran gammers alike.

I am a 46 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is now 15. My son recently started Terraria and in less than a week, he had already played for over 35 hours. This was terrible for me, as it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching videos on Youtube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing, but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both my son and I many happy memories.

This is why you should play Terraria in 2022

If you haven‚Äôt already dug deep into Terraria, 2022 is the perfect time to start.

Thanks to more than a decade of constant development, Terraria has become an icon of online gaming. The open-world game has a polished gameplay loop around exploring, crafting, and challenging difficult boss fights. All of that takes place in a randomly-generated world that changes as the game progresses.

If you‚Äôre interested in picking up Terraria in 2022, here‚Äôs everything you should know.

What is Terraria?
Terraria is a procedurally-generated sandbox game built around exploration and combat. Players start with very basic tools and weapons with the goal of improving their strength to take on new areas. Terraria features a very in-depth biome system, which includes designated evil zones including a hell layer. Unlike similar games, Terraria features dozens of boss fights meant to challenge the player and gate progression.

A major selling point of the game is its massive amount of content. From its release in 2011 to 2022, Terraria has gone through over a decade of content additions and adjustments. There are dozens of ways to improve characters and thousands of items to collect and craft.

If the single-player content ever gets boring, Terraria fans can host online worlds to team up with friends and take on the world together.

As a person who has beaten this game, this is definitely my favorite game ever made. It's grindy, but it's fun grindy. This game constantly makes you do something or have some sort of task, like protecting your world from a spreading biome, or collecting ores to make better gear and fight a boss, or building more rooms for npcs to move into. This game has everything, and a price so low it should be illegal. And there's also a gun shaped like a shark, it's pretty kewl.

This is such an amazing game.

While some might compare it to Minecraft, in my opinion, this game isn't about the creative building - though you can still make beautiful structures.

No, what I really love about Terraria is the exploration, the way you improve your gear over time, to overcome the bosses and monsters the game throws at you. And the game is really smart about it, too - there are ways for you to manually summon the bosses, but events will happen automatically over time to nudge you in that direction.

Great, whimsical soundtrack. Tons, and I mean TONS of content and references. Well worth full-price. Go from a doofus to wielding the powers of a demigod.

The "Do you recommend this game?" message has been there for a while so I might as well finally write something.

This game is incredible. Never have I played a game with a progression system quite like this one. It'll make you feel powerful one moment and completely weak the next while never feeling completely unfair. The weapon choices are amazing. The backgrounds are fantastic to look at. The building may seem limited at first but I can tell you from seeing a friend, it'll can take you less than a week to build something stellar. Customizing your character in a world is surprisingly easy (and fun as heck) with the dyes. The bosses are great while a little easy sometimes. The multiplayer aspect is great fun and watching them die in different ways from the chat alone is just hilarious. I could keep going on and on but I think I'll just summarize it with:

It's not just "2D Minecraft", it's a whole other experience entirely. A fantastic one.

sartting off, this is a great game if you have not ever played it, and even if you have I still recommend the PC version. This game is great because it has almost 90+ acheivements, 480+ tools and weapons to collect, 16 bosses and minibosses and tons of different armors and vanity items. Because of this and its wide range of possibilities for character customization it has lots of replayability and paths you can go down, not including the extra difficulty and extreme riches of expert mode, and the hardcore and mediumcore (where you drop all items on death) options for characters. Not only above and the several hours you could spend killing bosses, collecting items, and achievement hunting, there are also many amazing buildings you can make with a wide variety of blocks, and also has a large mechanical system with which you can make circuits and traps of sorts. My last and (probably biggest for those who have friends to play with, I give you all of my F's on my keyboard if you do not) is the co-op. This games co-op is amazing, with friends the possiblites are endless, exploring every cave, taking on hordes and armys together, defeating bosses and then becoming powerful enough to beat them quickly, and making amazing builds and other creations becomes possible, and that is why I heavily recommend this game, with it only being ten dollars.+

This game has been my entire life, it is THE greatest game I have ever played. My father bought me the game for XBox 360 around six years ago, to this day, this is my most played game in my entire life. Yes, I may have stopped playing on the 360, but I have it on Steam now. You could combine all of the hours in all of my games and Terraria would probably have double the that amount, to an exact point, I have been playing this game for 5,235.4 hours in total. 5,235.4 hours is equal to over 200 days! I love Re-Logic for making this game, Thank you!

Terraria is a beautiful game with thrilling action, amazing visuals, and the need to constantly have the terraria wiki open while playing. you'll never feel bored while playing since the game constantly occupies you with something to do. boss battles and exploring new terrains never feel underwhelming. there's always something you can do in each new area you find, be it new bosses and enemies, or finding materials to help you upgrade your weapon and tools. I have over 50+ hours of game play (played on mobile then switched to PC), and even after the end game boss, you still find something to do (and i still have a lot of achievements to get). the music has such a nice nostalgic feel to it, plus the 2D style is very pleasant to the eyes. terraria brings together action, fishing, crafting, and sexy fox women to create an overwhelmingly dynamic game play. This is simply a wonderful game to have. for both hardcore gamers or for those who just want to pass time.

Tried playing it in 2014, never got anywhere. Built a house and didn't know what to do next.
Tried again in 2018, same situation.

But I gave it another run in 2022, playing with my girlfriend (she'd previously sunk 200 hours in) who was a tremendous help, and provided a much better experience with her know-how due to her previous hours. I never knew the game was so complex with the bosses, intricacies of each biome, and baffling amount of weapons/armor. Once I opened and read the wiki, I wanted to keep going.

If you've never played, the music is tremendous. So much so, that I was hearing it in my dreams! The mechanics of the game regarding combat feels fluid when you aren't getting debuffed by enemies or bosses. The visuals of the game are surprisingly stunning, from boss fights to weapon effects to enemy death animations, despite the 2D sidescroller gameplay.

If you're unsure about reentering the game again after a hiatus that didn't end well, try it again and keep the wiki open. Very detailed, highly valuable information and worth having open at all times while you're playing, on either the 2nd monitor or your Steam Browser overlay.

I beat the game too quick in my opinion. I laid out 98 hours in 2 weeks because it was just so enthralling. Managed to unlock all achievements as well. After it's all said and done, there isn't much replay value in Terraria. Unless you decide to beat the game again with a different build/class, or wanna farm up and make stunning structures. 

While my first few playthroughs were torture because I didn't know what was happening, on the come around for the 3rd time and reading up on what the game has to offer, I was instantly hooked.

I believe this was one of the first games I got on steam, and I've basically grown up with it. Started playing near when it came out when I was like 6 or 7 -- I'm 18 now and still absolutely adore the game. It's definitely grown a lot since the beginning, and I love all that they've added, and that they kept putting more work into it even after so many years. 

On first look, the graphics may look dinky, but I think it gives it a nice unique charm, and even if you still can't get past that, everything else would make up for it. I love the soundtrack (and even listen to it when not playing the game sometimes), it has so many novelties inside it and so much character, and it's hard to describe the amount of content the game contains in only a few words. But I can guarantee you can get hours upon hours of gameplay with either defeating bosses, doing quests or tasks, collecting, building, and more. On top of that, you can even play with friends. 

I'll also say that more than likely you'll end up referring to the game's wiki quite often. It's almost necessary with how many items and craftables are in the game -- I can't remember them even after playing for so long.

All in all 11/10 game. I think $10 is a steal. It has been, and probably will always be, high on my list of favorite games.

Hello there!

So, Terraria. It's pretty cool. If you like games like Minecraft but want a game that takes longer than 30 minutes to reach late game in, then I'd recommend this. The game controls well, runs smoothly, and is fun to play. If you have like 3 friends and want a (relatively) cheap game to play together, I'd say this would be a good pick, due to the class system and the fact that it gets fun and hectic with more friends. My one complaint is that there is nothing to do after the final boss, but aside from that, it's a good game. Here is a list on why it is:

-Controls well
-Unique and fun bosses
-Multiple world difficulties and character difficulties for YOUR optimal experience
-Amazing pixel art visuals
-Neat weapons
-Simple but fun combat
-Build customizability with different accessories, buffs, set bonuses, and armor pieces
-Great soundtrack
-Finishing a house or base feels incredibly cathartic

But the game isn't without flaws. These flaws are:

-Lack of post game
-Melee and Mage class are the obvious favorites of the devs
-Hard to find motivation to continue playing singleplayer as a new player for more than 30 minutes at a time
-No cross platform
-Building is limited to 2D tiles and walls but there are ways to allow for tiles be passed through by the player

Overall, Terraria is a 9/10 and is one of the greatest games I have ever played I think you should play it.

[strike]2D Minecraft with Metroidvania style combat and graphics reminiscent of 16-bit era JRPGs.[/strike]

Terraria is a 2D action-adventure sandbox game that revolves around exploration, gathering materials & loot, crafting, building, survival, and combat.

First released in May 2011, Terraria deservedly won the 2021 Steam Award for "Labor of Love". On February 14th 2022, Re-Logic announced the 1.4.4 "Labor of Love" update.

With tons of content added over the years, and mod support, Terraria has a lot to offer. Though it can be overwhelming for new players.

PS: Here's a link to the official wiki, for those interested: https://terraria.wiki.gg/wiki/Terraria_Wiki

This is one of the best games I have ever played, and pretty much the only game I can confidently say is better is Minecraft.

The graphics are simplistic yet satisfying, they provide the player with a fun experience that has an almost retro feel. The game mixes a feeling of survival with a fun joyful 2D side scroller type. There are so many directions for players to go, from speedrunning to building to enjoying the little details. I have played for over 400 hours and have never once been truly "bored" by this game. Due to the updates by the developers the game seems to keep advancing as it's community grows. I have laughed and cried over this game, and when I play it now I feel an intense feeling of nostalgia. It embodies a part of my childhood that I never want to leave behind because of how blissful it seems looking back.

I have no complaints with the combat. The different types of weapons for any level of skill allows the players have a seemingly infinite array of directions to take their combat. You can build arenas or fight in the wild, you can use a flaming mace or an orange deathray. There is no flaw in the combat, and I find myself filling my inventory with weapons I know I'll never use, just because I enjoy how unique they are. Quite simply, anyone can find a way to enjoy the combat because there is something for everyone.

The building is amazing, almost to the level of Minecraft's. The amount of materials allows players to make builds with a huge amount of variety while still using the materials they have on hand, and although I have never been very skilled at building in this game I can tell by the community posts that there is a way for everyone to enjoy it. The fact that building is an essential part of that game (due to NPC housing) encourages players to make building a larger part of their gameplay and practice their techniques. Even I have managed to make a decent house, and for those not in the mood for the challenge of survival there is Journey mode, which perfectly balances on the line of survival and a mode with unlimited resources.

The progression in this game is amazing, the initial struggle to go into the caverns feels like such an accomplishment, and that feeling of accomplishment stays until the Wall of Flesh and beyond. The satisfaction is very much worth the struggle, and the game doesn't feel "too easy". Even if it did, there would be the different difficulties for the players to choose from, so that any age, skill level, or type of person could play this game. And with greater risk comes greater reward, which allows players willing to struggle an opportunity to get better prizes in exchange for their suffering.

The community is amazing, there are all different types of people congregating in one place just to enjoy a single thing, but they manage to do it together. From fanart to building, so many people find ways to appreciate this incredible game. People share, they interact, and they manage to all have this one thing in common. This game holds a special game in many people's lives, including mine. I created my Steam account to get this game, and that's just another way Terraria has genuinely changed me as a person. There is NOTHING wrong with this game, and if you get it on sale, good for you, but this game is, in my opinion, worth every single penny spent on it.

Among the best of the best. Of any game. Ever.
The best description for this game is a creative boss rush, you kill enemies, make houses for NPCs, upgrade your equipment, kill a boss, repeat.

You can theoretically finish the game relatively quickly, but that's where the games prowess is. Terraria has a massive amount of replay-ability. Multiple classes to use (Range, Melee, Magic, Summon), [i] many [/i] weapons and sets of armor to help you on the journey. 

There is no way you can do everything in anything less than a couple hundred hours. I still haven't, and I have played over 200 hours on steam, and at least 100 more on console and mobile before that. Even if you manage to do everything, TModloader is officially supported as an app on Steam, and modding is simply something else. Easily enough for over 1000 more hours of play.

Do I recommend this game? Yes. Simple as that. It has multiplayer as well so the added chaos will make things even more fun.

I just recently broke 1000 hours on this game, so I feel obligated to review it (and I want to, too!).

You‚Äôd think that if I‚Äôve played something for a thousand hours, I must like it. And you‚Äôd be right. Terraria is‚Ä¶ the best game I have ever played. But first, I must give you a little history of myself.

So, Terraria is the first real desktop game I played. By real, I mean not on a web browser (I played lots of arras.io). Before Terraria, I played Minecraft on my iPad. But only creative mode. I really liked building in Minecraft. Anyways, I was at a friend‚Äôs house, and my friend understood that I didn‚Äôt play any video games, so they let me try this game on their computer. I had no idea how to play, but I still liked it. Then, when I got my laptop, they bought me this game. We started playing it together, the three of us (one other friend as well). We finished the game in Normal mode while basically knowing little about how the game worked. Hell, we didn‚Äôt even know about double jumps, dashes, or the Goblin Tinkerer. We didn‚Äôt know why Moon Lord (the last boss) seemed to not be taking any damage. (After, we realized that he summons things that heal him unless you killed them. Even if we had realized at the time, we weren‚Äôt doing enough damage to kill the clots in time, anyways. I died 30 times and healed with the nurse more than 40 times in the winning fight. The fight took 45 minutes with the three of us. In classic mode, boss health doesn‚Äôt even scale, so we should have killed it in 2 minutes, because the average kill time for one person is 6 minutes.) Sorry if you have no idea what I‚Äôm talking about.

After that first multiplayer playthrough, I spent all my time reading the wiki and watching all sorts of youtube videos. Not even playing, just reading and watching. I memorized all the important things about the game, and learned insane strategies. And then I found multiplayer servers.

I had no idea what servers were at the time. I followed a youtube video to join one. I was immediately overwhelmed. So confusing stuff. So, there‚Äôs this server software thing called TShock which is essentially a mod for servers. You can teleport people, give them items, butcher enemies, etc. All by typing in a command! (For those of you that play minecraft, think of the command console. Same idea.) I have the capacity to learn quickly, so I did. The server had all sorts of stuff. I became proficient at the minigames. As of this review, over 700 of my 1000 hours on the game are on that one server. I have tried other servers, but that one is the best, in my opinion. (IP: penguingames.fun  Port: 7777)

The bad side of playing on servers is that you don‚Äôt improve much at the regular game. The minigames (such as Parkour) use weird techniques and stuff that you will never use in a normal playthrough. So, even after all these hours, I am very. Very. Bad. At the base game. But I know the theory and stats.

Okay, here‚Äôs the actual review. Gameplay 10/10. Decoration 8/10. Sprites 8/10. Animation 7/10. UI 8.5/10. Very balanced game overall. In classic/normal mode, if you pay enough attention, you will rarely die. In master mode (hardest mode), everything kills you in 2 or 3 hits, maybe 5 with endgame overpowered armor and stuff. Lots of unique items. Over 15 bosses to fight. Some bosses are bullet hell-type. 10 or so biomes to explore, plus unique structures. Enemies are interesting. Most major bugs have been fixed. 

Lastly, let‚Äôs look at mods. These are player/fan-made additions to the game. Mods can be played using tModLoader, a game that you can get for free on steam if you own terraria. I‚Äôm not going to cover how to install them. Mods vary from overhauling the game, adding better sprites (wait, actually that‚Äôs a texture pack), quality of life, new bosses, new AI for enemies in the base game, to adding extra-large worlds and doubling the number of items. All that! Just for 10 dollars (5 while on sale).

I haven‚Äôt completed any singleplayer playthrough of this game (had other stuff to do), but I am working on defeating all bosses without taking damage. I have also played a few other games since I got this one, namely: DRG (deep rock galactic), Core Keeper, Geometry Dash, and Splitgate. Terraria is still the most fun‚Ä¶

TL,DR: great gameplay, feels smooth and semi-balanced (logic is weird though), lots of content, cheap for the price, endless possibilities. You can build amazing stuff. Overall rating 9.5/10. Get this game. Thanks for reading!

Terraria is my #1 survival building crafting exploration game that I played since it came out.

You get the survival, exploration, build, upgrade, harvest and crafting + tons of items and content. Top-notch bosses, progression across multiple biomes, special events and what not. 

I always felt lackluster playing other games of similar nature, either the crafting and exploration was good, but the combat wasn't and the bosses felt cheap. Or the combat was great but it lacked all the harvesting managing part done well. 

The game is regularly updated, and for someone who got my entire family and friends hooked on the game, I'm still playing it a decade later. Multiplayer is very fun, even tho I completely recommend the single player first, to get familiar with the game.

UPDATES: You no longer need to read the wiki like your life depends on it. The team made the Guide actually be a wiki and even defend itself after years of torment! Items constantly being added, changed so there are so many ways to play the combat, melee ranged magic pets summons. 


Oh and the music will ring in your mind forever and bring you happy feelings. 

This game is nothing short of legendary. You're committing a crime by not playing it.

The depth and complexity of the crafting system in this game *really* scratches a mental itch for me. I love the fact that the best weapon you can get in the first half of the game is made by combining four other weapons, three of which have their own crafting trees. Then that weapon contributes to the best weapon in the entire game, which you get by combining ten total weapons, most of which have their own crafting trees as well. This is the ideal game for someone who loves deep, incremental-progression-type gameplay.

Boy, I started playing Terraria in 2013 when it first came out on the Amazon Appstore. I played it to death on my Kindle Fire, and I instantly fell in love.

Fast forward a few years, I finally got it for PC. Honestly, I would describe this game, but I simply cannot. This game, for all intensive purposes, is a masterpiece not only in the general idea of video games, not only in the content it holds, but is a masterpiece because it allows you, the player, to create your own masterpiece. The play styles, the environments, the challenges especially presented by the fairly new Master Mode, it's all so, so, so incredible. I haven't even gotten around to modding the game, but from what I can tell, the modding community is extremely, extremely strong (applause to all the creators of the mods out there).

But seriously, if you want endless hours of fun, purchase this game. It has to be played to be understood as to why it is such an incredible game. This game is so approachable, yet complex, as I've said, you are the player, you make the choices.

Thank you for the good memories with friends, Re-Logic. And to those reading this review, whether you be veterans, newbies, or those looking to buy Terraria for the first time, just have fun, become immersed in the experience. I am proud to consider myself a 'Terrarian' for sure. 11/10, recommend to anyone and everyone.

After hitting 600 hours, I think now's the time to put in my input. I stated playing pretty young, back when it first came out. A friend had it on his Xbox and we played a bit, but never did anything other than fuck around. All i can remember us chopping trees, and being very annoyed by acorns. Later down the road me and my brother got it for the PS4 and shit got real. The game had turned into something amazing, as I have waited a few years before coming back to it. We played this only, and sometimes guitar hero. This was one of the best ways i spent my time as a 11-14yo. At 15 I actually got a job lmao, anyways-. We played for some months, and made amazing progress, I built a mega base as a surprise, and our faces when we beat expert moon lord were unmatched. We were jumping up and down, hugging eachother, cheering, our dad had to come make us calm down, lol. Anyways, after that we settles down on terraria, and then I head of Tmodloader, back when it was a standalone exe.

Oh. My. God. The mechanic of "modding" was new to me, and it took my maybe 2 weeks to get it to work. I was on a i3 laptop, but it ran, and I was amazed. The gameplay changes hit me like a truck; all these new possibilities for an already legendary game, was so unfathomable to me, and yet right there in my hands was where the power was. And I got right to gaming. For many years now tmodloader has brought me limitless joy, and I know it will bring it to you to. Buy the game, and when you and your friends are done with vanilla, hop on tmodloader to see what really makes terraria, one of the best games I've ever owned

I have 2 simple issues with the game.
-1, this game is absolutely horrible at getting new players in. I was really overwhelmed at the start and thought I should've quit again (I got this game on ps4 before but immediately dropped it right after, the controls on console aren't good.)
-2, Once the game reaches its best part, it just ends so fast and suddenly. Once you beat the final boss there isn't much to do. 

Other than these flaws, I highly recommend playing this game. It's worth it.

Finally. After 240 hours of game play I have completed all the achievements for this game. I love this game so much, there is so much to do and so much to accomplish. Even though I have done so much, there is still plenty of things to do. It makes me so happy that Terraria's last updates and journey's end signified all the great journeys everyone has when playing the game. Over the 10 days of total gaming on the computer, and countless more on mobile, I can safely say that Terraria is the one of the most fun, and well made game. I will love this game forever.

This 5v5 tactical hero shooter by League of Legends developer Riot Games had a stranglehold on me from my first carefully strategized victory. Now, after clocking 90 hours between the closed beta and the full release, I'm still utterly enamored with the brilliant implementation of its superpowered cast and stellar gunplay. The learning curve is steep, but once the cogs of mastery clicked together, it became damn near impossible for me to put Valorant down.

although Terraria is super enjoyable, the game receives WAY too much praise for what it is. Terraria just happens to be the oldest one out there. 
I personally find an issue with the the fact that Terraria often forces you to look for better weapons after certain marks of progression yet makes the variety of viable weapons small. I would really like to enjoy my older weapons without having to worry about the fact that they become completely irrelevant after I beat an important boss. 

there are a lot more small issues about this game that become more apparent as you play. they aren't game-breaking or unbearable at all, but they are certainly obvious.

despite all that, yes the game is great!

[b] It's a very good game, that's really long and expansive for only $10, and you get more than your money's worth [/b] The game is $10, which is a very good price for a game this expansive. I have played the game quite a bit, but I still have stuff to do. It may seem similar to Minecraft from an outside perspective, but it is really different from it. You start off gathering wood, building a house, as well as houses for npc's, mining, etc. But later on you fight bosses, getting the best gear, and you get to the final boss, then you realize that's not the last boss, and you get thrown into harcore mode. Hardcore mode adds a bunch of new items, weapons, enemies, as well as being more difficult. I could talk all day about Terraria, but I need to keep this readable.

While not a bad game, this game requires an INCREDIBLE amount of dedication and time to get anything done.  I have played many directionless games before and enjoyed them, but this is the most open (in a bad way.)  Also not allowing you to browse crafting recipes unless you have ALL of the materials on you is one of the worst game decisions in a crafting game I've ever experienced.  

I know it's overwhelmingly positive... I believe this game must be played and enjoyed by people with no responsibilities and a ton of time to kill (and waste.)  For me, there was just too much mining in the dirt for hours without finding anything worth a damn.

Terraria, what a wondrous and amazingly fun game. Such a great and fun game to play not just solo but with friends, good way to describe Terraria is basically Minecraft but 2d and with over 50+ hours of content. You wanna use a yoyo or a bow or even a giant sword to fight and destroy anything standing in your way? Try this game out. So much armor and weapons and so much content, especially with 1.4 aka Journeys End that came out that adds even more to the game such as golfing. You know the developers of this game absolutely love this game when even after releasing Journeys End they're still adding more content. Please give this game a try if you haven't already, it goes on sale all the time and especially at $10 base price it's definitely worth it. 10/10

PS: The devs also support modding aka TModLoader, free "dlc" that comes with Terraria.

Throughout the many hours of spending my time engrossed with this game, it is definitely a great game to play. What makes Terraria mostly fascinating is that the game is compiled with a lot of content and tasks to complete. In comparison to most survival games such as Minecraft, it includes way more progression and time to finish the game. If you ever feel like the game is too short for whatever reason, you could also make the game more entertaining and long-lasting by installing tModLoader on steam. It's a wonderful game made by wonderful people. So much more than the "2D Minecraft" i thought i was getting all those years back.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

This game has brought me 83 hours of fun so far, and i dont regret a second of it.

Connection terminated.

I'm sorry to interrupt you, Elizabeth. If you still even remember that name.

But I'm afraid you've been misinformed.

You are not here to receive a gift. Nor, have you been called here by the individual you assume. Although, you have indeed been called.

You have all been called here. Into a labyrinth of sounds and smells, misdirection and misfortune.

A labyrinth with no exit. A maze with no prize. You don't even realize that you are trapped. Your lust of blood has driven you in endless circles. Chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber, always seeming so near.
Yet somehow out of reach.

But, you will never find them. None of you will.

This is where your story ends.

And to you, my brave volunteer, who somehow found this job listing not intended for you. Although, there was a way out planned for you, I have a feeling that's not what you want. I have a feeling that you are right where you want to be.

I am remaining as well. I am nearby.

This place will not be remembered and the memory of everything that started this, can finally begin to fade away. As the agony of every tragedy should.

And to you monsters trapped in the corridors. Be still. And give up your spirits.

They don't belong to you.

As for most of you, I believe there is peace and perhaps, warm, waiting for you after the smoke clears.

Although, for one of you, the darkest pit of Hell has opened to swallow you whole. So, don't keep the Devil waiting, friend.

My daughter, if you can hear me, I knew you would return as well. It's in your nature to protect the innocent. I'm sorry that on that day, the day you were shut out and left to die, no one was there to lift you up in their arms, the way you lifted others into yours.And then, what became of you, I should have known, you wouldn't be content to disappear. Not my daughter. I couldn't save you then.

So, let me save you now. It's time to rest, for you, and for those you have carried in your arms...
This ends.

For all of us.

End communication.

Terraria is a game I have sunk a lot of hours in to. It has a way to suck you in and keep you playing for hours on end. A really great game with a lot of replay-ability. But, I would not recommend this game if you are a fan of sexual intercourse. The fact that I can't have sex with any of the non-player characters is almost Orwellian in nature. It's almost as if we were living in 1984 itself. I myself am a professional sexist, so I know a thing or two about sexual intercourse. The fact that I can't perform coitus in my 2D Sandbox game is abysmal. You might say that I could just download mods to my game, but I am not a hacker and hacking is a sin. Socrates once said "The only good is knowledge and the only evil is ignorance", and I feel like the devs of this game are being rather ignorant for not adding mature content to their game. Anyway, I like this game very much other than that major problem that I hope is fixed in a new update.

Now if your here you might want to see what others DON'T like about Terraria. I have a love hate relationship with this game the first thing i will say is the beginning can be slow boring and not fun and for me personally i think a good intro to a game keeps players HOOKED but i can imagine that many players may just ...stop. But the game DOES get BETTER this game does have one the WORST tutorials ever you aren't told what to do at ALL the wiki and guides are the ONLY way you can even ENJOY this game (don't play blind). Now that's fine if a tutorial is for a game in a different genres but this just feels CRUEL also when crafting you can only see what you can craft but i STILL would like to see items i CAN'T. for an example i was making arrows and looking up stuff on the wiki ( you do that a lot ) and come across a item that allows for a dash move ( the master ninja gear ) and i realize i had the parts needed to make it but i had not thought i'd need them anymore so i threw them away and movement in Terraria is very IMPORTANT ( to me at least ). so if i had a way to see items not able to be crafted i would greatly appreciate ( ...hell even minecraft has it). the combat does feel a bit boring i'm not entirely sure how that could be fixed though the bosses in Terraria really CARRY this game the bosses aren't to difficult ( i first try all of them except for duke FishRon and wall of flesh...)but they are very fun, i very much enjoyed the empress of light boss for the fun bullet hell style fight. i also do want to say that this TYPE of game isn't for me i'd rather play different types of game BUT the other survival sandbox games do a MUCH better job at what Terraria try's to do ( don't starve does better combat and art style ) the NPC characters are nice and fun but i do like the mechanic where the NPCs want to live in different Biomes and like different NPCs but i just felt like it was there to WASTE my time honestly because you basically HAVE to have them in different places to get them pylons. pylons are the way to teleport across the map which is VERY useful ( also some randomly spawn anywhere on the map which is stupid instead of just moving in). Now this next part is very subjective but i like the CONCEPT of the crimson and corruption but in execution they are one of the worst game mechanics every i hate ( second only to the grinding needed in octopath traveler ) the infected Biome spreads across the land cool idea. But how do you get rid of it well.... you can use the purified powder which HARDLY works or the Clentaminator which is obtainable in the late game which when the wall of flesh is defeated the world enters hard mode which makes the infected Biome spread FASTER. there is the third option probably the BEST but most annoying... digging a tunnel... all the way around the biome so it can escape to nearby land which is very time consuming and BORING. the game does have a good sense of progression one of the best but to get there is hard and with the beginning being well... bad i'm not sure if many players will get that far i mean 50 percent of players haven't even beat the FIRST BOSS. I do like the addition of the classes in the game it REALLY needed that to be good. i do feel like playing this game blind ( I've never watched an play through of it i don't see ANYONE beating the game or even get to the wall of flesh due to you needing to drop a item into the lava in the underworld which is like the least cryptic way to spawn a boss the moss being duke fishron for needed to use the bug net which is like USELESS normally and then fish with the truffle worm only found rarely in the mushroom Biome. this is one of the hardest games to beat purely blind. this game is selling for 10.00 USD a good price you might as well pick up and some of you might even become part of the big terraria fandom but for MANY i just don't see this game clicking if you want a more survival based game play don't starve if you want a more chilled experience play stardew valley i didn't think it was for me but its was a very good game. also i feel like the game once is beaten just kinda feels... empty like there not much else to do. SO my final verdict is Terraria is a decent game... but i'm not sure it's for everyone with its flaws that just need to be fixed. So thank you for your time and reading. My rating is 6.5 to 6.7

Corruption destroys anything and everything you love... It's nearly impossible to predict if you are a builder. End game will destroy your creations in a heartbeat and it does not stop spreading regardless of how fast or slow you are at killing the "main" objectives. In the long run, a game file will get repetitive and boring as all biomes (and diversity) become corrupted. I only played so long because I desperately tried to save my villages. Just leads to heartbreak anyways.

I was deep underground, far from home, looting one of the many abandoned homesteads left to be discovered in Terraria's ever-generous bounty of nooks, crannies, alcoves, and recesses. To my left I found a twisted bit of minecart rail, populated exclusively by a nest of extremely territorial face-eating bugs that seemed eager to prove that my loose assemblage of iron-hewed armaments weren't cutting the mustard anymore. Whatever. This cabin seemed safe. Sure it was covered in musty spiderwebs, and broken furniture, but there was a golden chest on the top floor and a loom I was excited to take back to my modest township on the bottom. What could possibly go wrong?

As it turns out, nothing was going to go wrong. There wasn't a scripted boss encounter or an interrupting dirge of story exposition lying in wait for any adventurer who breached the walls. That'd be extremely un-Terraria. However, I managed to find something even scarier. if you're an idiot like me, you might not notice the underground reservoir of water above the roof until you inadvertently jam your pickaxe through the last brick keeping it at bay.

The building flooded in seconds, dowsing all of my torches, leaving me in total darkness. I took a few moments to admire the truly unique mess I'd made of everything before pulling out a glowstick (which stay lit underwater), swimming to the foyer, and flinging open the door, which sent the water rushing outwards and away from me. It was a completely improvised solution, in the face of a completely dynamic problem‚Äîeclectic dungeoneering, powered solely by the infinite potential of a player's arsenal. That is the essence of Terraria.

Terraria was an amazing game, as you can do so much things in it, like build a giant castle, or battle a pair of mechanical eyes with some amazing music playing during it. This entire concept is made better with other people, be the entire workshop (we'll get to that later) or multiplayer co-op or battle servers. The workshop expands this entire subject, as you can upload worlds that you're proud of or download worlds you think will be useful or neat to explore. Texture packs can also change the way you see the game, like texture packs that make some old sprites look newer and cleaner, or make some things more visually appealing, such as the jarless critters texture packs. All in all, amazing concept and deserving of all its praise and love.
I've put a few hours into it. Great game!

pretty good game, good music, and is fun

Terraria, for me, was just like Minecraft was to a lot of people, a fun new experience where I could do whatever I wanted, all in a neat little 2D client. One of the [b]only[/b] flaws with the base game is that it gets repetitive after a while. However, the modding community for Terraria is insane, making the replayability value skyrocket. Do you want more cool and fun content separate from the base game? Calamity. Thorium, and Stars Above have got you. Want to play something completely different? Overhaul and RPG Classes are there for you. Need some more quality of life features? There's Magic Storage, Wing Slot, Recipe Browser, and so, so much more. Asides from the mods, you've also got really cool workshop capabilities, with the likes of texture packs, and also a great community and player base. Overall, the Terraria experience has been a blast, and is placed firmly into my top 3 games of all time.
This game (in my opinion) accomplishes what minecraft could not in terms of content. Would highly reccomend.

There's a reason this game has been so good for so long. It's just in a class of its own. And not just to the general public, either. To me. Pretty much every single online friend I've made through steam or through discord has come from this game. I'm going to meet a friend overseas IRL next summer solely due to the connection we made through this game. 2,700 hours and counting have done unimaginable things for my life. This is, far and away, the best game I have ever and will ever play. It's saved me from suicide and gotten me through some tough times and been a source of entertainment, joy, and thrill over the years I've played it.

Thank you, Terraria, for everything you've done for me. I hope anyone who reads this is inspired to pick the game up and give it a spin. It has done a good thing.

Terraria, what a great game!
One of my hands-down, favorite games!

If you enjoy the Action & Adventure, Open-World, Building and Crafting themes and if you are a fan of the Survival, Roguelike, Sandbox, Crafting & Farming and Metroidvania genres. This game is undoubtedly for you.

If you are unaware, Terraria is a 2D open world sandbox game, where there are no limits as to what you can build, fight, craft and explore. With a unique progressive system that allows you to move through the story whilst battling escalating bosses in difficulty and also acquiring better weapons, armors and materials, this should be a no brainer for anyone that got even a slight interest from reading the review so far.

With amazing 2D graphics, anyone can play with even the worst setups. Play alone, with friends, or even play with strangers on online servers! 

The Developers of this game are also really interactive with their community as they often listen to any feedback people have and apply it to their patches. Additionally since the game stopped getting major updates, the developers allow and even promote mods for the game, which I love because they give an even deeper experience!

In conclusion for $10, this is an absolute steal, and a gem of a game! If you haven't already, give it a shot and enjoy every second of your experience! You will not regret doing so!

If $10 is your budget for buying games, then definitely get this one. It's really good, or at least WAS really good for when it actually came out. Nowadays, not so much.

Pros:
* Very fun randomly generated world to explore
* Lots of enemies and bosses
* Different "unique" biomes to explore
* Crap-load of weapons (even if they're mostly copy-paste tier upgrade)
* Really good music

Cons:
* Enemies deal way too much damage. Early and late game. The time you spend upgrading your health, armor, and magic mean literally nothing, as the difficulty never curves out. It stays at "bull****" for the entire game. More than half of the enemies OHKO without the best equipment at your current level, no matter what part of the game you're at.
* Enemies have way too much health. Health sponge enemies are NEVER a good thing in video games. I'm sorry. Again, even with the best gear, the enemies of your current game progression take way too long to kill... and there's A LOT of them. In waves. Especially at night.
* The bosses are boring as heck. They have maybe 3 total attack patterns, one shot you, and take 20-30 minutes to kill in the same way - by cheesing the crap out of it. Extremely boring. The only good boss is the Wall of Flesh. The only one that actually takes some sort of skill and planning.

So again, this game is really grindy, you're going to die a lot due to cheap bullshit, and the game doesn't feel that much different through a 90 hour world. If you want this type of sandbox resource gathering thing, then just buy Minecraft. Minecraft sucks too, but at least it's fair.

this is my favourite sandbox game, for multiple reasons:

1. There is an actual goal and its not like "do it because.. cuz"
2. the game has a lot of unique weapons, and let me tell you: they are all good and reliable at the point you get them
3. this game has 4 "classes": summoner (whips and slaves), ranger (Bows with different effects, Rockets, Bullet guns), melee (don't let the "melee" title fool you, they aren't melee their weapons range from pointy swords, trought boomerangs and yoyos all the way to a sword that shoots swords), and mages.. they.. use mana to do stuff from firing a gun that shoots homing bees, summoning a cloud that either rains blood or rain all the way to a crystal that shoots epilepsy at your enemies.
4. Multiplayer, its fun with some friends
5. lots and lots of game references, like a don't starve seed and a boss, Dungeon defenders event and turrets, yoyos representing real life ones.
6. Have you played trought the game? Time for a new dificulty! now introducing: expert mode, tankier enemies, new boss patterns, and all the bosses give more loot and a new item (just don't do master mode, its a pain.. everywhere)
7. Have you played trought the game in expert mode and almost commited suicide in master mode? Time for mods! raging from resource packs to a whole new game with twice as many bosses! (for mods, you need the base game and a free dlc called Tmodloader and right now its outdated)
8. WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? BUY THE GAME ALREADY!

Terraria is a confusing experience.. its both hard and easy. Simple yet clunky (i just really hate contact damage..)..  Its a unique side-scrolling experience that has steps of difficulty as you play and defeat bosses.. that unlocked more scary bosses.. and so on. The game is both a builder, npc collector and dungeon crawler kinda in one. I found myself having fun exploring around, but i was also overwhelmed by everything so fast. It took a bit to get used to it. 

Combat is simple, building pretty things is kinda forgettable.. NPCs are mostly just there to sell you things, there is no 'real' meat of any story with them. They are less annoying to move around than Minecraft villagers at least. The biomes are actually what I liked most and the bosses were at least fun to fight. The game can be VERY challenging and seems like it'd be a lot of fun with a few friends. I only play with by significant other and we enjoyed ourselves while we did. 

I also just loved using Journey Mode and unlocking stuff to play around with building, slowing down the pace of the game so I could learn more on my own.. actually that's a great way to just 'get' the game. Its also a way to do things a bit faster if your life doesn't afford you a lot of time for games these days. I'm not a HARD MODE FIRST kinda person, but if you are.. oh you can do that too. Just dive right on in to insane difficulty and hope for the best. I like that the game just gives you options. It wants you to enjoy PLAYING the game as you want.

I can fully recommend Terraria as a simple survival-crafting game as it also is great for aging systems, as not all of us can afford to continue the upgrade scam, especially now a days. So, a light weight game, no real bugs to be had by just playing normally, enjoyable with friends on LAN.. yup- definitely a good pickup even if I'm super late to the party.

Despite the many hours i have, Terraria is a good game, but i want to focus on the Good and Bad of the game personally in my opinion

Good:
Beautiful Visuals
Good Soundtrack
Perfect controls
Endless Creativity
and Endless replay ability

Sounds great right? Yes, but their are a some flaws i have with the game.

Bad: 
One important thing that i've been used to but want to say it, the game drags on forever. I know that's a common thing in this game but progression wise, it's very very very slow, doing all of the pre-game progression take a long time, building houses, finding treasure and digging a hellavator to the bottom of the world.

Addiction: Can't you tell from my hours? I spent 777.8 Hours on this game, for my enjoyment, i had fun, but it does not mean that i will again because I played this game way back in 2016 next to starbound. It means that i've been doing the same thing over and over again. From the eye all the way to the moonlord over and over and over and over again. But about the replay ability i mentioned, i know it's all about that but it felt like the same thing over and over again. Prepare for the bosses by building houses, find treasure in the underground and get life crystal's and organize everything at your chests, then fight bosses and get better weapons and items accessories, and the late-game is pretty much the same.

Bosses - If you say that i'm bad, no, i can beat all of the bosses during normal progression, but how the bosses are designed, is very questionable and very much poorly designed, going through one by one,

King slime jumps around and it's considered very easy,

Eye isn't very bad but has a unique pattern of learnable attacks

Eater of world is fine, may be me but sometimes spams the rotten balls at you.

Skeleton - fine boss but knockback is essential

Queen Bee - not bad but if you didn't build an arena, you lost

Goblin and Snowman waves are just enemy waves but minibosses are mediocre, same goes with the other events, those bosses aren't bad but barely require any skill.

by this point you'll have the shield which is very awesome since you don't have to worry about knockback anymore, unless you don't have it.

Wall of flesh - isn't bad but sometimes attacks are random.

Prime Trio: just Harder and more annoying bosses unlike their original states.

and as far as the rest they are basically the same as the other bosses i talked about expect some but it's the same.

That's about it, I recommend this game to anybody but if you don't like sluggish progression stay away.

I've been playing this game for awhile now and I'm not going to go into specifics because you'll be reading an essay if I do.

Point blank; the game is 'okay', it's not great. Sure it has bosses, but the mechanics make the game generally particularly unfun to play either solo or with friends.

You only have two difficulties, what I consider "Easy" and "Impossible at the Start"

Normal and Expert.

Normal is normal. Easy, pathetically so.

Expert basically takes the difficulty and cranks it up to about "Insanity" on most other games. Skipping Hard, Very Hard and Impossible to go directly into the hardest difficulty possible--it's almost as if the people who made that difficulty doesn't understand how difficulty scaling works.

Sure, you can heal with potions but using a single potion--or if you have a mushroom, eating a mushroom--puts you on a 60-second cooldown where you cannot use any kind of healing whatsoever. This is probably one of the worst healing 'balance' systems I've ever seen in a video game ever. Yes, it gives you a ton of healing potions but you're so limited on actually HEALING that you're going to literally have around 500 healing potions at the end of the game and not be able to use them properly.

The game is a platformer and when you encounter bosses, they'll have a thing where if you attempt to leave the combat they'll just instantly teleport on top of you, deal like their damage to you x5 because that's apparently how the developers thought boss fights should go. Or they'll go 'Enraged' and just one-shot you.

For as long as they've had to rebalance this game? I'm not impressed.

I've said it once and I'll say it again; others can enjoy this game, but this game honestly feels like a worse Starbound to me. I actually enjoyed playing Starbound. This game just irritates me constantly. I've never felt like I was cheated or robbed so many times as with Terraria, and I'm just done with it.

Get the game if you like the asthetic, but honestly I wouldn't consider this the 'best' game of its genre. Not even close to it, honestly. All it has going for it is boss fights and over-the-top items. That's literally it.

Nevermind the constant interruptions from invasions, day/night events, and constant bosses attacking you when you're trying to get things done--sometimes multiple nights in a row. More irritating than enjoyable or fun.

Extra Notes:

Terraria is a wonderful game. It's about you, a lone player, in a world of mobs filled with slimes, Vultures and Chimeras/Eater of worlds (there are WAY more mobs than what I stated, however those are the most notable ones in the early game). People who say this is a minecraft clone are only right in the way they are both creative sandboxes. 

Terraria's art style is impeccably gorgeous, spending hours looking at the background of the overworld while listening to the base soundtrack, It's a different experience, an experience I would HIGHLY recommend to anyone interested in 2D Pixel Art LONG games. 

The game's story may not be shone much, however like dark souls, you can piece what happens after every boss you go through. The game never leaves you wanting more, it's progression insanely balanced, same with it's enemy placements. 

For example, the moment you think you're extremely overpowered, the game brings you back to the beginning, building you up to bigger bosses, from Cthulu (spelt wrong im bad ok :( to Wall of Flesh, to Plantera to Golem (definitely a wrong progression order but that's all I could think of). Those aren't the only bosses though, there are dozens of bosses, enough to give you endless hours of content, even in the end-game there are plenty of opportunities to advance your character, to getting infinite flight time (Oh yeah did i mention there are wings?) to getting a flying UFO that can break blocks with over 6 lasers at a time! This game has something for everyone, and oh god don't get me started on the mods!

Mods are free to access from sources such as tModLoader, with the most notable consisting of Calamity, Tremor, Thorium, Magic Storage, etc. 
Mods add hundreds to even thousands of new items, hundreds of bosses, and add a whole new layer to Terraria's progression, and the world gen, like massive labs in the underworld.

Terraria World Generation is also great! There have been no anomalies as far as I'm aware, and the game itself is wonderfully built, on the left OR right side of the world there are dungeons (unanimous in all worlds), however where biomes such as jungles, hallows, etc are are randomised. Each world gives you a different experience.

The Terraria Tech.
Terraria also introduces multiple Technological aspects, such as actuators, wires, the Grand Design, and teleporters. They may be not as advanced OR as advanced as redstone, but they're enough to give a player a wonderfully hidden base by teleporting to the underground. They took time to design these features, and it definitely paid off in my opinion!

Terraria building.

I haven't named much of Terraria's building aspects, however every block placement sound is absolutely pristine to hear, and just building your own base from a couple of wood, stone and walls, is such an accomplished feeling. I dearly recommend, to anyone who is not into fighting or mobs, buy this game for the building. You can go nuts! I made a base that led from the underground with rails that flew into the sky with a cloud base, which had a teleporter to other parts of the map! You can build your base underground, in the sky, or even on the ground like a NORMI- jk.

Conclusion:

This review has had no cohesion, but I will say this. Terraria is a wonderful game for any one 3 and up. It is positively easy to understand, hard to master but wonderful to play for all ages. What you have to do is somewhat clear, and the developer team working behind this masterpiece of a game deserve all the credit they get. They listen to the community and actually input things in the games updates!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
