If you're looking for something a little more complex than Kingdom: Two Crowns but not quite as complicated as Dwarf Fortress, or not quite as boring as Minecraft, you might enjoy Terraria. The fact that it's still being developed after all these years speaks volumes about how much the creators have poured their heart into it.

When I first tried to play Terraria, I rage quit with frustration due to the initial learning curve for all the new buttons combined with dying every time I tried to chop a tree or explore a cave. I gave up and went back to some old games, but I kept seeing a couple friends hopping into Terraria consistently.

I gave it another try, this time I was successful from the start, idk why I had so much trouble the first time...the controls are intuitive. Maybe I was having a bad day the first time I played.

After 400+ hours of vanilla Terraria, including earning 100% of the achievements, I still love this game and highly (HIGHLY) recommend it to fans of the build/craft genre.

Terraria is 11 years old and still receives regular updates from the development team. They listen to feedback and actively search it out on Reddit and Discord, with tons of features and changes coming from the player base. If you've been even remotely interested in Terraria, pick it up. If you enjoyed Starbound or Minecraft, pick up Terraria. Play through the game at your pace, be prepared to spend countless hours exploring, building, and fighting. If you only enjoy this game half as much as I did, you'll be overjoyed!

-Terraria is an amazing game; the only downside that would come to mind with a game like this would be single-player, but this isnt even a problem for terraria as there are countless playstyles one can go for; and they are all rewarded if played well.
But multiplayer is where you will  have the most fun; fighting giant bosses with friends, exploring dungeons; finding new bioms, etc... even though this game can be played and really enjoyed in single player, i would greatly recommend experiencing it with friends, especially considering the "4-pack" available in the store.

-something to know before getting started is that terrarias learning curve and advancements are not linear; they can be completed in different orders and the game will not outwardly tell you what to do, so watch some videos on the game and have the wiki at hand with you most of the time and your first playthrough will go smoothly.

-with all that said; i highly recommend it, it is a 10/10 game that i would suggest to anyone.

I honestly love this game to the bottom of my heart ever since I started playing it on my dusty Xbox 360 when it was first released and then on PS4 and then on my PC! I fully recommend this game to really anybody.

Graphics: For a pixel 2D game this is great 7.5/10

Replayability: Depending on who you are, you could "complete" the game and reset and continue to replay it for very long time doing something different each run. However i'm not in to that really in to that 8/10

First time playing: If you are playing blind, You are overwhelmed with things to create and explore, meaning the first time playing generally makes you exited for the future and what you will become. that feeling is great 9/10

Content: I do not need a paragraph to tell you that there is SO much to do 10/10

Playing online: Having friends play with you in this game make the experience 2x better, what makes it 3x better is when you nor you friend don't know much about this game 10/10

Community: very nice people, but of course there is the fan fiction side of it... 7/10 

Mods: Meh. they create more content to the game, which is fine but the issue is the mods would sometimes add things that would ruin the original experience of the game.  I would recommend not going into mods until you have completed your first playthrough of the game 6/10

NPC's: The characters have a mindset of their own, meaning each person you meet in your journey will be unique to the others with different speaking style and things to sell which adds the feeling of the game being "alive" 7/10

My opinion: This is/going to be a gem in gaming history. My feelings on the game are, even after all of this, its ok. I am a hard person to please with video games and for 150 hours it was fun, but not as long as i wished for me to love it. My memories will never be lost with this game (my opinion:) 8.5/10

Final review: up there was my opinion, here i am putting what the game truly gets placed in

This game saved my life.

I am 42.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you Re-Logic.

Truly a testament to what even a smaller studio can do to make their game better over time. I played Terraria when it first came out with friends, we beat it once and they all were set, I dabbled a bit more before putting it down. I remember comparing Terraria to Starbound, which came out around the same time and is a very similar title, and thought Starbound was a more polished entertaining game at the time. But revisiting this comparison even years ago I found that since Terraria devs had kept patching and improving their game (for free I might add) it was leagues ahead of what Starbound had formed into and stayed as. I remember hearing about a patch that added some new content (1.1 on December 1, 2011) to find some really awesome changes but not enough to replay the game for. Later on I again stumbled upon the news that Terraria had received another patch for more content (Patch 1.2 on September 30, 2013). At this time I was shocked to find this added almost X2 the content to the original! Along with the lovingly thought through changes and improvements to UI, sprites, world generation, items and crafting system, bosses, events, mounts, etc that really brought the game forward from its original release I fell in love again. Playing through the game again with fresh eyes after not really playing since the release 2 years ago I was in for a treat. Terraria has an AMAZING feeling of progression through exploration of the world and crafting system, which also goes hand in hand with boss progression and even the world changes to make it feel less static (which I find is an issue in these procedurally generated world games). Re-Logic has even added more content over the years which just leaves such a nice warm feeling as a player to see a dev love their project and continue to improve it. I think Terraria is one of the best games ever made, not just in its genre. The level of polish and standard that has been achieved over the years really brings Terraria to a prolific place on a pedestal compared to what it started as in 2011.

Add to that the loads of fun you can have with friends here, almost endless vertical progression regarding items and unique in-game events and you have, by my standards, one of the best games I've played. 

Most importantly, Terraria's price tag hasn't changed with all the new additions, no expansion content is paywalled which is trully astounding if you consider that the devs have been working on Terraria for over 10 years.

Absolute masterpiece. That's the only word to explain this game as a whole.

But seriously though, I have a lot to say about this game, so this review will be pretty long and will also be followed by an explanation of why you shouldn't compare this game to Minecraft. If you're wondering about the little playtime I have, I've already played this game a lot before I actually bought it on Steam. Don't ask how I played it, I don't wanna break any piracy rules here. Just buy the game and support the devs because the devs actually care.

[b]Below the main review are pros and cons. Skip to the bottom of this review if you don't want to read essays.[/b]

When people see this game from the outside, they usually think that Terraria just looks like a 2D Minecraft rip-off due to how similar its style of gameplay is at the beginning and its sandbox features. However, I personally think Terraria isn't your usual sandbox, and it has something to do with its long term progression, I would argue that this game leans more towards the RPG side, although it's not totally an RPG.

[h1]Long-term progression[/h1]
One of the most exciting aspects of this game is its long term progression, and despite having a limited world unlike Minecraft being infinite, there are so much more biomes to explore and so much more enemies to fight, including bosses. A reason people might find this game boring is its grindy nature, but that's like 80% of Open World Survival games out there. People generally shouldn't be using that as a reason to criticize this. Despite being pretty grindy, it's not to the point where it takes away the main enjoyment of the game, because the satisfaction you get when you finally get what you want in this game is immense. There is so much layers of discovering, exploring, and fighting, and this is exactly what makes this game so fun, it's VERY experimentative (if that's even a word) and tests your patience a lot.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
Apart from its RPG-like elements, there's also the combat mechanics. Having multiple classes adds a lot of layers to the game's combat difficulty, as you get to experiment and learn more about different styles of combat and how you can use it to your advantage against monsters and bosses. A lot of the weapons always seem to have its own fun and exciting feature, with some of them obviously having its own limits at the same time to test your own skill rather than just purely relying on grinding.

People may complain about the game being too hard at times, which I can agree on when it comes to bosses and some biomes with really strong and overpowered enemies. When it comes to bosses, I don't see it as a problem since majority of games out there will always have one or multiple bossfights that are really hard to beat, which is part of what makes a game good while also making sure you get a good amount of satisfaction afterwards. However, when it comes to some biomes containing multiple strong enemies, they're honestly even more frustrating than fighting bosses especially when you're grinding for items.

While I understand that the game may be trying to test your own patience and skill, I don't really agree on having the player die multiple times without giving an open chance on how to figure things out. You are almost always guaranteed to die when you get cornered, there's multiple enemies, or some enemies might be too fast to dodge, so I feel like they should've toned down the immense difficulty by a bit. I do agree that the fun of it comes from the satisfaction of being able to succeed at something really hard, but personally not really to the point where it's just no longer newbie friendly, since there's no longer any enjoyment left on that part, just pure frustration. This isn't something that affects my enjoyment, but rather something that may affect someone else's enjoyment especially when they're not really the best at playing games.

[h1]Why you shouldn't compare this to Minecraft[/h1]
It gets me a bit triggered whenever people compare this to Minecraft or just simply call it 2D Minecraft, the 2 games are way more different from each other than what you are imagining. Terraria focuses more on adventuring and long-term progression. It's pretty clear with the almost infinite amount of items this game has. Minecraft can be quick and boring for people, simply because survival mode doesn't really have a lot of things to offer when compared to other longer games, but still enjoyable in its own right. I personally think the fun from Minecraft comes from its freedom, building, and multiplayer servers.

By freedom, it's more something to do with creativity which is also related to building. Minecraft is more "free" and casual than Terraria, which is full of really hard and long-term combat and progression. This is generally the reason why I would just recommend Minecraft than Terraria when it comes to playing something "calming", because Terraria is not a calming game at all. If you can't handle frustration, go play Minecraft since it might lean more towards your taste. Building is more enjoyable in Minecraft because it's 3D, it allows for a more experimentative type of building. Terraria has its limitations in building cool stuff because it's 2D, not to say that you can't make cool stuff in this game. Enjoyment varies from different types of games, and these 2 games are completely different types for different people.

Multiplayer servers are also something I find more fun in Minecraft. This is mostly because of how active the Minecraft community is when it comes to making servers and also the amount of people that play in them. While Terraria can have some pretty fun games in multiplayer servers, they are very limited and is not as wide as Minecraft's multiplayer, mostly because people tend to play more singleplayer in Terraria than they do multiplayer, which is something that people mostly play on Minecraft.

I am going to conclude this review by writing pros [+] and cons [-] for people who would rather not read long essays. They are followed by short explanations, but you don't need to read them if you just want a peek of what this game offers.

[b]Pros[/b]
+ Long-term progression. There is a lot of exploration and adventuring that tests your patience and ability to discover and experiment
+ Good combat that has multiple layers of skill, though can be a bit grindy when it comes to collecting weapons and accessories.
+ Good soundtrack. This isn't something I covered in the review, because I don't have a lot to talk about it. It's fun and calming to listen to while playing.
+ Still fun despite being grindy, as you can progress without relying too much on grinding but more on exploration.

[b]Cons[/b]
- It's, well... grindy. If you're wondering why I also have this as a pro, in this case it's mostly a problem with difficulty. You can progress without this but it's hard as hell. Generally a problem for the more casual players.
- Fighting enemies can be a bit too unnecessarily frustrating, which is generally a problem related to grinding as well since you have to fight long waves of endless enemies to get what you want. Difficulty of some enemies can also be a problem.

Thank you for reading this review all the way to end, unless you skipped to the end. Just kidding, thank you for reading nonetheless.

Alright, I can't express enough how amazing this game is and how much fun I have had playing it with my friends throughout the years, and even before I got it on steam, and before I even got a computer I still played it on my Xbox, and so many people when they first look at it they say, "its just 2d Minecraft" But it is so much more! It is so much fun to go around searching the world and discovering new items, accessories, and weapons, then fighting bosses to test your new gear and progress through the game. And once you feel you can stand up to all the mobs, and have such good gear, so you decide to face the waffle(wall of flesh) and win, you are hit with so much more content when entering hardmode. Discovering so many new bosses, items, and ores, while you old gear and weapons can hardly stand up to the new mobs and bosses. And then once you beat the game once, you can try expert, or master mode, and even try out Tmod loader to make the Terraria experience better, and introduce new bosses and items into the game. Overall, I have had a blast playing this game throughout my life, and it has got to be in my top 5 favorite games of all time, and after years of playing it, I still play it with my friends till this day, so I would highly recommend this to anyone who likes survival sandbox games, or to anyone who just wants a really good game to enjoy with their friends.

As someone who spends far too much time playing games, I can safely say there are few better than this. I've spent thousands of hours on Terraria from PS3, PC, PS4, mobile and Switch. The gameplay is heavily repeatable, with each new run-through giving an exciting experience. 
The actual gameplay is incredible. The boss fights, mining, building and exploring never bore me even with after all this time. It can be a thrilling, action-packed game if you want it to be, or it can be relaxing, but it will always be joyful. The game follows your pace perfectly, and with each new update the pacing of the game gets even more perfect when i thought it was already perfect.
The work put into this game by Re-Logic is admirable. After all the time Terraria has been out its been improved and improved and improved countless times, all for free. The game I first played in 2013 is completely different to the game it is now, yet it also isn't as the joyous charm you feel playing the game hasn't changed one bit.
I can literally not think of a single negative for this game. Too addicting?? Too fun??
I'd highly recommend this game to anyone, whether an expert gamer or casual. If you don't enjoy it at first just give it few more hours (reach hardmode) and you won't regret it.

This might just be one of the greatest games ever made. The gameplay is fun, the items are unique, and most everything that you can do is engaging. Do you like to build in your games? Terraria has it. Like fishing for some reason? Terraria has a lot of it. Do you like bosses? Terraria has, in my opinion, some of the most well designed bosses to ever be incorporated into a game. Everything from the music to the enemies has it's own unique charm. The game is beautifully made, and with over 4,000 hours on record as of writing this, I have thousands of memories of playing this game. The nostalgia is amazing, but the game holds up incredibly even when you look past it. I have so much to say about this game and maybe I'll make a more comprehensive review in the future, maybe at 5,000 hours, but for now, all I can say is that this game might have the most bang for your buck in terms of content out of any game on steam. And if not, it's definitely up there for me.

For people that have recently bought this game thinking it might be fun, I'd like to tell you how to find that fun while also progressing. When creating a character and world, choose classic and corruption. The Terraria Wiki will help you out a bunch btw. In early pre-hardmode, things'll be kinda tough, like the EOC or EOW, but if you grind enough you will make it through the top. Same with hardmode, it'll be hard at first, but know what to grind and what not to grind for and you will succeed. You might also want to pick a class. I recommend Mage because it's has a challenge while also being strong as fuck. Great game, I really recommend it to creative people who just wanna massacre some shit

[h1] One of the best on Steam [/h1]

[b]Terraria offers what many games that are "survival/craft" lacks, leading to boring or simply no drive to finish the game, and i have a list to mention:  [/b]
[list]
 [*] A lot of enemies and i'd say 75% of them are unique.
 [*] Unique events that brings different rewards and even the ones not necessary to proggres are detailed.
 [*] A huge(and i mean huuuuge) quantity of itens that you can use to your liking on gameplay and visual.
 [*] There's progression in game is smooth and offers a challenge appropiate to the difficulty selected.
 [*] Progression based in skill/knowledge is also a big thing, leading to many strats/different ways to play.
 [*] Day and night have actual impact in the whole game.
 [*] Multiplayer is fun, has total support for it, and for me, it's the only mining/farm game that doesn't feel like a drag to get 
      everyone to have their itens.
[/list]
[hr][/hr]

[u]I dare say that it's blocks are more diverse than in Mine, with different building methods based on biomes and all that.[/u]

I have 257 hours on this game and currently have a job (let's keep it like that), but I would like to detail my world(s), challenge myself and much more if I had more time.

[u]The only setback i can think for this game, is for people who get things a little slower, or really small children (supposing both are going to play alone) because the learning curve on the beggining is a little by yourself. [/u]

[h1]If you are not in the above, Terraria is a must experience on Steam. [/h1]

Terraria is definitely a game I SHOULD have picked up years ago, an excellent game.
The replay-ability is incredible, seemingly endless, the amount of content brings thousands of items to collect and use for combat or just decoration. in addition Terraria continues to update to this day and brings exciting updates that improve the game and its enjoyment. The hundreds of different monsters ranging from minions, enemies and bosses bring an added challenge especially with more harder difficulties, but the more you traverse your world, the more you can uncover secrets, loots, friendly NPC's and items that can help you in battle.

Terraria is definitely a video-game gem that deserves it's recognition. I recommend this game to those who enjoy a world of the unexpected that can bring a challenge, or those who just want to play a game with some buddies, regardless it is a gem worth playing.
The game can be played in what ever way you want; you are not restricted by anything but you.

I played this game on classic mode a couple of times. 1.4 came out and I wanted to try expert mode, 3 rage quits and Alt+F4s later I'm questioning my life...

i played this a bunch on console with my gf, and i can honestly say its actually pretty fun on normal mode for the first 2 bosses (queen bee and skeletron), but then everything just goes to shit once you start actually taking the game slightly seriously, where really redundant stupid things are required to do things that arent even necessary.

all in all, the game stops being fun once you start trying to beat the wall of flesh. now from what i gather hes not that hard to beat, it just takes a really long time depending on where you are and what you have.

basically i had to build like 10 houses before another guide spawned (because for some dumb reason i couldnt build next to any of my ORIGINAL houses next to my spawn point, im assuming corruption or whatever retarded mechanic it is), and EVEN THEN once i got him to spawn, i literally did not get a SINGLE voodoo demon to spawn.

so i resorted to just digging straight down from where the guide respawned, AAAAAALLLLLLLLLLLL THE WAY down to hell, just sacrifice the guide AGAIN, and to die to the wall of flesh AGAIN, because the geniuses who made this game decided not to tell you what you actually NEED to beat the fucking thing in the FIRST FUCKING PLACE.

its all just a giant waste of time, unless of course youre an absolute BRAINLET who just likes pressing buttons for the fuck of it.

do not waste your life. play smash ultimate.

EDIT: 6/2/2022

upon further play time and just a little bit more patience, ive come to realize that this game is an absolute masterpiece.

its all about the journey, NOT the destination. which is why ive decided to leave the original review in plain site.

ups, downs, and all arounds are to be expected with a challenge, but never in my wildest dreams did i expect to be challenged this much.

all just to realize all i needed to do was drink a couple potions, and just spam demon scythe and bees knees at the wall of flesh and he was dead in less than a minute. 

this is a game for everyone, its as simple as that.

if you dont like this game, youve got something wrong with your head.

It's a great game! If you like looting hidden chests and PvE to then relax building your home with the loot you've gathered, this is the game for you. 2D graphics and beautiful music, miriads of caves to explore and many different monsters to fight. You can build, you can fight, you can explore.

This game is really really good to the point that after playing it for more than 10 hours straight, I would still want to play more. Even though there's a lot of grinding and farming, it's far different than other games that make you do this. No matter how long you grind for items, it never gets repetitive. There is a constant progress throughout the game; weapons that felt overpowered a few hours ago, become trivial and you feel the joy of getting new gear, every single time.

You need to build your own arenas for boss fights and events, houses for NPCs, farms for potions... you name it. And building it in the best way you can, always pays off. (Even if you're not a big fan of building in games)

There is a reason as to why Terraria is one of the best selling games of all time. And as to why you most likely have a large amount of friends who own it on steam. 

Terraria is what happens, when every aspect of a game is flawless. The soundtrack is one of the best of any game ever. Period. However when I say that, I hope you get my full meaning when I say it does not carry this game. Simply because not a single aspect of this game requires carrying. It has, imo, the best progression system any single open world sandbox game has ever had, with the most satisfying gameplay mechanics, boss fights, and loops. 

Going further into the aspect of the gameplay progression, it feels perfect. You start the game weak whelp of a player. You can find a couple of weapons, and hold your own. But for the most part, you're at the whim of the world. As you dig and explore however, you will become stronger and stronger. Then you'll fight some bosses, and get better and better gear. Then right as you're feeling like the master of the world, you'll defeat the toughest boss yet, and it will open a new area, or completely transform the whole world as is, and you'll once again feel weak. But not just because suddenly you're fighting level matched enemies, but because now you're fighting whole new enemies, who can drop whole new loot, with stronger potential. Unlike Skyrim progression (for example) the difficulty scaling of enemies doesn't feel cheap, but earned and satisfying.

The bosses themselves are fantastic. Of course they get tougher just in matter of numbers, such as higher DPS, health, so on, but the complexity and skills required to defeat each subsequent boss gets progressively more intricate and satisfying to conquer. You could take the very first boss, and the very last, (or even any other), and even if they were to do the same numbers in terms of damage, and health, you would still be able to tell which one is supposed to be more difficult just because of the way the bosses fight.

Again not one aspect of this game is lacking. The sound design is so crisp and clean. It's soo satisfying to mine, especially as you get stronger and stronger, and the clean 'tick, tick, tick's of mining blocks get faster and faster.  The art is perfectly what it needs to be for what the game is going for. Simple, but also expressive. Each biome (with the help of all of the unique biome music) looks and feels unique. Each has its own personalities, if you will. The ice biome is unforgiving, with a focus on disrupting movement, whether that's chilling water, or slippery ice. The jungle is very spiky, and most deaths will come from being poisoned. The evil biomes are genuinely very eerie your first times diving into them.

This game is a must have. Singleplayer is a fantastic experience, and multiplayer can be some of the most fun you can have with friends online.

Incredible game. I can barely describe how masterfully perfected this game is. You can tell that the developers spent hours and hours of their time adding content to every little inch and corner of the game. Even after 34 hours of playing, it continues to amaze me. The thing about this game is that you are always progressing. No matter what. There is almost always something going on and something to do. Terraria adds excitement and new things to everything in the game. At no point in my experience of the game has it let me down. You are always finding, doing, or experiencing something new in the game. Every single time you play. Unless you have 100% seen everything there is to see. But thats what mods are for. (; In any case, this game is a solid 10/10. An absolute magnificent work of art, and the masterpiece of all masterpieces.

I absolutely recommend this game to everyone! I've played it for years on Xbox, but recently bought a gaming PC, and I remembered it. It's an AMAZING game, that gives you a sense of accomplishment whenever you overcome a challenge when progressing. Think of a 2D Minecraft, but better in EVERY WAY. It has hundreds of weapons and gear, a extremely large range of enemies of all shapes, sizes, and fighting styles. And completely original music for just about everything, from biome themes, to event music, to unique soundtracks for the majority of the bosses. You can truly play the game anyway you want, at whatever pace you want.

TLDR: I cannot recommend any other game more than this, YOU WILL ENJOY IT.

I've played this game more than any other game on Steam. Nothing really compares to it. You can spend hours and hours exploring just a small fragment of the world, uncovering new biomes, loot chests, creatures, and resources. Fill your inventory with treasures and regroup at base. Craft and trade gear with your friends for strategic boss battles, progressing in difficulty as the game goes on. It can be as easy or as challenging as you like.  Spend hundreds of hours designing and redesigning your bases throughout the world. Meet, save, and add NPCs to your towns, each with unique benefits. I can't say much about this game that hasn't already been said but if you don't already own it, you should just buy it right now. You'll quickly understand why it has such a dedicated fanbase.

This game is honestly amazing! I haven't played a game this fun for ages. Some of my friend said "fake minecraft" "minecraft is WAAAAAAAAAAAAY better" or "That's a 1960's bloody old game" (when minecraft is 2 years older ;) ) but it was amazing. Ofcourse my friend never played it and is a prejudice person but it was amazing. People say it's similar to minecraft (it is kind of) but theres something thats 100% different to minecraft that makes the game way better. Terraria is 99% adventure based and has less of those servers and stuff. There is no end and is just a never ending adventure. Once you get bored of having a completely grinded world, It is time to create a new one. The cool part about this game is that you can create as many players or worlds as you want. The world is completely different and allows you to create a new journey. Also, when you create a new world, The player you used will save!! All the items that was in your inventory will stay there! Overall, Terraria is a complete game of just AMAZING. Some people says 2D games are bad and stuff but that is wrong. This game illustrates the best way a 2D game can. You can make realistic houses in 2D. THIS GAME IS JUST AWESOME WORTH PAYING 15$ GET IT RIGHT NOW.

Terraria Is An Action-Adventure, RPG, Sandbox Masterpiece And Here Is Why...

Terraria not only is one of the best games ever (In my opinion), But it is also one of the most diverse sandbox games I have ever played. For instance, there is a whole class system with totally unique weapons, tools, armor sets and buffs directed to that specific class. There are tons of bosses that are both challenging but fun to fight against. And yes the amount of grinding in this game can be overwhelming at times but it is worth every minute if it means you get to progress further and further to achieve your goal. whether it be trying to collect every set of wings or armor sets in the game for your collection to show off to your friends or building a massive town or mega-mansion to house all of the things you've gathered over time. Or maybe you want to purge the world evil that plagues every corner of your world in an attempt to save it from being corrupted. And if I get started on the community and the support the developers show to them I would probably have to write about another 3 reviews so all i'm going to say is that Re-Logic is amazing for supporting the community, specifically the modding community contrary to some other indie developers. So to put this is short, Terraria is one of the most creatively diverse Action-Adventure, RPG, Sandbox games that i have ever played and i thank Re-Logic for making a game that truly lets me be creative even if its on a 2D space.

This is the type of game that you feel compelled to keep playing, but when all's said and done, you look back and realize the game hasn't given you anything worthwhile. Did this game enrich my life in any meaningful way? No, not really. Did I particularly enjoy my time playing? No, certainly not enough to justify even a fraction of the hours I put in. It's just a boring grind most of the time, designed to keep you addicted without doing much of anything else.

The only compelling reason I can imagine to play this game is if your friends are playing in a multiplayer world, but even then, there are much better co-op games out there. Take my meaninglessly, needlessly wasted time as a warning, and don't play this game. Spend your time on something more meaningful. Another, better game perhaps, or a creative hobby you truly care about.

Ok. If you have not bought this game, and you have steam, you probably should. Most of the reason I love it is the bosses, but it has easy to access and huge building potential, amazing exploration, a reason to go back to biomes you have explored, really fun items, and obviously, great combat. The bosses are some of the most complex mechanically I have ever seen, and are very unique and fun, and yet fighting them is always simple. It's just attack the boss, dodge the attacks. If you have beaten this game and want more, go play Tmodloader. It is currently on 1.3, but will be updating to 1.4 in the near(?) future. So yeah, play terraria. 10/10, best $10 I've ever spent.

The one and ONLY con I've encountered was that, if you let too many drops stay on the ground without picking them up, at least while playing with a friend in a server, it lags the game HARD. This makes doing wave-type defense impossible unless you make sure to actively pick up the drops every minute or so.

Fishing simulator disguised as an rpg. Best in slot weapons? Optimal DPS? Mobility vs Defense vs Offense? Nonsense. You should pay more attention to the time of day: dawn and dusk are the optimal fishing times, though with enough fishing power you can bruteforce any time of day. Fish are more active during full moons and blood moons, though during the latter you will encounter some special enemies (they drop chum which you can use to fish better). Don't forget to take into account the weather: the wetter the better. And you musn't forget about your hidden luck stat, which has a chance to influence your fishing power; to increase your luck, make sure to only place the correct type of torches in their respective biomes (CONSULT WIKI), and place gnomes (that's right). Did you know ladybugs are lucky? Even touching one will temporarily increase your luck; If you kill one or use one as bait however, you will suffer a luck penalty. Grab any ladybugs you find as they can be used for luck potions. Of course you should be using your fishing potions at all times to further increase fishing power. Sonar potions can help you avoid trash fish which will conserve your precious masterbait (or buggys/enchanted nightcrawlers if you don't have any). The pond you're fishing in is TOO SMALL! You're losing 40% of your hard-earned fishing power! Do you seriously not have anything better than a fisher of souls yet!? Sounds like you haven't been keeping up on your daily angler quests. Did you know angler earring's fishing power stacks with tackle bag and lava tackle bag? Send help please.

At first I was a little put off by this title, I won't lie.  I played about a half hour, uninstalled it and put it on the back burner.  I recently decided to give the game an honest shot, and must say I'm hooked.  I was a fan of Starbound already, so the building mechanics are pretty familiar, but this game feels so much more like it was built by a team with a clear vision, rather than one that was slapped together with unfitting pieces by shady developers. (yeah that was a shot fired at Chucklefish)  The controls seem a little lackluster at first, but once you start to get better than starting gear it actually gets to a point where you can terraform your bases as you see fit, and you feel invincible against enemies.  Mid-game the game kicks it up a notch and makes you feel as helpless as the beginning of the game, and doesn't do so cheaply.  There are hundreds of craftable items and weapons, and bosses to fight that are both terrifying and whimsical.  All in all I give this game a hearty thumbs-up, I wish I had given it more of a chance a few years ago but am pleased that it was still in my library.

TLDR: Great game crafted with obvious love.  Hearty thumbs-up.

Alright, TLDR: if you are a fan of any of the genres this game is listed as, this is a must have.

I have been playing this game since it released for the first time 11 years ago and this is by far one of the greatest games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. From the developers who listened to the fans and clearly put so much hard work and passion into this game, to the wonderful community that surrounds it, every second that I've spent experiencing this game grow into what it is today has been an amazing journey.

The overall mechanics are simple enough that an inexperienced player can easily pick them up. The crafting is straight forward, the combat feels smooth and satisfying, exploring is rewarding, and there's enough variety with different building materials that you can truly get as creative as you want. 

Though without a doubt, one of my favorite parts of this game is the progression. Beating a milestone boss feels satisfying, and the rewards for doing so always feel worth it. Usually when I complete a game 100% the achievements are such a hassle, but I truly had a blast the entire time I was completing this game.

And this is all just the base game, the modding community is thriving. With the addition of workshop content and TModloader being put on steam, any player can download it and have a fantastic time making their very own custom content, download additional content to the game, or even just break the game to their hearts content without any risk that a third-party site may have.

Overall, for just $10 there is no reason to not purchase and try out this game. While it may be slow at the start, I promise you that it will quickly grab your attention, or at the very least be a fun distraction for a while.

Terraria is my favorite game. Whether that opinion is formed by nostalgia or objectiveness I can't be certain, but it is one of the few games that I can always go back to. The balance of boss progression and creation is unmatched by any other game I've played, and the memories I've made from the hundreds of hours I've spent in worlds across platforms are some of my fondest. My only complaint is that if you're not creatively inclined like myself, once you defeat the final boss and craft your end game gear, that's the end. This problem however can easily be solved with mods. The love the community and the developers have for this game is truly incredible, and it makes you want to keep coming back. If you've still somehow never played, or had a bad experience and are considering whether to buy or not, I strongly suggest that you give it a try. The start can be slow if you're new, but there's a wiki there to help, and with a couple of friends you're bound to have a good time.

(thank you terraria devs, i love you all)

Terraria has been a part of my life since I was 12 years old, back then I had to partition my macbook's disk to run windows on it just so I could play it. I am now 23 and it remains one of my favourite games of all time. Every time I play through it, it's just as fun as the first time. It's that beautiful kind of game where you can take half a year off and start fresh, having just as much fun as you did the last time.

The game progression is wonderfully crafted to scale with your character, and the bosses give the perfect amount of challenge to keep you pressing on and upgrading your loadout.

11/10 for Terraria, thank you for always being there for me :)

Please keep up the great work!

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Played this cute game for around 7-8 years across a few accounts through most of my late childhood and early adult life. Whenever life was getting me down or something else external was bothering me in any way I would just hop on here and get lost in this beautiful little world. Magic. Thats the only word I can use to describe Terraria in all its greatness. Terraria is pure childhood wonder, bold adventure, and imaginative magic put into video game form. Never before in my life have I come across a game that has left me at a near loss for words when describing its perfection. All I can possibly say to do this game justice is to TELL you, not recommend you, to buy it. I promise you it will be worth it. 

11/10

Amazing graphics for a 2d game, extravagant mechanics, extraordinary boss figths. Deffinedly worth it.

I am 183 years old. My good days are past me, all my friends are dead, and I am very old and sad. I have a 2 year old grandson that became very distant with me as of late, and I wanted to find a way to reconnect with him. I found out he played this game called Terraria, so I made a steam account for free and bought the game. It brought me back to my youth when I went underground and mined for a living and killed god. My life has lost all meaning but Terraria has brought the life back into it. Thank you, Nintendo.

Terarria is a brilliantly designed game.  There is truly nothing like it out there.  Its progression system is meticulously designed to always feel like your character is very strong, but also always challenge you.  The bosses and story progression are all perfect, making the replayability of this game unmatched.  This is proved by my hours that I have amassed on this game.  I am still finding new ways to play this game and have fun with it.  Terarria truly grew up with me and for that I thank the developers for making such an amazing game.  If you are ever considering getting this game, I highly reccomend it.

I am a 54 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Ukrainian men French kissing canines on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

While this game is frequently called "The 2D Minecraft," the similarities between the games seem to end after you punch trees and make a table to craft things. there are obviously more similarities, but this game, in a lot of ways, has so much more to do. This game has a far larger variety of weapons, armors, and tools. along with this, there is a far longer progression with many, many bosses. I am not saying this is better than Minecraft, just different. they are both definitely worth a buy.

Terraria is honestly a masterpiece of a game. I have a long and strange relationship with this game that started when I was around 13 years old. My brother and I received an Xbox as one of our first gaming consoles and Terraria was one of our first games. My brother became obsessed, while I grew to resent Terraria for whatever reason my preteen brain could come up with. That being said whenever I played Terraria I thoroughly enjoyed myself. Later I got Terraria on my 3ds and even my phone, and now I have finally purchased it for my computer. I will never forget the memories I have from this game past, present, or future. It is worth the buy, and at only $10 you get a lot of bang for your buck.

This is not 2D Minecraft. Although it has similar features like, Tool progression through mining, mining - crafting = upragrading and so on, it is not even close to being the same game.

Terraria is a sandbox, boss fighter game. You mine to craft better gear and tools, scavenge caves and skies to gather resources and magical items. You do this to defeat the first boss of the roster consisting of 10's of bosses. You defeat the first boss, get loot, scavenge some more, get better gear and tools so that you can defeat stronger enemies. After gathering and crafting better gear and tools, you defeat the second boss. The second boss is chosen, based on what biome your world is made of. You either fight the eater of worlds or brain of cthulu. It is also important to say that this game, is in no way linear. The game lets you, as the player, choose wether you want to defeat the eater of worlds/brain of cthulu before or after you have defated the first boss. I (in this review) am only writing the bosses with the number that i usually defeat them in. This game gives you full, 100% freedome. Later on, you even have to make a choice, wether you want to be a mage, range, tank, and so on. Your gear, tools, weapons, Magical items, mana, health, ect. makes you the class you want, you can even be a hyprid amd choose to be a mage/range, meaning you have full mana bar and a lot of ammo, with a mix of both range and magic type accesories in your inventory. You heard me, accesories. In terreria you have accesories, accesories are items with stats that gives you abilities or buffs. fx. If you are fond of the class ''tank'' you would usually use a strong, expensive sword, that deals a heavy amount of damage.you can then equip a wide assortment of accesories that enhances the sword, giving the sword damage buffs, fire effect ect. accesories isn't weapon exclusive, some also affect yourself. Some makes you 50% less vulnerable to ex. ice hostiles, where others makes you able to fly or run really fast. 

You can also build in this game. The level of creative freedome in this game when it comes to building is incredible, even more than minecraft. Though it is hidden by the 2D format, your options are near limitless, with thousands of blocks and materials and the hammer tool, making you able to rotate blocks in manyways, makes building so liberating and free.

Npc's are also a big part of Terraria. After you have built your house (or while you're building it) having rooms decorated in a certain way (1x chair, 1x Table, big enough room, wall/background, and light source) npcs will automatically move in. The more rooms + the more you progress in Terraria, the more npcs move into your house. You can even build a village for them if you so please, become the ruler of your own village. Some Npcs, you find while exploring, or after you defeat a specific boss. All the npcs in the game has their own personality and meaning, including their own shop or ''ability'' some of them heal you when you need it (maybe during a boss battle or event like bloodmoon or invasion) (invasion of goblins, pirates, aliens and more) ( events like snow, slime, halloween and more) other npcs sell you items that you can you can use to decorate your house with, some sell weapons and tools, some buffs your weapons and accesories for money, and some just gives you money. 

If you are more of a technic-like player, you will probably like making automatic farms and other types of contraptions.

All of this is just a part of the game, there is so much more. But if you still don't feel like giving the game a chance after reading this review, then the game is probably just not for you. But for me, this is a 10/10

I've been playing terraria for over 5 years now. Started out on mobile when it got to 1.2, now playing it in almost its final form. There isn't a single thing in this game that I dislike. It is an absolute masterpiece that deserves all the love it gets. I only have 365 hours on PC. Overall, it is probably closer to 1,000 hours, combining mobile, console, and PC hours. One thing that I do wish is a way to limit particle effects. I play on a MacBook Air, and every time there is an abundance of particles on the screen, my frames drop dramatically. It is a huge problem with summoners, since the Kaleidoscope creates a lot of particles, bringing my game down to 5 fps. That is my only complaint throughout my many years of playing.

One of my greatest memories is defeating the Moon Lord for the first time. Going from mobile to PC felt like a whole knew world opened up (especially the field of view considering you could only see maybe 10 pixels on the screen at once during that time). Console was great as well, aside from how buggy it was with multiplayer. Having friends over playing 4 player split screen was a lot of fun. After about a half hour or so, the game would start to break, but that's what happens when you essentially have 4 different games running at once on a crappy PS4.

To end the review, I want to personally thank Re-Logic for creating a game that never got old. A game that will forever go down as one of the best games in history. The developers (mainly Redigit and Cenx) are super active in the community, always listening and using ideas from the player base to add to the game. Thank you for having a major impact on my childhood.

Disclaimer: At this point I'm pretty burned out on large-scale adventure games, so usually I steer clear of them, but Terraria piqued my interested recently so I gave it another shot. Thus, I'm not going to review the adventure side of the game. Also, I only play with a gamepad, and while it is a bit awkward, I'm generally satisfied with how comprehensive the support is and it's hard to think of how it could be better.

One of the biggest turn-offs for me is that the scale and proportions of the objects in the game really don't work. The blocks are too small and make it really unpleasant to build or dig. (However, the grid-snapping feature with the direction pad is a lifesaver.) Zooming in the view is a must. Also, it's really annoying to figure out what proportions work for buildings, mineshafts, etc. to make player movement convenient. One thing I noticed in particular is that the player can clear some gaps in one direction but not the other.

I liked the idea of a 2D Metroidvania-ish adventure game with a creative side, but these fundamental design quirks ruin the fun for me.
Amazing game, great game play, worth every cent. Would recommend for anyone who likes creativity in games.

EDIT: very good game

[h1] Terraria [/h1]

Many people have drawn comparisons between Terraria and Minecraft. If you are one of the those people that think Terraria is a rip off of Minecraft or vise versa, it is important to note that the two games inherently have different audiences. Minecraft is a open sandbox, where there isn't much (besides defeating the Ender Dragon to do). A key aspect of Minecraft is being able to build, whether it be a small house or a large castle. Minecraft also has a much wider appeal, with servers allowing players to play mini games or play story maps. Terraria has some similarities but it's main aspect is becoming more powerful and exploring the world as you play. Creating builds is somewhat important but there isn't really something similar to Minecraft's Creative mode to build grandiose builds. Now that we understand that Terraria is a whole different game, let's talk about the key aspects that make up a game.

[h1] Story [/h1]

One of the aspects of some sandbox games is the lack of story. Terraria has some semblance of lore but the story isn't the main aspect of the game. You are a player, who spawns into a new world. You must gather materials and defeat enemies to survive and improve.

[h1] Characters [/h1]

The characters of Terraria are interesting in some ways. While not all of them have lore or characterisation, it is interesting to see how certain characters are connected.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The gameplay of Terraria is arguably the main reason why this game is as liked as it is. You have a variety of biomes, with unique enemies and unique items. There is also unique ore and weapons you are able to collect. The main way you progress in Terraria is defeating bosses. Each one has a unique attack pattern and design, helping them become memorable. Some bosses need a specific item. Some bosses have to be in a certain biome. Some bosses require you to have beaten other bosses. Overcoming each one helps the player realise how powerful they are becoming as they are able to obtain tools, that help to mine certain ore or blocks quicker. There isn't just the bosses though. There are also the NPCs, which offer specific items to help achieve certain things. Each NPC has a unique sprite, unique ways that you obtain them, unique animations and items. Overall, Terraria has various things that players can do, that keeps them from being bored.

[h1] Mods [/h1]

it is important to talk about the mods for Terraria as a lot of them help elevate the experience. One of the more notable mods is the Calamity Mod. This adds new weapons, new enemies, new items and even new bosses. It is so massive that it has it's own dedicated wiki to help players. The Calamity Mod isn't the only mod players can experience but players can search through them using the Steam Workshop and loading them through TModLoader, a separate free application.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Terraria is a game that I believe is an essential part of someone's Steam library. With lots of ways to play the game (Single player, Multiplayer, Journey Mode, Normal Mode, Expert and Master Mode) and the ease of access to mods, Terraria provides many opportunities to allow players to play their game their own way. The only nitpick I have is Journey Mode, namely the fact that you have to "research" items, weapons etc. in order to duplicate them. Some only need to be researched once but some need to be researched 99 times or more. A way they could improve this is remove the grind to get duplicate items as many players don't want to waste hours gathering specific materials.

Rating: 9/10 (A Must for anyone, unless you really dislike combat and just want to build stuff only without grinding).

If you're the type of person to get into the hype that is this game don't get deceived by the game's slow and uneventful start. 
The game doesn't explain itself so you either read a wiki guide on how to progress or play with an experienced friend (much more enjoyable).
If none of these options suit you, the world provides you with a Guide NPC. He will give a vague direction on where to explore and teach you the crafting recipes, although this path will take significantly longer.

If you're an experienced gamer or like a challenge, I recommend starting with Expert mode. It's hard but has more content in it.

Honestly, just start the game by exploring, mining and getting better equipment. The game has loads of weapons and armor to choose from. 

After that start looking to fight against bosses like the Eye Of Cthulu. Then the game will slowly open itself up. 

Be patient and enjoy the game!

The Golem card is unlocked from the Hog Mountain (Arena 10). It is a slow, single-target, melee troop with extremely high hitpoints and moderate damage. When defeated, the Golem explodes, dealing area damage, pushing smaller foes nearby while spawning two Golemites which behave identically but with much weaker stats. The Golem is a colossal, menacing rock brute with team colored crystals growing on its back, while its Golemites appear similarly but are smaller with only one eye. A Golem card costs 8 Elixir to deploy.

[b] Strategy [/b]
An effective strategy with the Golem is to deploy the Golem behind the King's Tower. Due to the Golem's long deploy time and movement speed, the player will have time to generate Elixir and place other troops behind the Golem to make the push extremely effective and difficult to counter. High damage, spell resistant troops are the most effective as they make up for the Golem's low damage per second and still elicit another response as the push crosses the bridge. However, this costs a heavy amount of Elixir, and will leave the player fairly vulnerable for an enemy push in the other lane. Workarounds to this are waiting until the last minute where double Elixir starts, or to use the Elixir Collector to obtain an Elixir advantage.
Note that the Golem has a 3 second deploy time. This makes placing it at the bridge a very situational thing to do as it will be very easy to react to, and the player will not have much Elixir in hand to support it.
The same idea applies to placing the Golem on the opponent's side. The 3 second deploy time will allow the opponent to deal significant damage to the Golem before it starts walking. It can also be exploited by placing a building further away from the Golem's intended target, and can even change which Crown Tower the Golem heads towards after the building expires.
The Golem's death damage is enough to take down any unit with as much or less health than Lava Pups. Tornado can reel poorly spaced defenders into the explosion, and allow the player to fully take out Archers, Princesses, Dart Goblins, or Minions. Ranged units should be at their maximum range, away from the Golem's destination, to prevent unnecessary damage and to make it harder for a Tornado to reel them towards the Golem.
The Golemites also deal area damage upon death, but it is insignificant compared to the health of most cards, only being able to one shot Skeletons and Bats of equal level. This is still useful in taking out these defending foes since it will often allow one Golemite to survive without any defending troops left, letting it deal some chip damage.
Although the Golem spawns Golemites upon death, buildings and troops will start targeting troops behind the Golem since it takes a split second for the Golemites to spawn and the closest targets will be the troops the Golem is protecting. This can easily be fixed by placing a spell such as Zap, Lightning, or Freeze, which can all stun or freeze the Tower changing its target to the Golemites instead. An Ice Spirit or Electro Wizard could also work, but they are blockable and may result in a waste of Elixir.
A Golem is a very effective tank against an X-Bow or a Mortar. Place him at the maximum range of the building to accumulate some Elixir to support the Golem, otherwise the Golem will be overwhelmed by the building's defenders if it is placed directly on the building.
The opponent may try to lure your support troops to the other lane with an Ice Golem, separating them from the Golem. This can be cancelled out by a Tornado, which despite being a negative Elixir trade is still more valuable than letting all the support troops be kited away.
Many buildings provide effective support to distract and damage down a Golem. Even those which do not directly attack can be useful as they can separate the Golem from its support troops.
The Inferno Tower and Inferno Dragon can easily destroy a Golem for a positive Elixir trade if allowed to reach maximum damage stage. The player should always consider packing a card with a stun effect, as this will allow the player to reset the opposing Inferno card's charge and help a Golem push force its way through the defensive building.
Zap is the cheapest and most consistent method of resetting an Inferno card, but it will often not be enough to prevent the Golem from being incinerated unless the Golem has other support troops behind it. Lightning will deal much more damage in addition to stunning, and can also target and fully destroy many glass cannons like the Musketeer or Wizard.
Another method to counter the Inferno Tower is to deploy swarm air troops such as Bats or Minion Horde at the middle of the river. These will distract or simply destroy the Inferno Tower due to its sluggish targeting time. However, these can be spelled down on reaction, leaving the Golem helpless. A Night Witch can continually spawn Bats while being resistant to spells, and her Bats are hard to deal with without a spell in hand as the Golem will be tanking the Princess Tower's shots.
Troops with a shield like Guards or a Dark Prince can stall the Inferno Tower for additional time. Their shields will cause the Inferno Tower to reset on its own when it takes down their shields.
Some Inferno Tower users may play their Inferno Tower at the bridge and slightly into the other lane to avoid the Golem player from using Lightning on both their Princess Tower and Inferno Tower. An Electro Wizard or Electro Dragon are the most effective units in this situation as they will continually stun until the building is destroyed, and then support the Golem on the counterpush, while also being very difficult to block.
The Barbarian Hut is the most effective spawner building at destroying the Golem. The spawned Barbarians will deal high damage to the Golem, preventing it from reaching a Princess Tower with its death damage. Some Barbarians will survive, allowing for a small counterpush.
The P.E.K.K.A. is a fairly reliable counter to the Golem. She has enough damage per second to defeat the Golem before it can attack a Princess Tower, and possesses sufficient health to withstand a good number of support troop attacks. This is also a positive Elixir trade since she only costs 7 Elixir, while the Golem costs 8, not accounting for the support troops behind it. A Mini P.E.K.K.A. can achieve similar results to the P.E.K.K.A but needs to have the other support troops taken out first as it cannot withstand too much damage.
The Skeleton Army is a risky but rewarding counter. While it can be easily taken out by spells and splash units, its damage per second for 3 Elixir will easily demolish the Golem. The death explosion is not large enough to destroy all the Skeletons, meaning that the surviving ones will defeat the Golemites.
The Guards can finish off a weakened Golem reliably. Their shields will allow them survive the Golem's death damage, and they will quickly destroy the Golemites, although they will likely be defeated in the process
Avoid attacking in the same lane of a Golem. This will allow the opponent to defend with troops that were intended to support the Golem, which will be much harder to defend afterwards with a Golem in front of them. Attacking in the opposite lane is more effective. This is because most troops must be played in the same lane as a push in order to defend effectively, meaning they will not be able to support the Golem in the other lane. The Golem player must choose to either abandon their expensive Golem push, which makes their troops a lot easier to address separately, or ignore the attack, taking massive damage.
A Fisherman is very effective against a Golem push. He can either be played in the other lane to drag the Golem as far away as possible from its supportive troops and even force it to switch lanes, or he can be played in front of the King's Tower to lure the Golem to it and activate it.

Man... if U haven't played Terraria, what are you doing with your life. I first bought the game May 16 2012[on ps4] and didn't really know how to play the game. I never fully beat the game on ps4 but got really close. December 26 2019. I build my shiny new pc and the game I first bought was Terraria. I had a blast! The community was better than I ever imagined it would be, the vast ocean of items to use! Millions of blocks to expose my inner builder. It was love at first site. Still was playing Terraria and never got bored, being teased with the update called Journey's End really hyped me up but also made have lots of sorrow knowing that there would be no more major updates. Journey's End releases and it was amazing!!! march 3rd 2022. Dont Starve and terraria crossover!!! Played that and it was amazin!! So Terraria fans... WE STILL will be getting those juicy updates. Thank you for all the memories to come and the ones of the past

[h1] This game is AMAZING. [/h1]

If you are looking for a fun, sandbox, base-building, Minecraft sort of game, this game is the one for you. There are endless items you can get in this game, ranging from statues, to shooting stars from the sky. This game's soundtrack is also one of the best I have ever heard in my whole life, and it adds to the amazing fun you can have playing this game.

Writing a review for this game is like writing a review for The Shawshank Redemption - do you really need me to tell you that Terraria is good? I spent on this game about as much as it costs to buy a cup of coffee in this day and age, and it has consumed so much of my life that the Terraria wiki is lodged more firmly in my brain than anything the education system could've ever hoped to teach me.

Terraria is this eldritch conglomeration of so many things that I love in video games. A truly staggering amount of content has been added to the game in the decade since its release entirely for free (with one last batch on the way too!), the devs have gone above and beyond when it comes to catering to the fans and ensuring that everyone is as happy as possible playing their game, and the creativity of the community just boggles the mind. The possibilities really are endless.

Terraria is a mastercraft passion project that deserves the attention of any lover of the genres it encompasses. Again - I shouldn't have to tell you what thousands of others have already said and in much greater detail, but this game deserves every last ounce of reverence it receives.

Just stop reading my mindless gushing and buy it, alright?

One of the few games that actually stayed true to what they always were. No DRM, no BS, just pure gameplay and fun. In many aspects, the game overdelivered (which I see as a very good thing), so it's packed with countless features for people of any age to enjoy.

Thank you Re-Logic, for staying true to the legendary name of actual gaming (that is slowly being wiped off the planet due to corporatization and greed, sadly).
